UniCredit S.p.a., a bank, experienced a cyberattack on its mobile banking portal. During this attack, unauthorized individuals gained access to sensitive data, including names, social security numbers, identification codes, and PINs of thousands of customers and former customers. The attackers were able to determine the PINs for accessing the portal of over 6,800 customers. The bank had not implemented adequate technical and security measures to prevent such an attack and allowed customers to use weak PINs.

A former employee of VUKMAL TRADE, S.L. discovered that their private mobile number had been disclosed without their consent. The employee was concerned about the unauthorized sharing of their personal information and decided to take action by filing a complaint against the company.

An individual requested access to their personal data from Black Tiger Belgium. The company failed to properly comply with this request. Additionally, Black Tiger Belgium processed personal data across various databases without adequately informing the data subjects. The company also retained personal data for a period of 15 years, which was deemed excessively long. Furthermore, the company's register of processing activities was found to be lacking necessary information.

Provincia di Sassari, a public authority, was required to provide the contact details of their Data Protection Officer (DPO) to the Italian Data Protection Authority (DPA). This requirement is part of the obligations under the GDPR to ensure transparency and accountability in data protection practices. However, Provincia di Sassari failed to provide these details in a timely manner.

Provincia di Catanzaro, a public authority, was required to appoint a Data Protection Officer (DPO) and provide the contact details of the DPO to the Italian Data Protection Authority (DPA). However, Provincia di Catanzaro failed to provide these contact details in a timely manner, which is a requirement under the GDPR for ensuring transparency and accountability in data processing activities.

The municipality of Siracusa was required to provide the contact details of their data protection officer to the Italian Data Protection Authority. This requirement is part of the obligations under the GDPR to ensure transparency and accountability in data processing activities. The municipality, however, failed to provide these details in a timely manner.

ENDESA ENERGÍA, S.A.U. experienced a security breach where unauthorized individuals gained access to its systems. The breach was discovered when Facebook ads were found offering the sale of login credentials for the Endesa platform. This resulted in the compromise of personal data, including names, ID numbers, and bank account numbers, of millions of individuals. The company did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures to protect the data, nor did it inform the relevant authorities and data subjects in a timely manner. Additionally, there were insufficient safeguards for transferring personal data to countries not covered by an EU Commission adequacy decision.

A private individual, acting as a controller, installed a video surveillance camera in a communal area of a residential building. The camera was set up to monitor the area for security purposes. However, the installation and operation of the camera were not approved by the owners' meeting, which is typically required for such communal decisions.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: A private individual installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of public spaces. The cameras were set up to monitor the area, but they also recorded individuals in the public space. The individual did not provide proper information to those being recorded about the data processing activities.

Oney Servicios Financieros E.F.C, a financial service provider, submitted personal data of a customer to a credit information system. This submission was based on an alleged debt that the customer supposedly owed. However, the debt had been cancelled, and this cancellation was confirmed by a court ruling. Despite this, the data was still shared with the credit information system.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: A customer of CAIXABANK, S.A. accessed a document that contained personal data of a third party, including the third party's name and bank details. This incident occurred because CAIXABANK, S.A. did not implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect personal data. The bank also failed to proactively address the issue, instead reacting only after the complaint was made.
violated_articles: Article 25 - Data protection by design and by default

case_content: A private individual installed a video surveillance camera in a residential building. The camera recorded a communal area, capturing footage of residents and visitors. The installation was done without approval from the owners' meeting and without providing information about the video surveillance to those being recorded.

respondent: CAIXABANK PAYMENTS & CONSUMER EFC, EP, S.A.U.
case_content: CAIXABANK PAYMENTS & CONSUMER EFC, EP, S.A.U. included the personal data of an individual in a credit reporting register. The justification for this action was based on alleged debts that the individual supposedly had with the company. However, the matter of the debts was still under dispute in ongoing court proceedings.

A data controller experienced a data breach involving personal data. The data controller was required to notify both the Data Protection Authority and the affected data subjects about the breach. However, the data controller failed to report the breach in a timely manner to both parties.

The municipality of Salento received an information request from the Italian Data Protection Authority (DPA). The request required the municipality to provide specific information within a stipulated timeframe. However, the municipality failed to respond to this request in a timely manner.

A municipality decided to publish information about citizens' Covid cases on its Facebook page to inform the public. However, the municipality did not appoint a data protection officer nor did it provide the necessary contact details to the relevant authority in a timely manner.

VESTA CEU ROMÂNIA SRL, acting as a data controller, disclosed personal data including names, places of residence, salaries, CVs, and copies of passports to its employees without proper authorization. These employees accessed the data internally and subsequently passed it on to third parties.

Account Exchange SRL, a company operating in Romania, collected and used personal data from various individuals. The company did not obtain consent from these individuals before using their personal data. The data subjects were not informed about the use of their data, nor were they given the opportunity to consent to or refuse the processing of their personal data.

An owners' association shared personal data of an individual in a WhatsApp group. The individual later made a request to exercise their data subject rights, but the association did not respond appropriately.

A data controller experienced a data breach involving personal data of individuals. The controller was required to notify the Austrian Data Protection Authority (DPA) about the breach in a timely manner. However, the controller failed to report the breach promptly. Additionally, when the DPA sought cooperation from the controller to investigate the breach, the controller did not cooperate adequately.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of the public space outside the property. The cameras continuously recorded video footage of individuals passing by or present in the public space.

ATLAS ENTERTAINMENT, S.L., a company operating in the entertainment sector, was issued an order by the Spanish Data Protection Agency (DPA) to comply with certain data protection requirements. Despite the order, the company failed to take the necessary actions to comply with the DPA's directive. This non-compliance led to further scrutiny by the DPA.

The Municipality of Athens, acting as a data controller, was required to cooperate with the Hellenic Data Protection Authority (DPA) in matters related to the processing of personal data of its residents. The DPA sought information or assistance from the municipality to ensure compliance with data protection regulations. However, the municipality failed to provide the necessary cooperation or information requested by the DPA.

respondent: Ministry of Rural Development and Food
case_content: The Ministry of Rural Development and Food was responsible for managing personal data related to its operations. However, it did not appoint a data protection officer, which is a requirement for certain public authorities and bodies under the GDPR. Additionally, the Ministry did not sufficiently cooperate with the Hellenic Data Protection Authority when inquiries were made regarding its data protection practices.

A customer of Open Bank, S.A. was asked to provide proof of origin for payments on their account to ensure compliance with anti-money laundering regulations. The bank requested the customer to submit the documents via email, which did not provide a secure mechanism for transmitting sensitive information.

A company processes personal data of an individual. The individual requests access to their personal data to understand how it is being processed. The company provides some information but fails to give the individual a complete overview, including the legal basis for processing, specific data being processed, purposes of processing, and retention period.

Uber Technologies Inc. and Uber B.V. collected and stored data from approximately 120,000 drivers working for them in Europe. The company transferred this data to countries outside of the EU. However, Uber did not provide sufficient information to the drivers about how long their data would be stored or the specific countries to which their data was being transferred. Additionally, Uber made it difficult for drivers to access their data by not placing the digital request form in an easily accessible location within the app. When drivers did request access to their data, Uber's responses were not clear or comprehensible.

SOLAR PROGRESS, S.L., an employer, published a screenshot of an email from a former employee in a WhatsApp group. The email contained a professional question and included personal details of the former employee. The information was shared without removing personal details or obtaining consent from the former employee.

TITAN STRONG, S.L. installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured footage not only of their own premises but also extended to cover public spaces and a neighboring property. The cameras were intended for security purposes.

Mushtaq Rubina Kebabish, a business operating a premises, installed video surveillance cameras to monitor the area for security purposes. However, they did not provide adequate information to individuals entering the premises about the presence of CCTV cameras and the processing of their personal data.

Sectorul 1 al Municipiului București was involved in an investigation conducted by the Romanian Data Protection Authority (DPA). During this investigation, the DPA requested specific information from Sectorul 1 al Municipiului București. However, Sectorul 1 al Municipiului București failed to provide the requested information to the DPA.

A data controller is responsible for managing personal data of individuals. During an investigation, the Polish Data Protection Authority (DPA) requests specific information from the data controller to assess compliance with data protection regulations. The data controller, however, fails to provide the requested information to the DPA.

A data controller was involved in a situation where the Polish Data Protection Authority (DPA) requested specific information from them as part of an ongoing investigation. The data controller was expected to provide the necessary information to assist the DPA in their investigation process.

Amazon France Logistique implemented a system in its warehouses where employees were equipped with scanners to document tasks. Each scan recorded data that was used to calculate productivity indicators for each employee. The system also measured interruptions in activity, potentially requiring employees to justify breaks. The data and statistical indicators were stored for 31 days. Additionally, video surveillance software was used in the warehouses. Employees and external visitors were not adequately informed about these systems.

A patient underwent a COVID test at a health authority. An employee of the health authority provided the patient's COVID test report to the patient's spouse without obtaining proper authorization from the patient.

A private individual was requested by the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA) to provide certain information. The individual did not comply with this request, leading to further actions by the DPA.
violated_articles: Article 31 - Cooperation with the supervisory authority

case_content: LEADDESK, S.L, a company operating as a data controller, was requested by the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA) to provide certain information. This request was part of the DPA's regulatory oversight activities to ensure compliance with data protection laws. LEADDESK, S.L was expected to comply with this request by providing the necessary information to the DPA.

An employee of Sirio S.p.A. discovered that their personal data had been shared with a bank. The employee was not informed about this data sharing and had not given consent for their personal data to be passed on to the bank.

Limit Call S.r.l.s., a telemarketing company, acquired lists of personal data to use for telemarketing purposes. The company did not verify the legality of the data transfer, such as whether the data could be used for commercial purposes or if the data subjects had given their consent. Additionally, the company did not check if the telephone numbers they called were listed in the public objection register.

TECHNINK LEB SRL, a company acting as a data controller, experienced a data breach where personal data of its customers was disclosed to unauthorized parties. The company had not implemented adequate technical and organizational measures to safeguard the personal data of its customers.

A customer of Alior Bank SA terminated their contractual relationship with the bank. After the termination, the customer requested the deletion of their personal data. Despite this request, the bank continued to send unsolicited electronic correspondence to the customer.

UNIPREX, S.A. published a video on the internet showing a violent incident. The video included identifiable faces of the individuals involved in the incident. The company did not anonymize the faces before publishing the video.
violated_articles: Article 5(1)(a) - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: In 2019, International Card Services B.V. (ICS) initiated a process to digitally identify its customers in the Netherlands. This process involved collecting sensitive personal data, including pictures, from approximately 1.5 million people. The aim was to verify the identities of these customers as part of their service operations.

A company, acting as a data controller, was involved in an investigation conducted by the Polish Data Protection Authority (DPA). During this investigation, the DPA requested specific information from the company to assess compliance with data protection regulations. The company, however, failed to provide the requested information to the DPA.

A disciplinary officer of the Polish Bar Association was handling personal data related to legal disciplinary actions. This data was stored on a USB stick. Unfortunately, the USB stick was not encrypted, and it was lost, leading to a potential data breach.

A R.L Spartan Gym installed video surveillance cameras in one of their premises. The cameras were used to monitor the premises for security purposes. However, the gym did not obtain the necessary authorization to operate these cameras. Additionally, the gym failed to properly inform individuals about the presence of the CCTV cameras and the processing of their personal data.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: RCS Mediagroup S.p.a., a media company, published images of an individual. The images were made available to the general public through their media channels. The individual depicted in the images did not provide consent for their publication.

The municipality of Comune di Castel Goffredo conducted job interviews for potential candidates. During these interviews, audio-video recordings were made to assess the candidates' suitability for the job. However, the candidates were not informed about the recordings, nor was their explicit consent obtained for such recordings. The recordings were used by the interview panel to evaluate the candidates' performance and make hiring decisions.

The municipality of Comune di Lonato del Garda conducted job interviews and used audio-video recordings during these interviews. The recordings were intended to assess the candidates' suitability for the job positions they applied for. However, the municipality did not obtain the necessary consent from the job applicants to record these interviews.

A homeowner administrator decided to install a video surveillance system in a residential area. The system was set up to monitor the premises for security purposes. However, the administrator did not seek or obtain the necessary authorization from the homeowners' association before installing the system. The surveillance system began recording footage of the residents and the surrounding area without prior consent or notification to the residents.

A customer of Alpha Bank requested access to their personal data held by the bank. The bank, acting as the data controller, failed to respond to this request in a timely manner. The customer, dissatisfied with the lack of response, filed a complaint with the Hellenic Data Protection Authority (DPA).

A data subject requested access to their personal data from Techno Security s.r.l., a data controller. The data subject expected a response to their request, as is their right under data protection regulations.

A customer of EASYJET AIRLINE COMPANY LIMITED requested access to their personal data held by the airline. The airline failed to properly comply with this request, leading the customer to file a complaint with the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA).

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of a neighboring property. The neighboring property owner was not informed or asked for consent regarding the surveillance that included their property.

A physician prescribed themselves psychotropic drugs. The Polish Minister of Health accessed this information through a database. Subsequently, the Minister published the information on a social network.

In 2021, following the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan, the UK Ministry of Defense was involved in the evacuation of Afghan nationals eligible for relocation to the UK. During this process, the Ministry sent an email to a distribution list of these individuals. However, the email was sent without hiding the recipients' email addresses, thereby inadvertently disclosing the personal email addresses and other personal data of the recipients to each other.

A data controller was responsible for processing personal data of individuals. During its operations, the data controller was required to cooperate with the French Data Protection Authority (DPA) as part of its regulatory obligations. However, the data controller failed to provide the necessary cooperation, which is a critical aspect of compliance with data protection regulations.

A municipality was responsible for managing the personal data of its residents. The municipality used a system that required passwords to access this data. However, the passwords used were insufficiently secure, making it possible for unauthorized individuals to potentially access the personal data of the residents. This lack of adequate security measures raised concerns about the protection of personal data.
A candidate for parliamentary elections sent election advertising emails to a voter. The voter had previously objected to receiving such emails.

A company, acting as a data controller, collected personal data from individuals applying for jobs. The data collected included information that was not necessary for the job application process. The company did not adequately justify the necessity of collecting this specific data for the purpose of evaluating job applicants.

Cluster S-r.l. organized a medical training event where documents containing personal data of a data subject and their deceased son were shared with participants. These documents were not sufficiently anonymized. Subsequently, some of these documents were published on the internet by a third party.

An individual, referred to as the data subject, requested access to their personal data from Amazon Italia Transport s.r.l. The company, acting as the data controller, was responsible for responding to this request. However, the response provided by Amazon Italia Transport s.r.l. was deemed inadequate by the data subject.

A Homeowners Association decided to enhance security measures by installing video surveillance cameras around their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of the public space surrounding the property. The intention was to monitor and ensure the safety of the residents and the property.

A homeowners' association decided to publish an enforcement notice on a notice board. This notice contained the personal data of a property owner. The property owner, upon discovering this, was concerned about the exposure of their personal information to the general public.

A store owner installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of a neighboring property. The intention behind installing the cameras was to enhance security for the store. However, the cameras inadvertently recorded activities occurring on the neighbor's property, leading to concerns about privacy and data protection.

A private individual, acting as a data controller, was involved in an investigation conducted by the Romanian Data Protection Authority (DPA). During this investigation, the DPA requested specific information from the individual to proceed with their inquiry. However, the individual did not provide the requested information to the DPA.

Veranda Obor S.A. organized a lottery and collected personal data from participants, including their names and email addresses. This data was then disclosed on the company's website, making it accessible to the public.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of the public space outside the property. The intention behind installing the cameras was to enhance security. However, the cameras inadvertently recorded individuals who were in the public space, leading to concerns about privacy and data protection.

UPMOBILE SOLUTIONS, S.L., a company operating as a data controller, was requested by the Spanish Data Protection Agency (DPA) to provide certain information. This request was part of the DPA's regulatory oversight to ensure compliance with data protection laws. However, UPMOBILE SOLUTIONS, S.L. failed to provide the requested information to the DPA.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured footage that included not only the individual's private property but also extended to cover public spaces. The individual did not provide proper information to the people who were being recorded by these cameras about the data processing activities.

Kourou municipality, responsible for managing the personal data of its residents, was required to appoint a Data Protection Officer (DPO) to ensure compliance with data protection laws. However, the municipality failed to appoint a DPO. Additionally, when approached by the French Data Protection Authority (DPA) for cooperation in matters related to data protection, the municipality did not sufficiently engage or provide the necessary cooperation.

Employees of Autostrade per l’Italia S.p.A. requested access to their personal data held by the company. The company was responsible for responding to these requests in a timely and adequate manner, ensuring that employees could exercise their rights to access their personal data.

The city of Kópavogur decided to implement the Google Education system to enhance educational services. In doing so, the city selected Google as a data processor to handle student data. However, the city did not adequately assess Google's compliance with data protection regulations, nor did it establish a processing agreement that met the necessary data protection requirements. Additionally, the city failed to ensure that student data was processed solely for the purposes specified and did not appropriately limit the retention period of the data. Despite these oversights, the city worked transparently with the data protection authority to improve its data protection practices.

A data controller was involved in a situation where the Polish Data Protection Authority (DPA) requested specific information from them as part of an ongoing investigation. The data controller was expected to provide the necessary information to assist the DPA in their investigation process.

A data controller was involved in a situation where the Polish Data Protection Authority (DPA) requested specific information from them as part of an ongoing investigation. The data controller was expected to provide the necessary information to assist the DPA in their investigation process.

A private individual obtained intimate images of another person, referred to as the data subject. Without obtaining consent from the data subject, the individual decided to publish these images on YouTube, a public video-sharing platform. The images were accessible to the public, and the data subject was not informed or asked for permission before the publication.

In the context of selling company shares held by the Region of Lombardy, personal data of employees of the companies involved were disclosed. Employees found that by entering their first name and surname into a search engine, they could find a link to a draft contract between the Region and the acquiring company. This contract contained personal data such as income and employment information of the employees.

Hora Credit IFN SA, a financial services provider, accidentally sent documents containing the personal data of another person to a customer via email. Despite the customer reporting the error, the company continued to send messages to the wrong email address. Additionally, the company did not respond to the data subject's request for access to their data in a timely manner.

An individual noticed that an image containing the license plate of their car was processed by Piraeus Leasing S.M.S.A. The individual requested access to their personal data from the company, but the request was not fulfilled.
A municipality published a person's personal data on its website. The person requested the deletion of their data from the website, but the municipality did not comply with this request.

respondent: Employees of Azienda socio sanitaria territoriale di Lodi
case_content: In a health authority known as Azienda socio sanitaria territoriale di Lodi, employees accessed the personal file of a colleague who was also a patient. This access occurred without any medical reason or legal basis, leading to a breach of privacy.

The Open University of Cyprus experienced a data breach where hackers accessed and published personal data of students and alumni on the dark web. The university had not implemented adequate technical and organizational measures to safeguard the personal data.

ALBEN AIRPORT FACILITIES S.L., a company operating in the airport facilities sector, was involved in an investigation conducted by the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA). During the course of this investigation, the DPA requested specific information from ALBEN AIRPORT FACILITIES S.L. to assess compliance with data protection regulations. However, the company failed to provide the requested information to the DPA.

The city of Hafnarfjörður decided to implement the Google Education system for its educational purposes. In doing so, the city selected Google as a data processor to handle student data. However, the city did not adequately assess Google's compliance with data protection regulations, nor did it establish a processing agreement that met the necessary data protection requirements. Additionally, the city failed to ensure that student data was processed solely for the purposes specified by the city and did not appropriately limit the retention period of the data. The city also did not take sufficient measures to secure the transfer of data to the US.

The municipality of Garðabær decided to implement the Google Education system to enhance educational services. In doing so, they engaged Google as a data processor to handle student data. However, the municipality did not adequately assess Google's compliance with data protection regulations, nor did they establish a processing agreement that met the necessary data protection requirements. Additionally, the municipality failed to ensure that student data was processed solely for the intended educational purposes and did not appropriately limit the retention period of the data. Furthermore, there were concerns about the secure transfer of data to the US.

The city of Reykjavik decided to implement the Google Education system in its schools to enhance educational processes. In doing so, the city engaged Google as a data processor to handle student data. However, the city did not adequately assess Google's compliance with data protection regulations, nor did it establish a processing agreement that met the necessary data protection requirements. Additionally, the city failed to ensure that student data was processed solely for the purposes specified by the city, and did not secure the transfer of data to the US adequately.

The municipality of Reykjanesbær decided to implement the Google Education system to enhance educational services. In doing so, they engaged Google as a data processor to handle student data. However, the municipality did not adequately assess Google's compliance with data protection regulations, nor did they establish a processing agreement that met the necessary data protection requirements. Additionally, the municipality failed to ensure that student data was processed solely for the purposes they specified and did not appropriately limit the retention period of the data. Furthermore, there were concerns about the secure transfer of data to the US.

Link4 Towarzystwo Ubezpieczeń S. A., an insurance company, experienced a data breach involving personal data of its customers. The company was required to report this breach to the Polish Data Protection Authority in a timely manner. However, the company failed to do so, leading to a situation where the authority was not informed about the breach within the required timeframe.

respondent: Östersund Municipality's Department for Children and Education
case_content: The Östersund Municipality's Department for Children and Education decided to implement a digital school platform, Google Workspace, across 24 schools in the municipality. This platform was intended to facilitate educational management and improve the digital infrastructure for students. However, before introducing this platform, the department did not conduct a data protection impact assessment to evaluate the potential risks to the students' personal data.

The Norwegian Labor and Welfare Administration (NAV) was responsible for managing personal data related to labor and welfare services. However, the IT systems used by NAV were not adequately secured, leading to potential vulnerabilities. Additionally, a large number of employees had access to personal data, including sensitive information, without proper access controls. There was also a lack of systematic monitoring of how employees used these IT systems, which could lead to unauthorized access or misuse of personal data.

A data subject requested Dante International SA to delete their email from its records. However, the company continued to process the email without the data subject's consent. Additionally, the employees of Dante International SA were not adequately trained to handle such data subject requests.

A customer interacted with an Amazon sales partner, who, due to a system error, concluded a contract with VODAFONE ESPAÑA, S.A.U. without obtaining the customer's consent. The customer's personal data was used to finalize this contract without their authorization.

A student signed a training contract with Centro De Estudios Aeronauticos, S.L. (CEAE). Before enrollment, CEAE required the student to undergo a medical examination, present a medical certificate, complete a health declaration with personal health information, and present a police clearance certificate.

In 2018 and 2019, the municipality of Voorschoten replaced waste garbage cans for houses and underground containers for apartments. These bins were equipped with chips linked to house addresses to monitor waste disposal. The aim was to encourage residents to separate waste by limiting the amount of residual waste they could dispose of. However, the municipality stored the waste collection data for longer than necessary, with garbage can data kept for as long as it was in use and underground container token data stored for five years. Additionally, the municipality did not adequately inform residents about the use of their personal data in this process.

A customer interacted with SUMINISTRADOR IBÉRICO DE ENERGÍA, S.L., an energy provider. During this interaction, the energy provider concluded a contract with the customer. However, the customer had not given their consent for this contract to be concluded beforehand.
A physician received an online review about their practice. In response to this review, the physician disclosed personal health data of a patient publicly.

A private individual decided to create a social media profile. To make the profile more appealing, the individual used a photo of a minor without obtaining any consent from the minor's guardians. The photo was uploaded to the social media platform as part of the profile creation process.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of a neighboring property. The intention behind installing the cameras was to enhance security. However, the cameras inadvertently recorded areas beyond the individual's own property, including parts of the neighbor's property.

A pharmacy owner, acting as a data controller, improperly disposed of a large number of personal documents containing medical information of patients. These documents were placed in public trash containers, making them accessible to the general public.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of public spaces. The cameras were intended for surveillance purposes, but they also recorded individuals in public areas without their consent.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured footage that included not only the individual's private property but also extended to cover public spaces. The individual did not provide proper information to the people who were being recorded by these cameras about the data processing activities.

Libra Internet Bank SA, a financial institution, was required to comply with an order issued by the Romanian Data Protection Authority (DPA). The order was related to the handling of customer data, which the bank was responsible for as a data controller. The bank was expected to take specific actions to ensure compliance with data protection regulations, but it failed to do so within the stipulated timeframe.

QUALITY-PROVIDER S.A. processed the personal data of an individual. The company did not have a valid legal basis for processing this data. Additionally, when approached by the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA), QUALITY-PROVIDER S.A. did not sufficiently cooperate with the authority.
violated_articles: Article 31 - Cooperation with the supervisory authority

case_content: A company implemented location tracking systems on its service vehicles and construction machinery. The system was designed to monitor the location of these assets. However, the company did not provide its employees with adequate information about the use of these location systems. Additionally, the system operated continuously, even outside of working hours, and lacked a deactivation feature, leading to potential over-monitoring of employees.

An individual discovered that their personal data, which was stored by FORO ASTURIAS, had been disclosed to a media company. The media company subsequently published this personal data in a newspaper. The individual had not given authorization for their data to be shared with the media company.

A private individual operates a laundromat and decides to install a video surveillance system within the premises. The purpose of the installation is to monitor the laundromat for security reasons. However, the individual does not provide sufficient information to the customers about the presence of the CCTV system and the data being collected.

A private individual witnessed a violent incident involving minors and decided to record a video of the event. The individual then shared this video with the public, without obtaining any form of consent from the minors or their guardians.
violated_articles: Article 8 - Conditions applicable to child's consent

case_content: Robin Srl, a company, published images of minors in the context of reporting on a violent incident. The images were not sufficiently blurred, making the minors identifiable. The publication was intended to inform the public about the incident.
violated_articles: Article 8 - Conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services

case_content: The Athens Urban Transport Organization collected and processed personal data of passengers as part of its operations. However, it did not implement data protection measures by design and by default, nor did it conduct a data protection impact assessment. Additionally, the organization failed to establish appropriate retention periods for storing personal data.

A hospital, acting as a healthcare provider, disclosed a patient's health data to an insurance company for the purpose of processing an insurance claim. The hospital did not obtain the necessary authorization from the patient before sharing this sensitive information.

A private individual, acting as an advertiser, uploaded another individual's personal data, including their name, picture, and telephone number, to a website to advertise a massage service. The individual whose data was used had not given their consent for this use of their personal information.

Tiscali Italia SpA engaged in a marketing campaign where they sent advertising messages to over 160,000 customers over a period of four months. The company did not obtain consent from these customers for sending such messages, nor did they have any other valid legal basis for processing the personal data for marketing purposes. Additionally, Tiscali Italia SpA failed to provide adequate information to the customers regarding the retention period of their personal data used for marketing.

Compara Facile S.r.l. engaged in marketing activities by making unsolicited calls to individuals. Some of these individuals were registered in opt-out registers, had not given their consent, or had requested the deletion of their data. The company did not provide sufficient information to the individuals about how their personal data was being processed.

Rompetrol Downstream SRL experienced a data breach where customer data was accessed and used internally without proper authorization. This led to the unauthorized disclosure of personal data, including identity card numbers, names, addresses, and places of birth. The company failed to implement measures to ensure that personal data was processed only under its instructions and did not take appropriate technical and organizational measures to secure the data.

Nimbus s.r.l., an employer, implemented a biometric attendance system at the workplace. This system required employees to provide their biometric data, such as fingerprints or facial recognition, to track their attendance. However, the company did not adequately inform the employees about the use of this system nor did it obtain their explicit consent for collecting and processing their biometric data.

Scionti Selezioni Superiori S.r.l., a company, engaged in making marketing calls to individuals. Some of these individuals were registered in opt-out registers or had not given their consent to receive such calls. The company did not implement measures to verify whether the individuals were in opt-out registers before making the calls. Additionally, the company did not provide sufficient information to the individuals about the processing of their personal data, including their rights as data subjects.

respondent: Ministero dell'Ambiente e della Sicurezza Energetica
case_content: The Ministero dell'Ambiente e della Sicurezza Energetica published a document on its website. This document contained various types of data, including sensitive health data of its employees. The document was accessible to the public for a period of 16 days.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: A healthcare provider, Azienda Usl Toscana centro, had stored medical records containing sensitive patient data in one of its former and vacant buildings. This building was publicly accessible, meaning that anyone could potentially access the sensitive information contained within these records. The situation was brought to light when a person reported the issue, highlighting the potential risk to patient privacy and data protection.

During the Covid-19 pandemic, Salvator Mundi International Hospital s.r.l. implemented a policy requiring patients to present a Covid-19 Green Pass to access healthcare services. This policy was initially justified by the need to control the spread of the virus and ensure the safety of patients and staff. However, after the pandemic ended, the hospital continued to enforce this requirement for accessing healthcare services.

An individual requested a refund from APOLLONIA TOPCO, S.L. and was asked to provide their driver's license as proof of identity. The individual felt that this request was excessive and filed a complaint with the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA). The DPA reviewed the case to determine whether the request for a driver's license was necessary for the refund process.

Palombaro s.r.l., a company, installed video surveillance cameras on its premises. The cameras were set up to monitor the area for security purposes. However, the company did not provide adequate information to the employees and visitors about the data processing activities related to the video surveillance. This lack of information included not informing them about the presence of the cameras, the purpose of the surveillance, and how the data would be used or stored.

CHATWITH.IO WORLDWIDE, S.L. operates a website where users visit and interact with the content. The website uses cookies to collect personal data from users. However, the website does not provide detailed information about the purposes of processing this personal data. Additionally, the cookie banner on the website is designed in a way that makes it difficult for users to refuse cookies, as they are only given the option to consent or access the settings page, which requires multiple clicks to refuse cookies.

Indecap AB, a data controller, accidentally sent an email to a large number of its customers. This email contained an Excel document with a report that included personal data of other customers. The document contained sensitive information such as social security numbers, email addresses, and information on selected funds of more than 52,000 individuals.

TRACTAMENT D'AIGUES TEIA, S.L., a company operating in Spain, was issued an order by the Spanish Data Protection Agency (DPA) to take specific actions to comply with data protection regulations. Despite receiving this order, the company failed to take the necessary steps to comply. The DPA, as the regulatory authority responsible for enforcing data protection laws, monitored the situation and found that the company did not adhere to the instructions provided in the order.
violated_articles: Article 58(2) - Failure to comply with an order from the supervisory authority

case_content: OTP BANK ROMANIA SA, acting as a data controller, accidentally transmitted personal data of an individual to an unauthorized third party. This incident occurred due to the failure of the bank to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect personal data.

A private individual, acting as a data controller, was issued an order by the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA) to comply with certain data protection regulations. The individual failed to adhere to this order, leading to further action by the DPA.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured not only the private property but also extended to cover public spaces. The intention was to monitor and secure the property. However, the surveillance inadvertently included areas beyond the individual's property, capturing footage of individuals in the public space.

A customer of DIGI SPAIN TELECOM, S.L. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to an unauthorized third party. This unauthorized party used the SIM card to gain access to the customer's bank account. The telecom company did not verify the identity of the third party nor did it obtain the customer's consent to share their data.

THE BEE LOGISTICS, S.L. was responsible for delivering parcels to customers. In one instance, a parcel intended for a specific recipient was mistakenly delivered to a different person. This resulted in the unintended disclosure of the recipient's personal data contained within the parcel.

A private individual decided to install video surveillance cameras on their property. The cameras were set up to monitor the surroundings for security purposes. However, the individual did not provide any information to the people who might be recorded by these cameras, such as notifying them about the presence of the cameras, the purpose of the surveillance, or how the recorded data would be used or stored.

A physician, in the course of their professional duties, disclosed patient data to an unspecified third party without obtaining the necessary authorization from the patient. The disclosure was not aligned with any legitimate purpose related to the patient's treatment or care.

A hotel installed video surveillance cameras on its premises. These cameras captured footage of not only the hotel's property but also extended to public spaces and private properties nearby. The hotel did not adequately inform individuals, including guests and passersby, about the data processing activities conducted through these surveillance cameras.

A data subject requested FESTINA LOTUS S.A. to erase their personal data. The company, acting as the data controller, did not properly comply with this request. The data subject expected their personal data to be erased as per their request.

UNIQUE HOTEL APARTMENT, a hotel, required guests to provide their identification documents for the purpose of guest registration. The hotel copied and stored these identification documents as part of their registration process.

A customer lost her handbag, which contained her bank card. She requested the bank to block all her banking products to prevent unauthorized access. However, the bank failed to comply with this request, allowing third parties to access her bank products and transfer money using false identities.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras in a location where individuals were present. The cameras were set up to monitor the area, capturing video footage of people who passed by or stayed within the camera's range. However, the individual did not provide proper information to the people being recorded about the presence of the cameras or the purpose of the surveillance.

Company A, acting as a data controller, was ordered by the Supervisory Authority to take specific actions to comply with data protection regulations. Despite receiving the order, Company A failed to implement the necessary measures within the stipulated timeframe. The Supervisory Authority had previously identified issues with Company A's data processing activities, which required rectification to ensure compliance with GDPR standards.

An individual provided their email address to SC Spark Car Sharing SRL. Later, the individual discovered that their email address was being used for third party marketing purposes without their consent. The individual requested the deletion of all their data from the controller's records. Despite assurances from the controller that the data would be deleted, the individual continued to receive direct marketing messages from the controller.

Università Telematica E-Campus engaged in sending advertising messages and making advertising calls to individuals. Some of these individuals had explicitly objected to receiving such communications. Despite these objections, the university continued its advertising activities. Additionally, the university did not respond to complaints from individuals regarding these unsolicited communications.

Mensajero SRL, a company acting as a data controller, experienced a data breach. A link on their website was publicly accessible, allowing numerous files containing customer data to be viewed and downloaded by anyone who accessed the link. This incident occurred due to the lack of adequate technical and organizational measures to protect the personal data of their customers.

A data subject submitted a request to a data controller to access their personal data. The data controller failed to respond to this request within the time frame specified by the GDPR. The data subject expected a timely response to their request, as per their rights under the GDPR.

respondent: Mednow Medical Center di Giugni Marco
case_content: An individual underwent a medical examination at Mednow Medical Center di Giugni Marco. The results of this examination were inadvertently sent to the wrong recipient by the medical center. The individual, upon realizing this error, requested the medical center to address the issue and fulfill their data subject rights. However, the medical center only complied with these requests after being notified by the Data Protection Authority.

Two individuals discovered that documents related to a court case involving them were accessible on a bar association's website. These documents could be viewed and downloaded in a non-anonymous form and were also searchable via Google. Despite repeated requests from the individuals to have the documents removed, the association did not comply.

A company experienced a data breach when a senior employee's company car was broken into, resulting in the theft of a company laptop. The laptop contained personal data of three individuals. The company reported the breach to the Polish Data Protection Authority.

Cez Vânzare S.A., a company acting as a data controller, was responsible for handling personal data of its customers. During its operations, the company accidentally sent emails containing personal customer data to unintended recipients. This incident raised concerns about the adequacy of the technical and organizational measures implemented by the company to protect personal data.

Asl Napoli 3 Sud, a healthcare facility, experienced a ransomware attack. The attack involved a virus that restricted access to the facility's database and demanded a ransom to restore system functionality. This incident affected the personal and health data of 842,000 patients and employees.

A private individual decided to enhance the security of their home by installing a video surveillance camera. The camera was positioned in such a way that it not only captured the individual's property but also extended its view to the public space, including the street and sidewalk in front of the house. This setup resulted in the recording of individuals passing by the house, who were unaware of being filmed.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: Axpo Italia Spa, an electricity and gas supplier, was acquiring new contracts through a network of approximately 280 vendors. Data subjects discovered that contracts had been activated in their names without their knowledge. They only became aware of these contracts after receiving termination letters from their previous suppliers or reminders to pay outstanding bills. Additionally, the personal data provided in these contracts, such as email addresses, phone numbers, and utility numbers, was often incorrect or outdated.

A private individual, acting as a data controller, sent electoral advertising to various data subjects. The data subjects received this advertising without having given any prior consent or authorization for their personal data to be used for such purposes.

The San Severo municipality published a document on its website. This document contained personal data of its employees. The publication was made without obtaining a valid legal basis or consent from the employees whose data was disclosed.

DANTE INTERNATIONAL SA, a company acting as a data controller, sent marketing SMS messages to a consumer. The consumer had not provided valid consent for receiving such marketing communications. The company proceeded with sending the messages without ensuring that a legal basis for processing the consumer's personal data was in place.

respondent: Azienda Sanitaria dell'Alto Adige - Suedtiroler Sanitaetsbetrieb
case_content: A data subject requested information from Azienda Sanitaria dell'Alto Adige - Suedtiroler Sanitaetsbetrieb regarding the lawfulness and accuracy of the processing of their personal data. The organization failed to adequately comply with this request.

GROUPE CANAL+ engaged in sending electronic promotional messages to individuals without obtaining valid prior consent. The company also failed to provide adequate information about the retention periods of personal data in its privacy statement. During marketing calls, the company's processors did not furnish sufficient information to potential customers. Additionally, GROUPE CANAL+ did not adequately respond to requests from data subjects in certain cases and failed to establish contractual regulations for the processing of personal data by its processors. Furthermore, the company did not properly secure passwords for its employees and failed to report a data breach.

respondent: Shardana Working Soc. Coop. a r.l.
case_content: Employees of Shardana Working Soc. Coop. a r.l. requested access to their personal data to understand how their mileage allowances, hourly wages, and salary were calculated. They were particularly interested in the data collected through the company-provided smartphones, which had geolocation systems installed.
violated_articles: Article 15 - Right of access by the data subject

case_content: H&M, a well-known retail company, engaged in sending marketing messages to its customers. Some customers, however, had previously exercised their right to object to receiving such marketing communications. Despite this, H&M continued to send marketing messages to these individuals. The company lacked adequate systems and procedures to ensure that the objections of these customers were respected and that their marketing preferences were honored.

A private individual installed a video surveillance camera in a commonly shared garage. The camera captured footage of individuals using the garage. The individual did not inform the data subjects about the data processing activities related to the video surveillance.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: An individual received two emails and an SMS notifying them that a Vodafone business had activated two SIM cards in their name. The individual had not requested these SIM cards. Upon contacting the phone company to block the SIM cards, the individual discovered that the cards had been activated using a barely legible photocopy of their ID card. The company had not requested an original ID card for registration nor verified the legitimacy of the data. Additionally, the company did not inform the individual how they obtained the photocopy of the ID.

A school in Stockholm installed extensive video surveillance due to past problems with incendiary crimes. The surveillance system included about 50 fixed cameras monitoring hallways, stairwells, corridors, doors, toilets, and student lockers. The cameras operated 24/7, recording images continuously. The intention was to prevent potential fire hazards and ensure safety within the school premises.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured not only the private property but also extended to cover public spaces. The intention was to monitor and secure the property, but the cameras inadvertently recorded individuals in the public space.

An individual rented a room from a landlord. The landlord installed a video surveillance camera in the apartment without obtaining the tenant's consent and did not properly inform the tenant about the video surveillance.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: A debt collection company collected and processed personal data, including sensitive health-related data, of individuals who were both debtors and non-debtors. The company gathered information such as telephone numbers, names, and addresses. They also recorded comments on the health status of debtors and recorded telephone conversations without conducting a legitimate interest test. The company failed to implement adequate technical protection measures to prevent data leakage and did not transparently inform data subjects about the processing of their data.

respondent: Company engaged in gambling and betting activities
case_content: A company engaged in gambling and betting activities operates a website that collects and processes personal data from its visitors through cookies. The company does not provide visitors with the option to give separate consent for different types of cookies based on their functionality. Instead, visitors are only given the option to consent to all cookies at once. Additionally, the company fails to adequately inform visitors about the processing of their personal data, including the legal basis for processing, the function of each cookie, and the retention period of the cookies.

A hotel collected personal data from guests, including CVC numbers of credit cards and copies of identification documents, when bookings were made via email or web form. The hotel claimed this was to prevent misuse of credit cards, even though payment was not processed through these methods. The hotel also failed to provide clear and transparent information to guests about the data collection and use. Additionally, the hotel appointed its manager as the data protection officer, despite the potential conflict of interest due to the manager's responsibilities in personal data processing.

Zagreb Holding d.o.o., a utilities company owned by the city of Zagreb, required service users to provide a copy of their personal identification card to receive invoices via email. Previously, users only needed to provide their name, surname, address, personal identification number, facility number, and user number. The company collected copies of identification documents when there was suspicion of false representation, particularly if the email address structure did not match the user's name and surname. The company did not have established rules for identifying service users requesting invoice copies via email and failed to transparently inform users about the legal basis for collecting personal data for identification purposes.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured footage not only of their own property but also of the public space and a neighboring property. The individual intended to use the cameras for property surveillance.

A private individual installed a video surveillance camera in a commonly shared garage area. The camera was positioned in such a way that it captured footage of the shared space, which is accessed by multiple residents and visitors. The individual intended to use the camera for security monitoring of their property.
NORDETIA CLINICS MÓSTOLES S.L. sent an email to multiple recipients without using the blind copy (BCC) option. As a result, the email addresses of all recipients were visible to each other.

ILUNION SEGURIDAD, S.A., an employer, sent labor-related communications to its employees via email. However, the emails were sent without using the blind copy (BCC) option, which resulted in the personal email addresses of all employees being visible to each recipient of the email. This action led to the unintended disclosure of personal information among employees.

respondent: Azienda Socio Sanitaria Territoriale Ovest Milanese
case_content: Azienda Socio Sanitaria Territoriale Ovest Milanese, a healthcare provider, experienced several data breaches affecting the privacy of multiple individuals. In one instance, a patient's health records were mistakenly given to another patient. Additionally, an email containing information about Covid-19 behavior in multiple sclerosis patients was sent to 198 recipients, exposing all recipients' email addresses to each other. Furthermore, an invitation for a disability assessment was sent to the wrong individual.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: A company experienced a data breach involving the personal data of individuals. The company, acting as a data controller, was required to notify both the Data Protection Authority and the affected data subjects about the breach. However, the company failed to report the breach to the relevant parties within the stipulated time frame.

A customer of a psychotherapy service provider requested access to their stored personal data, specifically the records of their psychotherapy sessions. The company, however, did not provide the customer with the requested records nor did they inform the customer of the reason why these records could not be provided.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured footage of the general public without obtaining proper authorization or consent. The individual intended to use the cameras for security purposes.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: Breikot Management Ltd, a company involved in journalistic activities, processed personal data of individuals for reporting purposes. The company collected and processed more personal data than necessary to serve the journalistic interest of the public.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras at their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of the public space outside the property. The cameras continuously recorded video footage of individuals passing by or present in the public space.

Athletes participating in sports competitions organized by FEDERACIÓN DE BALONMANO DE CASTILLA LA MANCHA were required to upload their COVID-19 vaccination certificate, a certificate of recovery, or a negative antigen test result to the controller's website 48 hours before the events. This requirement was set to ensure the safety and health of participants during the competitions.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data
Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: A data subject, who was a witness to the will of a recently deceased actress, found their personal data published in an online newspaper. The publication included a photo showing the will of the actress. Following the publication, the data subject was contacted by acquaintances and journalists seeking more information about the actress's death.

UAT Comuna Albeni, a data controller, was involved in an investigation conducted by the Romanian Data Protection Authority (DPA). During this investigation, the DPA requested specific information from UAT Comuna Albeni to assess compliance with data protection regulations. However, UAT Comuna Albeni failed to provide the requested information to the DPA.

CHINA CENTER LLEIDA installed video surveillance cameras on their premises to monitor activities for security purposes. However, they did not provide sufficient information to individuals about the data processing activities related to the video surveillance, such as the purpose of the surveillance, the identity of the data controller, or the rights of the data subjects.

A customer of DIGI SPAIN TELECOM, S.L. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to an unauthorized third party. This unauthorized individual used the duplicate SIM card to gain access to the customer's bank account. The telecom company had not verified the identity of the third party nor obtained the customer's consent before issuing the duplicate SIM card.

respondent: EUROPA PRESS DE CATALUNYA, S.A., Other media outlets
case_content: Several media outlets, including EUROPA PRESS DE CATALUNYA, S.A., published an audio recording of a rape victim's testimony in court on their websites. The case had attracted significant media attention, and the outlets aimed to report on the proceedings by sharing the audio recordings.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured footage that included not only their own property but also extended to cover public spaces and a neighboring property. The individual did not provide proper information to the people being recorded about the data processing activities being conducted through the video surveillance.

Digi Telecommunications and Services Ltd., a company providing telecommunications services, maintained a website where personal data of its customers and newsletter subscribers were stored. An unauthorized party managed to access this personal data through the company's website. The company had not implemented adequate technical and organizational measures to protect the personal data, which allowed the unauthorized access to occur.

Two individuals ordered parcels for home delivery. However, instead of being delivered to their homes, the parcels were redirected to a courier service office. This change in delivery terms was made without the individuals' consent.

Prodav srl, a company operating a shop, installed video surveillance cameras within their premises. These cameras were used to monitor the shop for security purposes. However, the company did not obtain the necessary authorization to operate these cameras. Additionally, they failed to provide adequate information to customers and visitors about the presence of the CCTV system and the processing of their personal data.

A customer of an energy supply company, SUMINISTRADOR IBÉRICO DE ENERGÍA, S.L., discovered that their electricity and gas supply company had been changed without their prior consent. The customer had not authorized this change and was unaware of the switch until they noticed discrepancies in their energy supply services.

An individual rented a room from a landlord. The landlord installed a video surveillance camera in the shared kitchen area. The tenant was not informed about the camera installation and did not provide consent for being recorded in the shared space.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of neighboring properties. The individual intended to use the cameras for security purposes.

A former employee of AcegasApsAmga SpA requested access to their personal data from the company. The employee needed this data to prepare a defense in an ongoing disciplinary proceeding. Despite the request, the company failed to provide the requested data.

TikTok Limited, a social media platform, set the profiles of child users to public access by default, allowing their personal data to be accessible to the public and non-child users. The platform also introduced a 'Family Pairing' feature, enabling non-child users to link their accounts with child users, which posed a security risk. Additionally, TikTok did not provide child users with adequate information about who could access their data or the implications of data processing. The platform also used 'dark patterns' to influence users to choose less privacy-friendly options.

Suomen Yritysrekisteri, a company acting as a data controller, received requests from data subjects seeking access to their personal data. The company was responsible for managing and processing personal data and was expected to comply with these access requests as per the GDPR requirements. However, the company did not adequately fulfill these requests, leading to a situation where data subjects were unable to access their personal data as requested.

A customer of NN Asigurări de Viață S.A. received advertising messages from the company. The customer had previously objected to receiving such messages, indicating a preference not to be contacted for advertising purposes.

The University of Iceland installed video surveillance cameras on its buildings. However, the university did not adequately inform students, staff, and visitors about the presence of these cameras. Additionally, the university failed to provide sufficient information regarding the purpose, nature, and scope of the data processing involved in the video surveillance.

A private individual, residing in an apartment building, decided to install a surveillance camera in the common areas of the building. The individual believed that the camera would enhance security for all residents. However, the individual did not seek or obtain permission from the owners' association before installing the camera.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of public spaces. The cameras were set up in such a way that they recorded individuals in these public areas. However, the individual did not provide proper information to the people being recorded about the surveillance taking place.

A customer of Vodafone España, S.A.U. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to a third party without their consent. This unauthorized third party used the duplicated SIM card to gain access to the customer's bank account and perform unauthorized transactions. The telecommunications company failed to verify the identity of the third party or obtain the customer's consent before sharing their data.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of neighboring properties. The individual intended to use the cameras for security purposes.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured footage not only of their own property but also of public spaces and a neighboring property. The individual did not inform the people being recorded about the data processing activities.

Autostrade per l'Italia spa ('ASPI') was involved in a service that provided toll refunds for delays caused by roadworks through an app called 'Free to X'. ASPI was responsible for determining the reimbursement mechanism, the type of compensation measures, and the processing related to delays due to road works. However, the documents governing the relationship between ASPI and 'Free to X' incorrectly identified ASPI as a processor instead of a data controller. 'Free to X' was tasked with implementing the service, but the notice to users did not correctly identify ASPI as the data controller, leading to a lack of transparency in the information provided to users.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data
Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: A customer of Rinascente S.p.A. had her loyalty card cancelled after an incident with a store employee. She received a new card with offensive information in her name. Additionally, the company did not specify the retention period for data used for marketing and profiling, nor did it inform customers that their email addresses were shared with Facebook-Meta for marketing purposes. Furthermore, Rinascente conducted broad profiling for e-commerce activities without performing a data protection impact assessment.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data
Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: Trygg-Hansa, an insurance company, sent emails to its customers containing web links to access their documents. A recipient discovered that by altering the web link, they could access documents of other customers without any authentication. This security flaw exposed sensitive data of approximately 650,000 customers, including health, financial, and contact information, over a period of more than two years, from October 2018 to February 2021.

WALL BOX CHARGERS S.L., a company, was sending emails to its customers. During this process, an individual was inadvertently included in the CC field of emails sent to other customers. This mistake allowed the individual to access personal data of four other customers, which was not intended.

ALBEN AIRPORT FACILITIES S.L. organized a training course and, upon its completion, sent out certificates of participation to all attendees. However, the email containing these certificates was sent to all participants in a way that disclosed each participant's personal data, including their names, surnames, and ID card numbers, to every other participant.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras recorded not only their own property but also captured footage of a neighbor's property. The neighbor became aware of the surveillance and raised concerns about privacy and the extent of the recording.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras in a residential complex. These cameras covered not only the individual's property but also common areas shared by all residents. The individual did not obtain consent from the homeowners' association or inform the residents about the presence of the cameras.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: Ermeslink di Giovanni Di Stefano installed CCTV systems near waste garbage cans on behalf of the municipality of Modica. The purpose of these installations was to combat illegal waste disposal by capturing video footage of individuals near the waste disposal areas.

Cat s.r.l. installed CCTV systems near waste garbage cans on behalf of the municipality of Modica. The purpose of these installations was to combat illegal waste disposal. The cameras collected video footage of individuals near the waste disposal areas.

Uipath SRL, a data controller, managed an academy platform where personal data of 600,000 users, including first and last names, email addresses, and employment details, were stored. This data was accessible via a URL address without proper authorization, indicating a lack of adequate technical and organizational measures to protect the personal data.

MULTIGAS ASESORES S.L., a company acting as a data controller, was involved in a situation where the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA) requested specific information from them as part of an ongoing investigation. The company was expected to provide the requested information to comply with the investigation process.

A private individual recorded a video of another person who was clearly drunk. Without obtaining consent from the person in the video, the individual uploaded the video to their Facebook profile, making it accessible to their friends and potentially a wider audience.

A homeowners' association decided to publish an enforcement notice on a public notice board located in a common area of a residential building. This notice included personal data of a property owner, who is a member of the association. The notice was accessible to anyone who passed by the notice board, including residents and visitors.

A private individual installed a video surveillance system at their property. The system was set up to monitor the premises, capturing footage of visitors and passersby. However, the individual did not provide sufficient information to those being recorded about the presence of the surveillance system, its purpose, or any other relevant details.

A private individual, who is a homeowner in a residential complex, installed CCTV cameras at his house. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of the community pool area, which is a shared space used by other residents of the complex. The intention behind installing the CCTV was to enhance security around the individual's property.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: An individual posted an image on their private Instagram account. JOLY DIGITAL, S.L.U., a company, accessed this private image and published it without obtaining consent from the individual. The individual, upon discovering the unauthorized use of their image, filed a complaint with the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA).
