A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured footage that included not only the individual's private property but also extended to cover public spaces. The individual did not provide proper information to the people who were recorded by these cameras about the data processing activities being conducted.

A private individual installed a video surveillance system in a shared garage. The system was set up to monitor the area for security purposes. However, the individual did not properly inform the residents of the garage about the installation of the surveillance system or the recording of their activities.

respondent: MÁRMOLES Y GRANITOS MEJIAS, S. L.
case_content: MÁRMOLES Y GRANITOS MEJIAS, S. L. installed video surveillance cameras on their premises. These cameras captured footage that included not only their private property but also extended to public spaces. The company did not provide adequate information to individuals about the presence and purpose of the CCTV cameras.

RING RING CLIN S.L., a company operating in Spain, was involved in an investigation conducted by the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA). During the course of this investigation, the DPA requested specific information from RING RING CLIN S.L. However, the company failed to provide the requested information to the DPA.

An organization was required to provide specific information to the Spanish Data Protection Authority (AEPD) within a designated timeframe. This request was part of the AEPD's regulatory oversight responsibilities. The organization, acting as a data controller, failed to comply with this request, which involved the transmission of certain information related to data subjects. The scenario unfolds as the organization does not meet the deadline set by the AEPD for providing the requested information.

A healthcare provider, Azienda Usl Toscana Sud Est, displayed an information poster in the emergency room. The poster showed a healthcare professional at a computer, and an emergency protocol with the personal data, including health data, of a patient was visible on the screen. The poster was displayed for a few weeks.

GYMOOGIMNASIOS S.L. implemented a reservation system for their sports facility. To use this system, data subjects were required to consent to the processing of their health-related data. This data was necessary for the reservation system and access to the sports facility.

ODRIA COSTAS INTERNACIONAL, S.L. published a picture on their website that included the residence of a data subject. The picture also showed the data subject's underage daughters. The data subject had not given consent for the publication of the children's images.
violated_articles: Article 8 - Conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services

case_content: A medical center, Camedi s.r.l., mistakenly sent invoices and appointment reminders intended for one patient (Patient B) to another patient (Patient A) who shares the same name. This led to a mix-up in personal data communication between the two patients.

ELECTRAWORKS - CEUTA, S.A., a company providing services to customers, collected personal data from its customers. However, the company did not provide sufficient information to the customers regarding how long their personal data would be retained. This lack of transparency in data retention practices led to concerns about the company's compliance with data protection regulations.

Humboldt Forum Service GmbH documented sensitive information about individual employees, including personal statements, health concerns, interest in forming a works council, and psychotherapy treatment. This information was used to assess the employees' continued employment status as 'critical' or 'very critical'.

Ew Business Machines S.p.A. installed a video surveillance system that recorded both video and audio of employees. The company's legal representative and their family could access these recordings via a smartphone. Additionally, the company used an application to continuously track the location of some employees via GPS. Furthermore, the company installed an alarm system that processed biometric data, specifically fingerprints, without demonstrating a sufficient legal basis for this processing.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data
Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data
Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: Thin Srl was running an international project aimed at improving patient care by collecting and analyzing health data. General Practitioners (GPs) were required to add an additional function to their existing management software, which was supposed to automatically anonymize patient data and transfer it to Thin Srl's database. The company assumed that the data being processed was anonymized.

FONTANORTE, S.L., a company acting as a data controller, disposed of documents containing personal data in trash containers that were accessible to the public. This action led to the exposure of personal data to unauthorized individuals.

A private individual, acting as both employer and landlord, used the bank details provided by an employee in their employment contract to collect rent payments. The employee was also a tenant of the employer. The bank details were used without obtaining the employee's consent for this specific purpose.

respondent: Azienda Tutela della Salute della Sardegna
case_content: Azienda Tutela della Salute della Sardegna, a health authority, placed a sign at the gate of a physician's practice. The sign informed the public about the physician's absence due to illness. This action involved disclosing the physician's health information to the public.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: A private individual repeatedly shared personal data of various individuals on a public Telegram channel. The data subjects did not provide consent for their personal data to be shared in this manner. The individual did not have a valid legal basis for the dissemination of this information.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: A customer of TELEFÓNICA MÓVILES ESPAÑA, S.A.U. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to a third party without their consent. This unauthorized third party used the SIM card to gain access to the customer's bank account and perform unauthorized transactions. The telecommunications company did not verify the identity of the third party nor did it obtain the customer's consent to share their data.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras in a condominium. These cameras recorded not only the private areas but also the common areas of the condominium and the public space outside. The intention was to enhance security within the premises.

Fraudulent third parties impersonated a legitimate customer and requested Vodafone España, S.A.U. to change the customer's phone number. The company complied with this request and sent a new contract to the new phone number, which led to the disclosure of the customer's personal data.

A customer of Vodafone España, S.A.U. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to an unauthorized third party. This unauthorized individual used the duplicate SIM card to gain access to the customer's bank account and perform unauthorized transactions. The customer had not given consent for their SIM card to be duplicated or for their information to be shared with any third party.

QUALITY-PROVIDER S.A., a company acting as a data controller, was involved in a situation where the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA) requested specific information from them as part of an investigation. The company was expected to comply with this request to facilitate the investigation process.

A data controller was involved in a situation where the Polish Data Protection Authority (DPA) requested specific information from them as part of an ongoing investigation. The data controller was expected to comply with this request and provide the necessary information to assist the DPA in their investigation.

A data controller is responsible for managing personal data of individuals. During an investigation, the Polish Data Protection Authority (DPA) requests specific information from the data controller to assess compliance with data protection regulations. The data controller, however, fails to provide the requested information to the DPA.

A data controller was involved in a situation where the Polish Data Protection Authority (DPA) requested specific information from them as part of an ongoing investigation. The data controller was expected to provide the necessary information to assist the DPA in their investigation process.

The Comune di Napoli, a municipality, sent an email to three former employees after their employment had ended. This email contained personal evaluation forms and a ranking list with the grades achieved by the individuals. As a result, all recipients were able to access the personal information of the other individuals.

A company, acting as a data controller, was involved in a situation where the Polish Data Protection Authority (DPA) requested specific information from the company as part of an ongoing investigation. The company was expected to comply with this request and provide the necessary information to the DPA.

Citynews S.p.A., a publishing company, published an article in their newspaper about the arrest of an individual. The article included sensitive health data about the individual. The publication was made without obtaining a valid legal basis or consent from the individual whose data was disclosed.

La Gazzetta di Parma S.r.l., a media publisher, published photographs in its newspaper of an individual accused of murder. The photos depicted the individual in handcuffs, and the images were not sufficiently blurred, allowing the individual to be identified.

A property manager installed a video surveillance camera in the public entrance area of an apartment building. The camera was positioned to monitor the entrance, capturing footage of residents and visitors as they entered and exited the building. The purpose of the surveillance was to enhance security in the building. However, the property manager did not obtain the necessary legal basis or consent from the individuals being recorded.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: A company controller shared a photo in a company WhatsApp group. The photo depicted an individual who was bleeding heavily after a physical attack. The individual did not give consent for the photo to be shared in the group.

A company was responsible for managing the personal data of 50,000 individuals. However, the company did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures to protect this data. Specifically, there were insufficient access controls and authentication processes for IT system administrators. Additionally, the company did not establish a proper retention period for the personal data it held.

An individual wrote reviews on the internet using another person's photo and name without obtaining their consent. The affected individual filed a complaint with the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA) regarding this unauthorized use of their personal information.

respondent: SERVICIOS E INTERVENCIONES EN EDIFICACION DEL MEDITERRÁNEO, S.L.
case_content: An individual discovered that a company, SERVICIOS E INTERVENCIONES EN EDIFICACION DEL MEDITERRÁNEO, S.L., had published a picture of them without obtaining their permission. The individual was concerned about their privacy and the unauthorized use of their image.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras recorded not only their own property but also captured footage of a neighbor's property. The neighbor became aware of the surveillance and raised concerns about their privacy being infringed upon.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras that recorded the public space. The cameras captured video footage of individuals in the public area. The purpose of the surveillance was not clearly defined, and there was no indication that consent was obtained from the individuals being recorded.

respondent: ING Bank NV Amsterdam Sucursala București
case_content: ING Bank NV Amsterdam Sucursala București experienced a data breach where a PDF file containing customer data was transmitted without authorization via WhatsApp. This incident led to the unauthorized disclosure of numerous customer data.

A guard at a detention center took pictures from the facility's video surveillance system. These pictures showed a female visitor to the correctional facility. The guard then forwarded these pictures to colleagues via WhatsApp.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: The Irish Department of Health obtained information from the Health Service Executive about services that claimants and their families had received. They were asked broad questions that led to the disclosure of sensitive private information. The data was collected to determine whether a settlement could be pursued with the plaintiff.

NANDIVALE, S.L. hosted a party at its premises and took photographs during the event. These images included minors and were subsequently uploaded to social media platforms. The mother of one of the children noticed the images online and realized that she had not been asked for consent for the publication of her child's image.
violated_articles: Article 8 - Conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services

case_content: MADRID TOURISTIC CAPITAL, S.L. installed video surveillance cameras at its premises to monitor security. However, the company did not provide adequate information to individuals, such as visitors and employees, about the presence of these cameras and the processing of their personal data. This lack of transparency led to concerns about the privacy of individuals being recorded without proper notification.

A customer of Digi Spain Telecom, S.L.U. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to a third party without their knowledge or consent. This unauthorized third party used the duplicate SIM card to gain access to the customer's bank account, leading to potential financial harm. The telecom company did not verify the identity of the third party nor did it obtain the customer's consent before sharing their data.

A company experienced a ransomware attack on its systems, leading to the loss of personal data. The company had not implemented sufficient technical and organizational measures to safeguard the personal data, which allowed the attack to occur. Additionally, the company did not notify the relevant authorities or the affected data subjects about the incident in a timely manner.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras recorded not only their own property but also the neighboring property. The neighbor became aware of the surveillance and raised concerns about privacy and the extent of the recording.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of public spaces. The cameras were set up to monitor areas beyond the individual's private property, thereby recording individuals in public spaces. Additionally, the individual did not provide adequate information to those being recorded about the presence and purpose of the video surveillance.

Birou Gas, S.L., a company, was involved in an investigation conducted by the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA). During this investigation, the DPA requested specific information from Birou Gas, S.L. However, the company failed to provide the requested information to the DPA.

respondent: CONCENTRA CENTRAL DE COMPRAS Y SERVICIOS S.L.
case_content: CONCENTRA CENTRAL DE COMPRAS Y SERVICIOS S.L. is a company that processes personal data of its customers. During its operations, the company is required to inform its customers about their rights, including the right of withdrawal. However, the company failed to properly and explicitly inform the customers about this right.

An individual received a receipt from a service provider. However, the receipt contained personal data belonging to another customer instead of their own. This incident raised concerns about the handling and protection of personal data by the service provider.

CBHNOS S.L. installed video surveillance cameras for security monitoring purposes. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of a public road, thereby recording individuals who were passing by. The company did not obtain consent from these individuals for capturing their images.

LISMARTSA, S.L., acting as a data controller, sent an email that included personal data of 74 individuals to multiple recipients. The email was distributed without ensuring that the personal data was minimized or that the recipients were authorized to receive such information.

An individual requested personal data from CaixaBank, S.A. However, instead of receiving their own personal data, they received information pertaining to a third party. This incident raised concerns about the adequacy of CaixaBank's technical and organizational measures to protect personal data.

Creditinfo Lánstraust hf., a data controller, collected and registered information on individuals' loan defaults. This included registering unpaid small loans that were below the required minimum amount for registration. The information was then shared with various financial institutions for the purpose of credit assessment.

respondent: Università degli studi di Cassino e del Lazio Meridionale
case_content: A professor at Università degli studi di Cassino e del Lazio Meridionale discovered that their personal data, specifically related to criminal proceedings, had been disclosed to third parties by the university. The professor had not given consent for this disclosure, and the university did not have a valid legal basis for processing and sharing this information.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: A customer of Santander Consumer Bank S.p.a. requested access to their personal data held by the bank. The bank was responsible for providing the requested information to the customer in a timely and complete manner, as per the customer's rights under data protection regulations.

A private individual installed a video surveillance system at their property to enhance security. The system captured video footage of individuals, including visitors and passersby, who came into the vicinity of the property. However, the property owner did not provide sufficient information to these individuals about the video surveillance system, such as its purpose, the data being collected, or their rights regarding the data.

eCommerce 2020 ApS, a company involved in eCommerce, submitted information about individuals' loan defaults to a registration entity. This included data on unpaid small loans, even when these loans were below the required minimum amount for registration. The company aimed to register these defaults as part of their business operations.

CARROZADOS TECAI, S.L. installed a video surveillance system to monitor its premises. However, the company did not provide all the required information on the information sign that accompanies the video surveillance system. This lack of information could potentially affect the individuals being recorded by the system, as they may not be fully aware of the surveillance or the details regarding the processing of their personal data.

Almennri innheimtu ehf, a company acting as a controller, submitted information regarding loan defaults to a registration entity. This information included details of unpaid small loans, even when these loans were below the required minimum amount for registration. The company pursued this action with the intent of profit, affecting a large number of individuals.

A data subject was added to a WhatsGroup by LISMARTSA, S.L. without their consent. The data subject did not agree to be part of this group communication, which involved sharing their contact information with other group members.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of public spaces. The cameras were set up to monitor the area, but they also recorded individuals who were passing by or present in the public space. The individual did not provide proper information to the people being recorded about the data processing activities being conducted through the surveillance system.

An individual, referred to as the data subject, requested the erasure of their personal data from the records of KUGELCHEN PROPIERTIES, S.L., a company acting as a data controller. Despite this request, the company continued to process the individual's personal data.

An individual contacted RCL CRUISES LTD to request information about a cruise ship via email. In response, the individual received an email from RCL CRUISES LTD that mistakenly included personal data of another individual.

A customer of VODAFONE SERVICIOS, S.L.U. experienced a breach of their personal data when the company issued a duplicate SIM card to a third party without verifying the identity of the requester or obtaining the customer's consent. This unauthorized third party used the SIM card to access the customer's bank account and perform unauthorized transactions.
Heilsuveru, a data controller, experienced a data breach where two unauthorized persons managed to view personal data. The breach was reported to the Data Protection Authority (DPA).

respondent: EXPLOTACIONES HOSTELERAS Y DE OCIO ALBACETEÑAS, S.L.
case_content: EXPLOTACIONES HOSTELERAS Y DE OCIO ALBACETEÑAS, S.L. installed video surveillance cameras on their premises. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of the public street, thereby recording individuals who were not within the premises of the business. The intention behind the installation of these cameras was to enhance security measures for the business.

CDON AB, a company based in Sweden, utilized Google Analytics to gather visitor statistics from its website. The data collected was transferred to the United States for processing. CDON AB relied on the EU standard contractual clauses to legitimize this data transfer, as there was no EU Commission adequacy decision for the USA. The Austrian organization None of your Business (NOYB) filed a complaint against CDON AB, arguing that the data transfer was unlawful in light of the Schrems II judgment.

Tele2 Sverige Aktiebolag, a Swedish company, used Google Analytics to collect visitor statistics from its website. The data collected was transferred to the United States using EU standard contractual clauses, as there was no adequacy decision by the EU Commission for the USA. The Austrian organization None of your Business (NOYB) filed a complaint against Tele2, arguing that the data transfer was unlawful in light of the Schrems II judgment.

A website operator collected personal data from various sources on the internet using web scraping techniques. This data was then published on the website www.trovanumeri.com. The individuals whose data was collected were not informed about this collection, nor were they given the opportunity to request the deletion of their data. Additionally, the website did not provide any contact information for individuals to reach out regarding their data.
violated_articles: Article 12 - Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject
Article 17 - Right to erasure ('right to be forgotten')

case_content: PUNTO ROJO LIBROS, S.L., a company, was required to comply with an order issued by the Spanish Data Protection Agency (DPA). The order was related to the company's handling of personal data. However, the company failed to comply with the order, leading to further action by the DPA.

Sjúkratryggingar Íslands, a health insurance company, was involved in the development of a new system. During this process, they used real health data of individuals without implementing adequate security measures, such as multi-factor authentication, to protect this sensitive information. This situation affected a large number of individuals.

Grizzaffi Management Srl, a company, engaged in sending marketing messages to individuals. These individuals, who are consumers, had previously exercised their right to object to receiving such communications. Despite this objection, the company continued to send marketing messages to them.

Benetton Group S.r.l. stored a large amount of customer data indefinitely without a clear retention policy. Additionally, the administrative database containing employee data from stores in seven countries was accessible using a single password, which posed a security risk. This situation involved a large number of individuals whose personal data was not adequately protected.

A store owner installed CCTV cameras within their premises to monitor the area for security purposes. The cameras captured video footage of customers and visitors who entered the store. However, the store owner did not provide adequate information to these individuals about the CCTV surveillance, such as the purpose of the surveillance, the identity of the data controller, or any other relevant details as required by GDPR.

A municipality, acting as a data controller, experienced a ransomware attack. The attackers exploited a vulnerability in the municipality's IT system. This incident occurred because the municipality had not implemented adequate technical and organizational measures to protect the personal data of its residents.

Bonnier News AB, a media company, collects customer data through various means such as tracking their surfing behavior and recording purchases made from different subsidiaries. The company uses this data to create profiles for marketing purposes. Bonnier News AB relies on a predominant interest as the legal basis for processing this data, assuming that customers visiting their websites would expect such data collection.

respondent: Azienda socio sanitaria locale n. 3 di Nuoro
case_content: An individual submitted a medication request to Azienda socio sanitaria locale n. 3 di Nuoro. In the process, the health authority published the individual's personal data, including their date of birth, residence, and health-related data, on the internet.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: A municipality, Comune di Cogollo del Cengio, published a document on its website that contained personal health data of a former employee. The document was accessible to the public, and the former employee was not informed or asked for consent regarding the publication of their personal health data.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

respondent: Ufficio Scolastico Regionale per la Puglia, Ufficio VI - Ambito Territoriale di Lecce
case_content: A school board in Italy, Ufficio Scolastico Regionale per la Puglia, Ufficio VI - Ambito Territoriale di Lecce, published a document on its website. This document contained personal health data of a teacher. The publication was made without obtaining the necessary consent or legal basis for sharing such sensitive information.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: An employee of La Risorsa Umana.it s.r.l. was using their company email account for work-related communications. The employer, La Risorsa Umana.it s.r.l., regularly checked the employee's email account without informing the employee. The employee was unaware of this monitoring activity.

TRC TRUCKS 2020, S.L., a company operating in Spain, was issued an order by the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA) to comply with certain data protection regulations. The company failed to adhere to this order, leading to further scrutiny by the DPA.

A customer of NOVA TELECOMMUNICATIONS & MEDIA ΜΟΝΟΠΡΟΣΩΠΗ Α.Ε. received promotional emails multiple times despite having objected to receiving such communications. Additionally, the customer was not provided access to their personal data upon request.

Piraeus Bank, in its operations, processed personal data of its customers. The bank did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure that only necessary data was processed for specific purposes. Additionally, the bank did not properly address a customer's request for access to their personal data.

Farmacia Ardealul SRL, a data controller, experienced a data breach due to the unauthorized installation of malware on its website. This malware led to the unauthorized processing of customer data, specifically bank data. The controller had not implemented appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect the personal data of its customers.

Sociedad Vascongada de Publicaciones, S.A. published a video on its news site. The video included an Excel spreadsheet containing personal data, specifically the first and last names of 56 women identified as victims of gender-based violence. The publication aimed to exercise freedom of information.

Corporación de Medios de Extremadura, a news publisher, published a video on its news site. This video included an Excel spreadsheet that contained the first and last names of 56 women. These women were identified as victims of gender-based violence. The publication of this information was intended for news reporting purposes.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of a neighboring property. The intention behind installing the cameras was to enhance security. However, the cameras inadvertently recorded activities occurring on the neighboring property, leading to concerns about privacy and data protection.

The city of Rome provided data of women who had abortions to Ama S.p.a., which is responsible for the administration of certain cemeteries in Rome. Ama then included this data on boards placed on the graves of the fetuses.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: Roma Capitale, the city administration, provided personal data of women who had undergone abortions to a funeral company. This data was used by the company to place information on boards on the graves of the fetuses. The data shared included sensitive personal information about the women.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: A customer applied for financing with Volkswagen Leasing. During the process, the customer's application was rejected due to an assessment of their creditworthiness. The customer requested information from Volkswagen Leasing regarding the creditworthiness assessment that led to the rejection of their financing application. However, Volkswagen Leasing did not provide the requested information to the customer.

A data controller was responsible for processing special categories of personal data belonging to numerous individuals. The controller failed to adhere to the necessary GDPR regulations, which require explicit consent and proper handling of such sensitive data. The data was processed without obtaining the necessary authorization from the data subjects, and the purpose of processing was not clearly defined or communicated.

Company A collected personal data from its customers to improve its services. The data was shared with third-party service providers without obtaining explicit consent from the customers. The company assumed that the data sharing was covered under its general terms and conditions, which the customers had agreed to when signing up for the service. However, the terms did not clearly specify the extent of data sharing with third parties. Customers were not informed about the specific third parties involved or the exact nature of the data being shared. The company also failed to implement adequate security measures to protect the data during transmission and storage.

A data controller installed a surveillance camera that captured audio recordings. The controller accessed these audio recordings without obtaining the necessary consent from the individuals being recorded. The recordings were used for purposes not explicitly consented to by the data subjects.

An employee of a municipality copied a document containing personal data from a company computer onto an unauthorized data carrier. This action was not authorized by the municipality and involved the transfer of personal data to a medium that was not approved for such use.

A physician received a negative online review about their practice. In response to this review, the physician disclosed personal data of the patient who wrote the review. The disclosure was made publicly, allowing anyone who read the response to access the patient's personal information.

A company decided to enhance customer engagement by introducing a loyalty card program. To participate, customers were required to provide personal data. The company collected this data and issued loyalty cards to customers. However, the company did not obtain explicit consent from the customers for processing their personal data for this purpose.

The Belgian Order of Pharmacists conducted disciplinary proceedings against a pharmacist. During these proceedings, they collected personal data from the pharmacist's personnel file. The data included information on disciplinary actions, which was stored without distinguishing the severity of the actions and for the entire duration of the pharmacist's career. Additionally, the purposes for storing this data were not adequately defined.

A customer of Vodafone Romania SA requested information regarding their personal data processing. Vodafone Romania SA, as the data controller, was responsible for providing the necessary information to the customer in compliance with GDPR requirements. However, the company did not adequately fulfill this obligation, leading to a situation where the customer's right to information was not sufficiently respected.

A customer of Vodafone España, S.A.U. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to an unauthorized third party. This unauthorized access allowed the third party to gain entry to the customer's bank account and perform transactions without the customer's consent. The company did not verify the identity of the third party nor did it obtain the customer's consent to share their data.

An organization, acting as a data controller, was involved in an investigation conducted by the Data Protection Authority (DPA). During this investigation, the DPA requested specific information from the organization to assess compliance with data protection regulations. The organization failed to provide the requested information to the DPA, which was necessary for the investigation process.

Company A, acting as a data controller, was required to comply with specific orders issued by the Data Protection Authority (DPA) regarding the handling of personal data of its customers. Despite receiving these orders, Company A failed to implement the necessary measures to align its data processing activities with the requirements set by the DPA. The orders were intended to ensure that Company A's data processing practices were in compliance with the GDPR, particularly concerning the protection of personal data and the rights of data subjects.

GRUPO TRANSAHER, SL, a company, installed video surveillance cameras in areas designated for employee breaks. These cameras were set up to monitor the activities of employees during their break times. The employees were not informed about the installation of these cameras, nor was their consent obtained for such monitoring. The company used the footage for monitoring purposes without considering the privacy implications or obtaining necessary authorizations.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras recorded not only their own property but also captured footage of a neighbor's property. The neighbor became aware of the surveillance and raised concerns about privacy and the extent of the recording.

A customer of Digi Spain Telecom, S.L.U. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to an unauthorized third party. This unauthorized individual used the SIM card to gain access to the customer's bank account and perform unauthorized transactions. The telecom company did not verify the identity of the third party nor did it obtain the customer's consent to share their data.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured footage of the general public, including bystanders, without obtaining proper authorization or consent. The purpose of the surveillance was to monitor the property.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: Employees of Artima S.A. accessed the company's video surveillance system and recorded the monitor displaying the recorded images using their cell phones. One of the employees then shared these images with a third person, who subsequently posted them on Facebook.

BRD-Groupe Société Générale S.A., a bank, was involved in a situation where personal data of a bank client and other individuals were disclosed to unauthorized third parties. The bank had reported this data breach to the Romanian Data Protection Authority (DPA).

Sorgenia S.p.a., a company, engaged in telemarketing activities to promote its services. The company used a telemarketing chain to reach out to potential customers. However, several individuals, who were contacted, had not given their consent to receive such marketing communications. Additionally, when some of these individuals requested information or actions regarding their data, the company did not respond in a timely manner.

Green Network S.p.A., a telemarketing company, engaged in telemarketing activities targeting potential customers. The company collected and used contact information of these individuals to promote their services. However, the company did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure that they were informed about all operations in the telemarketing chain, including whether proper consent was obtained from the data subjects.

KG COM, a company operating several websites offering fortune-telling consultations via chat or telephone, systematically recorded conversations with customers and potential customers. The company stored banking information of its customers for conducting transactions, combating fraud, and facilitating further purchases. Additionally, KG COM processed data on the health status and sexual orientation of its customers without obtaining explicit consent. The company also failed to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect personal data, such as providing robust passwords for user accounts. Furthermore, KG COM did not report a data leak to the relevant authority.

A credit agency stored incorrect personal data, including 27 false addresses and 13 false dates of birth, of an individual for over two years. The data was not corrected until the individual requested information. The agency provided the information late due to an internal error.

A job center employee accessed data in the civil register for private research purposes. The employee used their position to obtain information from the civil register, which contains personal data of individuals. This access was not related to their professional duties and was conducted without the consent of the individuals whose data was accessed.

A job center employee accessed the job center database systems to retrieve personal data of individuals for private research purposes. The employee used their access privileges to gather information not related to their professional duties, without obtaining proper authorization or consent from the data subjects.

A private individual took pictures of numerous young women in public spaces. The individual processed these photographs, which are considered personal data, without obtaining effective consent from the subjects.

A company maintained a customer database accessible via the Internet. The database contained thousands of customer entries. The company relied on a long-form web address as the sole access protection measure, assuming that the web address would not become known to unauthorized parties. No additional security measures, such as password protection, were implemented.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras that recorded the public space. The cameras captured video footage of individuals in the public area. The purpose of the surveillance was not explicitly stated, and there was no indication that consent was obtained from the individuals being recorded.

A data controller was issued an order by the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA) to take specific actions regarding data processing activities. The controller failed to comply with this order within the stipulated time frame. The situation arose from the DPA's investigation into the controller's data processing practices, which led to the issuance of the order.

A customer of DIGI SPAIN TELECOM, S.L. experienced a breach of their personal information when the company issued a duplicate SIM card to an unauthorized third party. This unauthorized individual was able to use the SIM card to access the customer's bank account and perform transactions without the customer's consent.

A customer of DIGI SPAIN TELECOM, S.L. experienced a breach of their personal data when the company issued a duplicate SIM card to an unauthorized third party. This third party, without the customer's consent, used the SIM card to access the customer's bank account and perform unauthorized transactions.

A customer of DIGI SPAIN TELECOM, S.L. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to an unauthorized third party. This unauthorized access allowed the third party to gain entry to the customer's bank account and perform transactions without the customer's consent. The telecom company did not verify the identity of the third party nor did it obtain the customer's consent to share their data.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured footage not only of their own property but also of public spaces and a neighboring property. The cameras were intended for surveillance purposes.

LEADDESK, S.L, a company operating as a data controller, was involved in an investigation conducted by the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA). During this investigation, the DPA requested specific information from LEADDESK, S.L to assess compliance with data protection regulations. However, LEADDESK, S.L failed to provide the requested information to the DPA.

A data controller is responsible for managing personal data of individuals. In this scenario, the controller is required to provide data subjects with sufficient information to exercise their right to object to the processing of their personal data. However, the controller fails to provide this necessary information, which is crucial for the data subjects to understand and exercise their rights under the GDPR.

Spotify, a music streaming provider, was involved in a situation where it did not adequately inform its users about the origin of their data or any international transfers involving their data. Additionally, Spotify provided information that was difficult to understand, such as technical processes, only in English, rather than in the data subjects' native languages. This led to complaints and a lawsuit by an Austrian organization.

FUSIONA SOLUCIONES ENERGÉTICAS, S.A. submitted data from an individual to a credit information system due to an alleged debt. However, the debt had been cancelled, which was confirmed by a court ruling.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: A customer of Digi Spain Telecom, S.L.U. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to an unauthorized third party. This unauthorized access allowed the third party to gain access to the customer's bank account and perform transactions without the customer's consent. The telecom company did not verify the identity of the third party nor did it obtain the customer's consent before sharing the SIM card information.

A customer of Digi Spain Telecom, S.L.U. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to an unauthorized third party. This unauthorized individual used the SIM card to gain access to the customer's bank account and perform unauthorized transactions. The telecom company had failed to verify the identity of the third party or obtain the customer's consent before sharing their data.

respondent: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE ESPAÑA LTD. Y CIA SRC
case_content: A person ordered a package to be delivered to their home. However, the package was delivered to a store without the person's consent, resulting in the disclosure of their postal address and telephone number to the store.

TIM S.p.A., a telecommunications provider, engaged in telemarketing activities by contacting individuals for marketing purposes. These individuals were either registered on opt-out lists or had not given their consent for their data to be processed for marketing purposes. Additionally, TIM S.p.A. did not adequately respond to inquiries from data subjects and failed to comply with its information obligations. Furthermore, the company did not properly investigate and address a data breach.

A vehicle owner installs a dashcam in their car to record video footage while driving. The dashcam captures video of pedestrians and other drivers on public roads. The footage is stored and occasionally shared with law enforcement or posted online without obtaining consent from the individuals recorded.

H&M Hennes & Mauritz s.r.l. installed numerous video surveillance systems in its Italian stores. The purpose of these systems was to prevent theft and ensure the safety of employees. Each store was equipped with at least three cameras that operated 24/7, covering both public and employee areas.

A sports photographer captured over 16,000 photos of minors participating in a swimming competition. These photos were then published on the company's freely accessible website. The parents of the minors were not involved in the decision-making process regarding the capturing and publication of these images.
violated_articles: Article 8 - Conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services

case_content: During the Corona pandemic, a restaurant operator required visitors to fill out forms with their personal data for the purpose of contact tracing, as mandated by law. The data collected was intended to be used solely for health-related contact tracing to prevent the spread of the virus.

During the Covid-19 pandemic, a store required customers to provide their contact information as a condition for accessing the premises. An employee of the store used this contact information to reach out to a customer privately, outside the context of the store's operations.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: A website operator manages a website that collects personal data from its users. The operator is responsible for ensuring that the privacy policy on the website is clear and complies with legal requirements. However, the privacy policy provided does not meet the standards set by the GDPR, specifically lacking necessary information as required by Article 13. Users visiting the website are not adequately informed about how their personal data will be used, stored, or shared.

A data subject provided their personal data to ALPA 57 PRODUCCIONES. Subsequently, ALPA 57 PRODUCCIONES transmitted this data to third parties for marketing purposes. The data subject did not authorize this transmission, leading to a complaint being filed.

respondent: RCI BANQUE, S.A. SUCURSAL EN ESPAÑA
case_content: A customer of RCI BANQUE, S.A. SUCURSAL EN ESPAÑA requested the deletion of her personal data from the company's databases. Despite this request, she continued to receive text messages from the company.

respondent: PELAYO, MUTUA DE SEGUROS Y REASEGUROS A PRIMA FIJA
case_content: An individual provided their personal data to PELAYO, MUTUA DE SEGUROS Y REASEGUROS A PRIMA FIJA, a company acting as a data controller. Due to an internal error, the company disclosed the individual's personal data to unauthorized third parties. The individual became aware of this unauthorized disclosure and was concerned about the potential misuse of their personal data.

A data subject requested the deletion of their personal data from QUALITY-PROVIDER S.A.'s records. Despite this request, the company continued to use the data subject's information for marketing purposes. The data subject, feeling their privacy was violated, decided to file a complaint with the Spanish Data Protection Authority.

VODAFONE ONO, S.A.U. conducted a credit check on an individual. The individual was not a customer of VODAFONE ONO, S.A.U., nor did they have any other affiliation with the company. The company processed the individual's personal data to perform this credit check.

In 2022, a sports betting operator offered players the option to have their winnings paid out via their Visa card. To facilitate this, the operator collected copies of players' bank cards, intending to comply with the national Money Laundering Act. However, the operator did not adequately inform players about the processing of their personal data, including the legal basis, purpose of collection, and retention period. Additionally, the operator failed to implement sufficient technical and organizational measures to protect the personal data, resulting in unauthorized access to some of the bank card copies.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras inadvertently recorded footage of a neighboring property, capturing video data of the neighbor without their consent. The individual intended to use the cameras for security purposes.

S.C. Apollo Salon S.R.L., a company operating in Romania, was involved in a situation where the Romanian Data Protection Authority (DPA) requested specific information from the company as part of an ongoing investigation. The company was expected to provide the requested information to assist the DPA in its investigation process.

A customer applied for a credit card at Deutsche Kreditbank. Despite having a good credit history and high income, the application was rejected through an automated decision-making process. The customer requested an explanation for the rejection and the basis of the automated decision, but the bank refused to provide this information, making it difficult for the customer to appeal the decision.

WILLOUGHBY COLLEGE, S.A. was involved in an investigation conducted by the Spanish Data Protection Agency (DPA). During this investigation, the DPA requested specific information from WILLOUGHBY COLLEGE, S.A. However, the college failed to provide the requested information to the DPA.
violated_articles: Article 31 - Cooperation with the supervisory authority

case_content: NORDETIA CLINICS IBERIA, S.L., a healthcare provider, was involved in a situation where the Spanish Data Protection Agency (DPA) requested specific information from them as part of an investigation. The clinic was expected to comply with this request by providing the necessary information to the DPA.

A private individual decided to publish a picture and the address of another person on a website. The individual did not seek or obtain consent from the person whose picture and address were being shared. The information was made available to the public through the website.

A private individual installed a video surveillance camera at their property. The camera's coverage extended beyond the individual's property, capturing footage of public spaces and a neighbor's property. The individual did not inform the people being recorded about the data processing activities.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: A private individual, acting as a data controller, was issued an order by the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA) to comply with certain data protection regulations. Despite receiving this order, the individual failed to take the necessary actions to comply with the DPA's directive.
A company, Global Baby Brand SRL, sends commercial SMS messages to a consumer. The consumer did not provide consent for their telephone number to be used for marketing purposes.

AUTOMOBILE BAVARIA SRL, a data controller, experienced a data breach where unknown parties managed to unauthorizedly disclose personal data of 290 customers on the controller's website. The disclosed data included information such as names, telephone numbers, and residences.

NN Asigurări de Viață S.A., an insurance company, made technical changes to its systems. These changes inadvertently allowed some website visitors to access personal data of other individuals, including names, ID card numbers, and email addresses.

respondent: NN Pensii Societate de Administrare a unui Fond de Pensii Administrat Privat S.A.
case_content: NN Pensii Societate de Administrare a unui Fond de Pensii Administrat Privat S.A., an insurance company, made technical changes to its systems. These changes inadvertently allowed some website visitors to access personal data of other individuals, including names, ID card numbers, and email addresses. This incident involved unauthorized access to the personal data of two individuals.

An individual requested information from Libra Internet Bank SA regarding their personal data. The bank failed to fully comply with this request. Additionally, the bank did not inform the individual about the possibility of filing a complaint with the Data Protection Authority (DPA). The bank also could not demonstrate that it facilitated the exercise of the individual's data subject rights.

Meta Platforms Ireland Limited, a data controller, was transferring personal data of EU citizens to entities in the U.S. The transfers were based on Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs) and additional safeguards implemented by Meta. However, following the Schrems II ruling by the CJEU, it was determined that U.S. law does not provide a level of protection for personal data equivalent to EU law. Despite this, Meta continued its data transfers relying on the SCCs and its own safeguards.

A business entity, acting as a controller, sent unsolicited commercial messages to consumers. The privacy policy provided by the controller did not meet the transparency requirements expected under data protection regulations. Additionally, when consumers requested information regarding their data, the controller failed to comply with these requests.

A data controller was responsible for managing personal data of individuals. However, the controller failed to provide the necessary information to the data subjects regarding the processing of their personal data. Additionally, the data protection policy implemented by the controller did not fulfill the transparency requirements as mandated by the GDPR. This lack of transparency and failure to inform the data subjects led to a situation where individuals were unaware of how their personal data was being used.

A data controller sent an email to multiple recipients. In doing so, the controller inadvertently disclosed a personal email address of an individual to all recipients of the email. The email was intended for communication purposes, but the personal email address was not meant to be shared with all recipients.

An unauthorized third party gained access to an individual's account without their knowledge or consent. The account contained personal information that was accessed by the third party. The account holder was unaware of this breach until it was discovered through other means.

Clearview AI, a company specializing in facial recognition technology, collected personal data from individuals without obtaining their consent. The company used this data to enhance its facial recognition database and services. Despite being aware of data protection laws, Clearview AI did not take adequate measures to ensure compliance with these regulations.

A data controller sent an email to multiple recipients. In doing so, the controller inadvertently disclosed a personal email address of an individual to all recipients of the email. The email was intended for communication purposes, but the personal email address was not meant to be shared with all recipients.

Company A, a data controller, was responsible for processing personal data of its customers. Due to a security lapse, an unauthorized third party gained access to this personal data. The data breach occurred because of inadequate security measures in place to protect the data. The customers were not aware of this unauthorized access, and their personal data was exposed without their consent.

A data controller, responsible for managing personal data, disclosed personal data of an individual to a third party without obtaining the necessary consent or authorization from the data subject. The disclosure was not aligned with any lawful basis for processing under the GDPR.

A company, acting as a data controller, was responsible for managing personal data of individuals. However, it failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure the security of this data. This lack of proper safeguards potentially exposed the personal data to unauthorized access or breaches.

A data controller, responsible for managing personal data, disclosed the personal data of an individual without obtaining the necessary consent or authorization. The data was shared with an unknown recipient, and the purpose of this disclosure was not aligned with the principles of data protection.

A trucking company, acting as a data controller, disclosed personal data of a former employee to third parties. The disclosure was made without obtaining a valid legal basis or consent from the former employee. The personal data shared included information that was not necessary for any legitimate purpose related to the company's operations.

Bulgarian Posts EAD, a data controller, experienced a hacking attack where attackers accessed their databases. The organization had not implemented adequate technical and organizational measures to protect the personal data stored in these databases.

A political party added personal data of several individuals to voter lists. These individuals had not given their consent for their personal data to be used in this manner. The individuals discovered their data was being used without their permission and filed a complaint with the Bulgarian Data Protection Authority (DPA).

Razmataz Live s.r.l. contracted a processor to carry out marketing campaigns on its behalf. The processor was responsible for executing these campaigns in a manner that complied with privacy regulations. However, Razmataz did not perform adequate checks to ensure that the processor was handling personal data in a compliant manner.

The municipality of Bolzano delegated the management of electronic health records to Informatica Alto Adige Spa. Due to a deficiency in the system, unauthorized access to the health data of several patients occurred.

The Bolzano municipality delegated the management of electronic health records to a processor. A data breach occurred due to unauthorized access to the health records of several patients. This breach was caused by a deficiency in the electronic health record service managed by the processor.

respondent: Employees of ESTUDIO INMOBILIARIO SAN ISIDRO, S.L.U.
case_content: An individual was at home when employees from ESTUDIO INMOBILIARIO SAN ISIDRO, S.L.U. visited their residence. The employees were there to advertise their rental services. The individual had not given consent for such a visit or for their home address to be used for this purpose.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured footage not only of their own property but also of public spaces and a neighboring property. The individual intended to use the cameras for security purposes.

Several individuals had loan agreements with a credit institution. Without obtaining consent from these individuals, the credit institution transferred claims from their loan agreements to a new bank account. This action led to complaints being filed by the individuals with the Data Protection Authority (DPA).

I&S Limited Kft, a spa operator, installed video surveillance cameras on its premises to monitor guests and employees continuously. The company also processed customer data for marketing purposes. However, the company did not have a valid legal basis for the extensive video surveillance and failed to properly inform the data subjects about the processing of their personal data.
A dentist installed several surveillance cameras in their practice to protect property and individuals. These cameras permanently recorded both employees and patients.

A political party experienced a data protection breach where six Excel files containing personal data of approximately 2,000 party members were inadvertently made accessible on the Internet. The files were not adequately protected by technical and organizational measures, leading to unauthorized access by the public.

An intern at Consorzio Concessioni Reti Gas S.c.a.r.l. completed their internship, but the company did not deactivate the intern's business email account. This account remained active, allowing potential access to personal and business communications. Additionally, the company was unable to demonstrate that it had provided the necessary information to the intern regarding the processing of their personal data, as required by GDPR.

respondent: Chairman of ASSOCIACIO DE CAÇADORS D'ALZIRA
case_content: A member of the ASSOCIACIO DE CAÇADORS D'ALZIRA wrote a letter. The chairman of the association shared this letter in a WhatsApp group consisting of 195 members without obtaining consent from the member who wrote the letter.

NAGA Markets Europe Ltd, a financial services company, experienced a data breach where an unknown individual accessed their database. This database contained the personal data of approximately 342,000 customers. The breach occurred due to the company's failure to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to safeguard the personal data.

Epic Ltd, a telecommunications company, contacted 332 individuals who were previously their customers. These individuals received unsolicited calls from Epic Ltd, despite no longer being customers. The company did not have a valid legal basis for making these calls, as they had not obtained the necessary consent from the individuals. Additionally, Epic Ltd failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure that their data processing activities complied with the GDPR.

A newspaper named 'Πολίτης' published an article that included the names and pictures of two police officers. The publication was made available to the general public, allowing anyone to access the personal information of these officers.
violated_articles: Article 10 - Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences

case_content: A debt collection agency processed a large amount of personal data from debtors without proper authorization. The agency's privacy policy lacked sufficient information about data processing and the legal basis for refunding overpaid funds. Additionally, the agency did not have a data processing agreement with a processor monitoring consumer bankruptcies, putting many individuals' data at risk. The agency also failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to protect personal data, leading to insecure processing and unauthorized data filtering. These issues persisted over several years.

A coin dealer collects data from new or prospective customers for customer relationship management purposes. However, the privacy policy provided to these customers lacks sufficient information about how their data will be processed. As a result, customers are unable to give informed consent for the data processing activities.

An individual discovered that their personal data was published on a website operated by a data controller. The individual, seeking to understand the extent of the data processing, sent a request for access to their personal data to the controller. However, the controller did not respond to this request. Additionally, the controller did not engage properly with the data protection authority during the subsequent investigation.
A patient requested her physician to send all her medical records following the death of her unborn child. The physician did not comply with this request.

A beauty salon installed video cameras throughout its premises, which continuously recorded both customers and employees. The salon also used the recorded data for marketing purposes. However, the salon did not inform the customers or employees about the video surveillance or the use of their data for marketing, nor did it obtain the necessary permissions to do so.

A hotel installed video surveillance cameras in the dining room and whirlpool area to protect individuals and property. These cameras recorded guests continuously. The hotel did not provide sufficient information to the guests about the video surveillance.

In a residential community, members of the homeowners' association accessed video surveillance footage from the community's security system. They then shared this footage with others via a WhatsApp group. This action led to a complaint being filed by one of the homeowners, who was concerned about the unauthorized distribution of the video footage.

An individual participated in a training event organized by FUNDACIÓ PRIVADA UNIVERSITARIA EADA. During the event, pictures were taken that included the individual. Later, the educational institution used these pictures for promotional purposes. The individual did not provide consent for their image to be used in this manner.

A company, acting as a data controller, experienced a data breach that led to the loss of personal data. The company had not implemented adequate technical and organizational measures to protect the personal data. Additionally, the company did not conduct necessary risk analyses and failed to properly review its data processor to ensure it provided sufficient guarantees for data protection.

A private individual, acting as a marketer, decided to send promotional messages to several people. These individuals were potential customers whose contact information was used to send these messages. The marketer did not obtain prior consent from these individuals before sending the promotional content.

An individual wanted to register for an event organized by GSMA LTD. To complete the registration, the individual was required to transfer special categories of personal data, including ID card data, to the event organizer.

An individual received an unsolicited advertising call from Aesse S.r.l.s. The individual had not given consent to receive such communications. Upon requesting information about the origin of their data, the controller failed to provide adequate information.

Aldi, a supermarket chain, implemented a system where the date of birth of customers was entered and stored in their checkout system when purchasing alcoholic beverages. This was done to facilitate the cashiers' work by allowing the software to quickly determine if a customer was over 18 years old.

A couple decided to celebrate their wedding at the premises of BANQUETES SANTA ANA, S.L. The event organizer requested the couple to provide personal data of their guests, including ID card numbers, for the purpose of contact tracing during the Covid-19 pandemic.

An individual discovered that DISPLAY CONNECTORS, S.L. had published information about a court case that included personal data of their minor son. Concerned about the privacy implications, the individual filed a complaint with the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA). The case revolves around the conflict between the minor's right to privacy and the controller's freedom of information.

Burwebs S.L. operates websites with adult content. The company processes users' personal data but does not do so transparently. It retains users' personal data for an indefinite period and processes the data of minor users without obtaining parental consent. Additionally, Burwebs complicates the exercise of data subjects' rights and does not sufficiently inform users about the processing and storage of their personal data in its privacy policy. Furthermore, Burwebs' record of processing activities is incomplete.

Ediscom S.p.a., a marketing company, collected data from 21 million individuals through various online portals. The company intended to use this data for marketing activities and to transfer it to third parties. To obtain consent from users, Ediscom employed 'dark patterns', which are deceptive design techniques that mislead users into consenting to data processing and sharing. In some instances, the company could not demonstrate that it had obtained valid consent from the data subjects.

INFINITY ECOM S.L. operates an e-commerce website where it collects personal data from its visitors. The company is responsible for providing a privacy policy on its website that informs users about how their personal data is being processed, including details such as the identity of the data controller, the purposes of the processing, the legal basis for processing, and the rights of the data subjects. However, the privacy policy on the website did not meet the requirements set out in Article 13 of the GDPR, which mandates specific information to be provided to data subjects when their data is collected.

ALBERO FORTE COMPOSITE, S.L., a company, decided to take photographs of its employees at the entrance of the workplace. The purpose of taking these photographs was to record the working hours of the employees. The company did not conduct a data protection impact assessment before implementing this practice.

An aid organization that provides transportation services for people with illnesses maintained a database containing over 80,000 records, including sensitive health information. The organization experienced a data breach due to a hack, which resulted in the unauthorized publication of this data. The organization had not implemented adequate technical and organizational measures to protect the personal data. Additionally, the organization had not established a processing agreement with its data processors.

respondent: Operator of an outdoor swimming pool
case_content: During the Covid pandemic, an outdoor swimming pool operator collected visitor data for contact tracing purposes. The operator gathered more data than necessary for this purpose, exceeding the legal requirements for data collection. The data was intended to be used to trace contacts in case of a Covid outbreak.

During the Corona pandemic, a restaurant operator required visitors to fill out forms with their name, address, telephone number, and e-mail address for the purpose of contact tracing as required by law. Visitors were also required to check a box stating that they agreed to be contacted by the restaurant. The restaurant subsequently used the email addresses to send a promotional newsletter.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: A bank installed a video surveillance system covering parts of its branch foyer, entrance area, sidewalk, and parking spaces. The system transmitted images and allowed camera access commands over the Internet without encryption. This setup led to a data breach where unknown third parties compromised the video cameras, posted images online, and gained limited control over the cameras.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also recorded the neighboring property. The intention behind installing the cameras was to enhance security. However, the cameras inadvertently captured footage of the neighbor's property, leading to concerns about privacy and data protection.

A website operator manages a website that collects personal data from its users. The website has a privacy policy in place, but it does not fully comply with the requirements set out in Article 13 of the GDPR. This article mandates that data controllers provide specific information to data subjects when collecting their personal data, such as the identity of the data controller, the purposes of the processing, and the rights of the data subjects. The website's privacy policy lacks some of this required information, leading to a situation where users are not fully informed about how their data is being used.

A customer of Telefónica Móviles España, S.A.U. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to a third party without their consent. This unauthorized third party used the SIM card to gain access to the customer's bank account and perform unauthorized transactions. The telecommunications company did not verify the identity of the third party or obtain the customer's consent before issuing the duplicate SIM card.

A customer of DIGI SPAIN TELECOM, S.L. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to an unauthorized third party. This unauthorized individual used the SIM card to gain access to the customer's bank account and perform unauthorized transactions. The telecom company did not verify the identity of the third party nor did it obtain the customer's consent to share their data.

SECURITAS DIREC ESPAÑA, S.A., a company operating in Spain, was involved in a situation where it was required to comply with an order issued by the Spanish Data Protection Agency (DPA). The order was related to the company's data processing activities, and the DPA expected the company to take specific actions to ensure compliance with data protection regulations. However, SECURITAS DIREC ESPAÑA, S.A. failed to comply with the order within the stipulated time frame.

An employee of the Skåne region was in possession of a USB stick that contained the social security numbers and sensitive personal data of nearly 2,000 individuals. Unfortunately, the USB stick was unencrypted and was lost by the employee. This incident raised concerns about the adequacy of the technical and organizational measures implemented by the Skåne region to protect personal data.

A healthcare facility, Azienda sanitaria locale di Bari, published reviews of former patients on the Internet. The facility provided access to hundreds of documents where patients could be identified. Although attempts were made to redact the information, it was insufficient, leading to the disclosure of sensitive data such as patients' state of health, clinical data on operations, and diagnoses.

KFC RESTAURANTS SPAIN, S.L operates a website where it collects personal data from its visitors. However, the company did not appoint a data protection officer to oversee data protection activities. Additionally, the website did not provide all the necessary information required under GDPR Article 13, which mandates transparency in data collection practices.

A data subject exercised their right to object to the processing of their personal data by Tensa Art Design SA. Despite the objection, Tensa Art Design SA continued to process the data subject's personal data.

A police officer, utilizing their access to police databases, conducted private research to gather information about their ex-partner's new partner. This action was taken without any official police work justification, purely for personal reasons.

A police officer accessed data in police databases over a period of three years. The officer used this data for private research purposes, which was not related to their official duties. The data accessed included personal information of individuals stored in the police databases.

An employee at a Covid-19 test center took an adhesive label from the trash, wrote the test center's e-mail address on it, and attached it to the center's window. The employee did not notice that the label still contained personal data of an individual. As a result, the personal data was visible to third parties for about 24 hours until the label was removed.

A Covid-19 test center sent an email containing personal data to multiple recipients using an open distribution list. This action exposed the personal data of individuals to unintended recipients. Additionally, the test center did not adequately document the data breach that occurred as a result of this action.

A data subject submitted a request to a data controller to access their personal data. The data controller failed to respond to this request within the time frame stipulated by the GDPR. The data subject expected a timely response to their request, as per their rights under the GDPR.

Partidul Uniunea Salvați România, acting as a data controller, published personal data of individuals with varying degrees of disability on their website. This data was made accessible to the public without obtaining the necessary legal basis or consent from the data subjects.

The Dutch Social Insurance Institution (SVB) experienced a data breach where a client's benefit information was leaked to an unauthorized third party. This occurred when an unknown third party successfully requested the benefit information through the SVB's telephone helpdesk. The system for verifying the identity of callers was found to be inadequate, with verification questions being too simple.

VODAFONE ONO, S.A.U. conducted a credit check on an individual. The individual was not a customer of VODAFONE ONO, S.A.U., nor was there any other affiliation between them. The personal data of the individual was processed for the purpose of conducting a credit check.

An individual posted a review on the website of GUUDJOB WORLDWIDE S.L. Upon realizing that their name was published alongside the review, the individual requested the deletion of their personal data. However, the company did not comply with this request in a timely manner.
violated_articles: Article 17 - Right to erasure ('right to be forgotten')

case_content: A customer of Vodafone España, S.A.U. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to an unauthorized third party.
