However, the patrons of the bar were not provided with sufficient information regarding the video surveillance, such as the purpose of the surveillance, the identity of the data controller, or their rights concerning the data collected.

In a residential area managed by a homeowners' association, video surveillance cameras were installed to monitor the premises for security purposes. However, the association did not provide adequate information to the residents and visitors about the presence of these cameras, the purpose of the surveillance, or how the recorded data would be used and stored. This lack of transparency led to concerns among the residents and visitors about their privacy and the handling of their personal data.

Apă Canal Ilfov SA, acting as a data controller, sent an email containing personal data to multiple recipients using an open distribution list. This action allowed all recipients to view the email addresses of other recipients included in the list.

A homeowners' association decided to publicly post a list containing the first and last names of all its members. This list was made accessible to the general public, potentially exposing the personal information of the members without their explicit consent or a clear legal basis for such disclosure.

An individual submitted a request to the Cisterna di Latina Municipality to access their personal data. Due to an error, the municipality disclosed the data to a third party instead of the individual. Consequently, the individual did not receive a response to their request.

Meta Platforms Ireland Limited updated its terms of service shortly before the GDPR came into force. Users were informed to click 'Agree and Continue' to indicate their agreement with the new terms of service, which was required for further access to the services. Meta assumed that the acceptance of the updated terms constituted a contract, as the data processing was necessary for the provision and improvement of services. However, a complaint was filed arguing that Meta was actually relying on consent as a legal basis for processing users' data, effectively forcing users to consent to the processing of their personal data.

Sportitalia, an employer, decided to implement a system to register the attendance of its employees using biometric data, specifically fingerprints. The company collected and processed this biometric data from its employees for the purpose of monitoring their attendance at work. However, the employees were not sufficiently informed about the processing of their biometric data.

A customer of Areti spa, an electricity supplier, was classified as a defaulting customer due to outdated data in Areti's databases. This classification prevented the customer from switching to another electricity supplier. The issue arose from a mismatch in Areti's internal systems, affecting approximately 47,000 customers. Additionally, Areti stored the data for an inadequate length of time and failed to properly respond to requests to exercise data subject rights.

An employee of Kaufland Romania SCS took pictures of CCTV recordings using their cell phone. These images, which included identifiable information of two people and a license plate, were then transmitted to a third party. The third party subsequently published the images on the website of a local newspaper.

An employee of SUDREZIDENȚIAL Broker S.R.L. published an Excel spreadsheet on the Internet. This spreadsheet contained personal data of 509 customers, including their first name, last name, telephone number, ID number, e-mail address, and bank details. The data was made publicly accessible without the customers' consent.

The Villafranca di Verona municipality published a document on its website. This document contained personal data of one of its employees. The data was accessible to the general public through the website.

The Lazio Region, suspecting that employees of its legal department might be disclosing information protected by official secrecy to third parties, decided to monitor the e-mail accounts of these employees. The Region stored and analyzed the employees' data for 180 days. This data included not only work-related information but also personal data concerning the employees' private lives.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: An individual, upset about the requirement for students to wear masks during physical education classes, decided to record videos of teachers and underage students during these classes. The individual then posted these videos on the Internet to express their dissatisfaction with the mask mandate.
violated_articles: Article 8 - Conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services

case_content: Two property owners submitted a request for a copy of financial documents to the board of a Property Owners Association. The Association published these requests, which included personal data of the individuals, on the bulletin board in a common area of the residential building.

A private individual shared personal data, including name, surname, ID card number, and date of birth, of another person in a WhatsApp group consisting of 31 members. The data was shared without obtaining consent from the person whose data was shared.

A data subject discovered that a telephone line was registered in their name without their consent or any contractual relationship. The contracts for the telephone line were fraudulently concluded by individuals using the data subject's personal information. The data controller, ORANGE ESPAGNE, S.A.U., entered this personal data into their information systems without verifying the legitimacy of the contracts or whether they were actually concluded by the data subject.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: A patient visited HOSPITAL RECOLETAS PONFERRADA, S.L. for a medical examination. During the visit, the patient was asked to fill out a consent form. The form had certain items pre-ticked, indicating consent for specific uses of personal data. Later, the patient requested access to their personal data from the hospital, but the hospital did not provide the data in a timely manner.
violated_articles: Article 12 - Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject
Article 15 - Right of access by the data subject

case_content: Societatea Energetică Electrica S.A., a company providing energy services, engaged a third-party service provider to process personal data of its customers. The company was responsible for ensuring that the service provider adhered to GDPR requirements, particularly in establishing a data processing agreement that included specific instructions for processing personal data. However, the company failed to ensure that the agreement with the service provider contained all necessary clauses as required by GDPR, particularly those outlined in Article 28 (3) a). This oversight led to a potential risk of unauthorized data processing.

A customer of Vodafone España, S.A.U. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to a third party without their consent. The company did not verify the identity of the third party nor did it obtain the customer's consent to share their data.

A customer of Vodafone España, S.A.U. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to an unauthorized third party. The customer did not give consent for this action, and the company did not verify the identity of the third party before issuing the duplicate SIM card.

An oncology health care facility, I.S.P.R.O., mistakenly sent an individual's medical records to another patient via email. The intended recipient was supposed to receive their own medical records, but due to an error, they received the records of a different patient.

FREE SAS, a telecommunications company, received requests from individuals to access and delete their personal data. However, the company did not process these requests in a timely manner. Additionally, the company allowed users to use insecure passwords and stored user passwords unencrypted in its databases. Furthermore, the company failed to adequately document a data breach.

A customer of Vodafone España, S.A.U. discovered that their SIM card had been duplicated and provided to a third party without their consent. This unauthorized third party used the duplicated SIM card to gain access to the customer's bank account and perform unauthorized transactions. The customer was unaware of this until they noticed irregularities in their bank account.

In 2021, the Portuguese National Statistical Institute conducted a national census. During this process, they collected various types of personal data, including religious and health information. However, they did not inform the data subjects that providing religious and health data was voluntary. Additionally, the Institute did not exercise due diligence in selecting its data processor. The contract with the processor allowed for the transfer of personal data outside the European Economic Area (EEA) without implementing additional security measures beyond the Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs) approved by the European Commission. Furthermore, the Institute did not conduct a data protection impact assessment for the census.

A private individual, who owns a multi-party residential building, installed a video surveillance system to monitor the premises. The system was intended to enhance security for the residents and visitors of the building. However, the information sign accompanying the video surveillance system did not provide adequate details about the controller or how data subjects could exercise their rights.

A notary accessed the land register to obtain information about a property owned by a data subject. The notary did not have an order requiring this consultation nor did they have the consent of the data subject to access this information.

A private individual residing in a residential complex decided to install video surveillance cameras. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also covered common areas of the complex. The individual did not seek or obtain permission from other residents or the residential complex management to install these cameras. Furthermore, the individual did not inform the residents or any other data subjects about the presence of the video surveillance system.
violated_articles: Article 12 - Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject

case_content: Casa Rusu S.R.L., a company, implemented an unauthorized form on its website during the payment process. This form collected sensitive bank card information from customers, including their first and last names, card numbers, expiration dates, and CVC codes. The unauthorized form allowed third parties to access this personal data without the customers' consent or knowledge.

In 2018, Slane Credit Union Ltd. experienced a data breach due to an error in a search engine optimization tool installed on their website. This error led to the unintentional publication of four reports containing personal data of 76 members, including minors. The personal data exposed included names, addresses, gender, birth dates, and account numbers. The controller had not implemented adequate technical and organizational measures to protect this personal data. Additionally, they failed to conduct due diligence on the processor and did not conclude a GDPR-compliant contract with the processor.

The Association for the prevention and study of crimes, abuses and negligence in information technology and advanced communications (APEDANICA) requested information about LEGAL ERASER from the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA) under the Spanish Transparency Act. The information obtained included personal data of LEGAL ERASER's customers and employees. APEDANICA then published these documents on 58 links on the Internet, making the personal data publicly accessible.

ALPA 57 PRODUCCIONES, S.L., a company, was involved in an investigation conducted by the Spanish Data Protection Authority (AEPD). During this investigation, the AEPD requested specific information from ALPA 57 PRODUCCIONES, S.L. However, the company failed to provide the requested information to the AEPD.

respondent: Federation of Sports for People with Intellectual Disabilities of Castilla la Mancha-FECAM
case_content: The Federation of Sports for People with Intellectual Disabilities of Castilla la Mancha-FECAM organized sports competitions. During these events, they processed medical data from Covid-19 antigen tests of the participants. However, the participants were not asked for their consent to process this medical data. Additionally, the participants were not informed about how long their data would be retained.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: CASA 7 PERSONAL SHOPPER, S.L. sent an email containing personal data to multiple recipients using an open distribution list. This action allowed all recipients to view the email addresses of other recipients, potentially compromising their privacy.

During the Covid-19 pandemic, Azienda Usl Valle d'Aosta simplified its medical record system to facilitate patient management. This change allowed any employee to access patient medical records, regardless of whether the patient had given consent. An employee, who was also a patient, discovered that a colleague accessed their medical file multiple times without having treated them and despite the patient's explicit refusal of consent for such data processing.

A former voluntary member of Codess Sociale, Soc. Coop. sociale requested the deletion of their personal data from the organization's archives upon their resignation. The organization did not comply with this request in a timely manner.
violated_articles: Article 17 - Right to erasure ('right to be forgotten')

case_content: Alpha Exploration, the operator of the social network Clubhouse, allowed users to store and share audio messages from other users without obtaining their consent. Additionally, the company shared account information with unauthorized third parties without a valid legal basis. Users were not provided with sufficient information about the processing of their personal data, and the company did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures to protect this data. Furthermore, Alpha Exploration failed to define retention periods for personal data and did not conduct a data protection impact assessment.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data
Article 12 - Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject
Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject
Article 25 - Data protection by design and by default

case_content: A Homeowners Association installed several video surveillance cameras across a residential area. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also covered the common areas of the residential complex. The intention behind installing these cameras was to monitor the security of the area. However, the cameras captured footage of residents and visitors in the common areas, leading to concerns about privacy and data protection.

LORENT 2013, S.L. installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of public spaces. The cameras were intended for security purposes, but they also recorded individuals in public areas without their consent.

A person received an email from INDECEMI, S.L. containing personal data such as first name, last name, address, and telephone number of another individual. This occurred in the context of handling a complaint. The recipient of the email was not the intended subject of the personal data shared.

A company installed a video surveillance system that recorded both video and audio, capturing the voices of employees and customers. The company did not inform the individuals about the audio recording, nor did it provide information about the processing of this data, the identity of the data controller, or how individuals could exercise their data protection rights.

ÉLECTRICITÉ DE FRANCE (EDF), a major electricity supplier, was involved in a situation where several customers faced difficulties in exercising their data protection rights. EDF's privacy policy lacked sufficient information regarding data processing, particularly concerning the retention period of personal data. Additionally, EDF did not respond promptly to data subject requests and failed to honor the right to object to advertising in some instances. Moreover, EDF could not demonstrate that it had obtained valid consent from data subjects for a commercial solicitation campaign. The company also had issues with data security, as it stored passwords insecurely for over 25,000 customer accounts and merely hashed, without salting, the passwords of 2.4 million accounts.

An 80-year-old customer was contacted by an external call center commissioned by Vodafone Italia S.p.A. During the call, the call center concluded a new contract with the customer without obtaining their explicit consent. Additionally, the customer was not provided with sufficient information about the processing of their personal data, and the information that was provided was read out too quickly, making it incomprehensible.
violated_articles: Article 12 - Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject

case_content: A private individual installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of public spaces. The individual then published the recorded images on Facebook, making them accessible to the public.

An individual discovered a vulnerability in an IT platform operated by OTP LEASING ROMANIA IFN SA. By altering the URL address, the individual was able to create an administrator account, which granted them unauthorized access to personal data stored on the platform. This incident highlighted a lack of adequate technical and organizational measures by the controller to protect personal data.

Meta Platforms Ireland Limited, operating Facebook, had tools such as Facebook Search, Facebook Messenger Contact Importer, and Instagram Contact Importer. These tools were involved in a scenario where a dataset containing personal data of up to 533 million Facebook users, including phone numbers and email addresses, was made available on a hacking platform. This situation raised concerns about the adequacy of technical and organizational measures implemented by Meta to protect personal data.

Medicover S.R.L., a data controller, inadvertently sent documents containing personal data to the wrong recipient. The personal data included the data subject's name, correspondence address, email, and health data. This incident occurred due to the controller's failure to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect the processing of personal data.

respondent: ING Bank NV Amsterdam Sucursala București
case_content: ING Bank NV Amsterdam Sucursala București experienced a data breach where several personal data of customers, such as ID card data, bank data, and bank card data, were accessed and disclosed without authorization. This unauthorized access led to payment transactions being carried out by unauthorized third parties.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of the public space outside the property. The cameras were intended for surveillance purposes, but they inadvertently recorded individuals in the public space without their consent.

Upon arrival in Setúbal, Ukrainian refugees were asked by the municipality to fill out a form providing personal details such as their name, date of birth, and marital status. The municipality collected this information to assist in the registration and support of the refugees. However, the municipality did not adequately inform the refugees about how their data would be processed, did not implement sufficient technical and organizational measures to protect the data, did not define a retention period for the data, and failed to appoint a data protection officer.

The Homeowners Association 'Bld. Pipera 1-2E' was involved in a situation where the Romanian Data Protection Authority (DPA) requested specific information from them as part of an ongoing investigation. The association was expected to provide the necessary information to the DPA to assist in the investigation process.

DISCORD INC. offers an online communication service that allows users to chat or make video calls. Over time, the company accumulated a large number of inactive user accounts, with some accounts remaining unused for over three to five years. The company did not have a clear data retention policy or complete information regarding retention periods. Additionally, DISCORD INC. did not implement data protection by default, allowing user data to be transmitted even after the application was closed. The company also accepted insecure passwords, consisting of only six characters with letters and numbers. Furthermore, DISCORD INC. failed to conduct a data protection impact assessment.

Raiffeisen Bank SA conducted queries in a credit agency without obtaining consent from the data subjects. The bank also granted credit to several customers who had not applied for it. Additionally, the bank inadvertently sent personal data of data subjects to incorrect recipients, allowing unauthorized access to the data. The bank did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures to protect personal data, leading to unauthorized access and/or disclosure.

An employee of the Dobrzyniewo Duże municipality was using a work computer that contained personal data of residents. The computer was stolen, leading to a potential data breach. The municipality had not implemented adequate technical measures to secure the data on the computer.

respondent: AMPLIFON Hungary Trade and Service Provider LLC
case_content: AMPLIFON Hungary Trade and Service Provider LLC obtained contact information from the Ministry of the Interior for market research purposes. The company used this information to send unsolicited invitations for hearing screenings to several individuals. The individuals had not given their consent to be contacted for this purpose, and they were not adequately informed about how their data would be processed.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data
Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: A customer of BANKINTER, S.A. accessed their bank account and noticed that personal data of a third person was also displayed to them. This incident occurred due to inadequate technical and organizational measures at the bank, leading to unauthorized disclosure of the third person's data.

During the Covid-19 pandemic, XASTRE DO PETO, S.L., a restaurant, required individuals to fill out a form with their personal information for contact tracing purposes. An individual, concerned about this practice, filed a complaint with the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA). The restaurant collected personal data without providing sufficient information to the data subjects about the data processing and did not offer an easy way for individuals to object to the processing of their personal data.
violated_articles: Article 12 - Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject

case_content: An individual requested information about one of their accounts from Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, S.A. However, instead of receiving the requested information, the individual received contract information pertaining to a third party. This incident occurred due to inadequate technical and organizational measures at the bank.

A Homeowners Association decided to enhance security within a residential area by installing video surveillance cameras. These cameras were strategically placed to cover various parts of the residential area. However, the placement of some cameras also captured footage of public spaces adjacent to the residential area. The intention behind the installation was to monitor and ensure the safety of the residents and the property within the residential area.

respondent: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE ESPAÑA LTD Y COMPAÑIA SRC (UPS)
case_content: A person ordered a package to be delivered by UNITED PARCEL SERVICE ESPAÑA LTD Y COMPAÑIA SRC (UPS). Instead of delivering the package directly to the person, UPS delivered it to a neighbor without obtaining the person's consent. This action led to the unauthorized disclosure of the person's delivery information.

Techpump Solutions S.L. operates several websites with adult content. The company shared users' personal data with companies belonging to the same group, contrary to the information specified in its privacy policy. Techpump did not specify a retention period for users' personal data, keeping it indefinitely until users requested to withdraw their consent. The company processed users' personal data without first obtaining their consent. Techpump lacked sufficient parental controls to prevent minors under the age of 14 from accessing its content. The privacy policy was only available in English, not Spanish, and was not clearly understandable. Techpump required individuals wishing to exercise their data subject rights to submit their ID card information for identity verification. Additionally, Techpump collected data such as IP addresses and WIFI data without defining a processing purpose.
violated_articles: Article 12 - Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject
Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject
Article 25 - Data protection by design and by default

case_content: CÍTRICOS TANTA, S.L. entered the personal data of an individual into the Social Security General Employee Register, despite the individual never having worked for the company. The company was required to remove the individual's data from the register within 72 hours, as there was no legal basis for retaining it once it was clear that the individual was not employed.
violated_articles: Article 17 - Right to erasure ('right to be forgotten')

case_content: An individual received an unsolicited commercial email from Colosseo S.r.l. The individual then requested the company to provide access to their personal data, delete their personal data, and objected to receiving future promotional emails. However, the company did not respond to these requests.

SC Das Sense Society SRL, a company operating in Romania, was involved in a situation where the Romanian Data Protection Authority (ANSPDCP) requested specific information from the company as part of an ongoing investigation. The company was expected to provide the requested information to assist the authority in its investigation process.

SC Prestige Media PHG SRL published 23 documents on its website. These documents contained personal data related to the termination of employment relationships. Some of the individuals whose data was published had no legal relationship with the company.

A customer repeatedly requested a copy of their phone contract from Vodafone España, S.A.U. After several attempts, the customer received an email from Vodafone. However, instead of receiving their own contract, the customer received the phone contract of another customer.

The Romanian Post was responsible for delivering mailings that contained sensitive personal data, including pension statements, employment certificates, and death certificates. During the process, several mailings were lost by the staff, affecting 35 individuals who were the intended recipients of these documents. The incident raised concerns about the adequacy of the technical and organizational measures implemented by the Romanian Post to protect personal data.
A customer of CAIXABANK S.A. repeatedly requested the bank to update their address on file. Despite multiple attempts, the bank failed to update the address as requested by the customer.

A customer of BANCO BILBAO VIZCAYA ARGENTARIA, S.A., who is also an attorney, filed a statement of claim against the bank on behalf of their client, another customer of the bank. In response, the bank sent a reply to the client. However, instead of using the attorney's professional address, the bank inadvertently used the attorney's private address.

A member of a staff council decided to share the minutes of staff council meetings with individuals who were not part of the staff council. These unauthorized third parties received the information without any legal basis or consent from the staff council members whose information was contained in the minutes.

A private individual, acting as a blogger, published personal data of another person on their blog. The data was shared without obtaining consent from the individual whose data was published. The publication was done in a manner that was defamatory towards the data subject. The blog was accessible to the public, allowing any reader to view the personal data.
violated_articles: Article 10 - Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences
Article 17 - Right to erasure ('right to be forgotten')

case_content: A customer, who is a new tenant, received a document from URBANO DIVERTIA S.L., the controller, containing personal data of the previous tenant of the apartment they are now renting. This incident led to a complaint being filed by the customer.

A data subject submitted a request to a data controller to access their personal data. The data controller failed to respond to this request within the time frame stipulated by the GDPR. The data subject expected to receive their data or at least a response acknowledging the request and providing a timeline for when the data would be made available. However, the data controller did not provide any response or the requested data within the required period.

respondent: EL RACO DEL PIS INVERSIONES S.L.
case_content: EL RACO DEL PIS INVERSIONES S.L. sent an email to multiple recipients using an open distribution list. This action made the email addresses of all recipients visible to each other, potentially compromising their privacy.

respondent: ACKERMANN & SCHWARTZ ATTORNEYS AT LAW SLP
case_content: ACKERMANN & SCHWARTZ ATTORNEYS AT LAW SLP, a law firm, collected personal data from users visiting their website. However, the firm did not obtain consent from these users before collecting their data. Additionally, the privacy policy on the website was found to be lacking essential information, such as the contact details of the data controller and instructions on how data subjects could exercise their rights.

A customer of OES GLOBAL ENERGY S.L. received an email from the company. This email contained documents related to the termination of electricity contracts. However, the documents mistakenly included personal data of other customers, such as their names and ID numbers.

A former employee of Thiene municipality discovered that a document containing their personal data, specifically information about the termination of their employment relationship, was published on the municipality's website. The employee was concerned about the exposure of their personal information to the public.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: A consumer, who had registered their contact information in the Robinson advertising exclusion list to avoid receiving unsolicited marketing communications, received advertising calls from ADSL HOUSE, S.L. The company contacted the consumer for advertising purposes despite the consumer's explicit registration in the exclusion list.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras at their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of the public space outside the property. The cameras continuously recorded video footage of individuals passing by or present in the public space.

A company installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of public spaces. The cameras were intended for security purposes, but they also recorded individuals in public areas without their consent.

Acqua Novara.VCO S.p.a. engaged Clio S.r.l. to provide and manage a whistleblowing reporting application. In this arrangement, Acqua Novara provided personal data related to whistleblowing reports to Clio. Clio collected and stored this data as part of its service to Acqua Novara. However, the relationship between Acqua Novara and Clio was not adequately regulated, and there was no valid legal basis for the processing of personal data by Clio.

Ginosa municipality engaged Clio S.r.l. to provide and manage a whistleblowing reporting application. In the course of this engagement, the municipality provided personal data related to whistleblowing reports to Clio. However, the municipality did not establish a valid legal basis for this data sharing and failed to adequately regulate its relationship with Clio.

Clio S.r.l. provides and manages a whistleblowing reporting application for various private and public entities. In its operations, Clio shares data on whistleblowing reports with its customers. However, Clio has not adequately regulated its relationship with these customers, and it provides data on whistleblowing reports without a valid legal basis. Additionally, Clio fails to maintain a register of activities carried out in its role as a processor.

Servizio Idrico Integrato S.c.p.a. operated a website where personal data of users was processed. However, the website did not use an SSL form, which is a security measure to protect data during transmission. This lack of security measure raised concerns about the protection of personal data being processed on the website.

Interserve Group Limited, a construction company, experienced a cyber attack when a phishing email was sent to their accounting team. An employee opened the email and downloaded an attached zip file, which led to the installation of malware. This malware allowed attackers to access and siphon off personal data of 113,000 employees, including sensitive information such as bank account details, social security numbers, ethnicity, sexual orientation, and religion. The company had inadequate security measures, including insufficient employee training on data privacy, use of unsupported operating systems, lack of adequate vulnerability scans, and insufficient investigation of the attack by the information security team.

An individual requested Bper Banca S.p.A. to delete their personal data. The bank asked the individual to provide identification documents to verify their identity for processing the deletion request. The individual submitted the required documents but did not receive a response regarding the deletion of their data.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of the public space outside the property. The cameras continuously recorded video footage of individuals passing by or present in the public space.

In the context of using certain debit/credit cards, the NATIONAL BANK OF GREECE S.A. stored information about the last 10 transactions on the chip of the card. This information could be read out later by card reader devices. The bank did not inform the customers about this storage of transaction information.

PIRAEUS BANK S.A. implemented a system where the last 10 transactions of a customer's debit/credit card were stored on the chip of the card. This information could be accessed later by reading the chip. However, the bank did not inform its customers about this storage of transaction information, nor did it obtain explicit consent from them for this practice.

EUROBANK ERGASIAS S.A. implemented a system where the last 10 transactions made with certain debit/credit cards were stored on the chip of the card. This information could be accessed later, but the bank did not inform its customers about this storage practice, nor did it obtain explicit consent from them for storing such information on the card.

ALFA BANK S.A. implemented a system where the last 10 transactions made using certain debit/credit cards were stored on the chip of the card. This information could be accessed later by reading the chip. However, the bank did not inform its customers about this storage of transaction information, nor did it obtain explicit consent from them for this practice.

A school installed several video surveillance cameras on its premises, which continuously recorded students, teachers, and visitors. The school informed teachers and parents about the video surveillance system only verbally and incompletely.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: A gas station operator had a video surveillance system in place. A parent requested access to images of their minor child recorded by this system. The operator failed to provide access to these images. Additionally, the operator shared the images with the police during an investigation without informing the parent.

Immobiliare Riscostruzione Meloria s.r.l. installed a video surveillance system at its office. The system covered parts of a common entrance to the building, which resulted in the recording of residents of the building. The information sign regarding the video surveillance did not provide sufficient information on the purpose of the processing of personal data and the contact details of the data controller.

A company installed video surveillance cameras on its premises. These cameras were equipped to record both video and audio. The company used these recordings for surveillance purposes. However, the company did not obtain the necessary legal basis or consent from the individuals being recorded.

A private individual accessed and used another person's personal data without obtaining their consent. The individual did not have any formal authorization to use this data, and the purpose for which the data was used was not specified.

SC Materiale Constructii Online SRL was involved in a situation where the Romanian Data Protection Authority (ANSPDCP) requested specific information from them as part of an ongoing investigation. The company was expected to provide the necessary information to assist the authority in their investigation process.

Clearview AI, a company that maintains a database of over 20 billion facial images collected from publicly accessible online platforms, offers a search service that allows individuals to be identified based on biometric data extracted from these images. The service also enriches individuals' profiles with additional information such as image tags and geolocation. The company limited the exercise of data subjects' rights to twice a year without justification and required multiple requests before responding, often inadequately. Additionally, Clearview AI was uncooperative with regulatory investigations.
violated_articles: Article 12 - Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject
Article 15 - Right of access by the data subject
Article 17 - Right to erasure ('right to be forgotten')
Article 31 - Cooperation with the supervisory authority

case_content: A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured footage not only of their own property but also of the public space and a neighboring property. The individual intended to use the cameras for property surveillance.

RESTEXPERIENCE, S.L., a company acting as a data controller, accidentally sent an email containing tax information of 36 individuals to 11 unauthorized individuals. This incident involved the transmission of sensitive personal data without the appropriate consent or authorization from the data subjects. The company had not implemented adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure the security and confidentiality of the personal data, leading to this accidental disclosure.

A data subject took out a life insurance policy with Intesa Sanpaolo Vita S.p.a. During the course of their business, an employee of the insurance company mistakenly disclosed the data subject's personal information, including their first name, last name, and details about their policy, to third parties. This disclosure was not authorized by the data subject.

INMUR JOYEROS, S.L. installed video surveillance cameras on its premises to enhance security. However, the company did not provide any notice to inform customers and visitors about the presence of these cameras and the collection of their video data.
A patient requested her complete medical records from her physician, including imaging records and consent forms related to her maternity care. The physician did not fulfill this request.
violated_articles: Article 15 - Right of access by the data subject

case_content: An individual received invoices from Cosmopol Security S.p.A. without ever having had a contractual relationship with the company. The individual requested information from the company regarding the origin of their personal data. However, the company did not respond to the individual's request for information in a timely manner.

SEAN SERIOS S.L. conducted a selection procedure and published the results on a website. The published information included personal data of the participants, such as their surnames, first names, and scores in the selection process. The data was made accessible to the public through the website.

An individual applied for a credit offer from a bank, which led the bank to conduct a credit check on the individual. Subsequently, the bank performed a second credit check on the individual without a new credit application or request from the individual.

IDIKA SA was involved in providing free COVID-19 tests. During this process, they collected personal data from individuals undergoing the tests. However, they did not adequately inform these individuals about how their personal data would be processed. Additionally, IDIKA retained the personal data for longer than necessary and did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures to protect the data.

A medical laboratory was responsible for managing patient data. Physicians were able to access patients' personal data through the laboratory's website. However, the data was not encrypted, potentially exposing sensitive information. Additionally, the laboratory did not conduct a data protection impact assessment to evaluate the risks associated with processing this data. Furthermore, the laboratory failed to provide a privacy statement on its website, which would inform patients about how their data was being used.

EDYTE SA, acting as a data processor, was involved in handling personal data on behalf of a data controller. During its operations, EDYTE SA disclosed personal data to third parties. This disclosure occurred without obtaining the necessary authorization from the data controller, which is a critical step in ensuring that data processing activities are conducted in compliance with the agreed terms and legal requirements.

Curtea Veche Publishing SRL experienced two data breaches. In the first incident, a file containing the customer database was inadvertently published in a public forum, leading to the unauthorized disclosure of personal data of 10,793 customers. The data included first names, last names, phone numbers, emails, passwords in encrypted form, and IP addresses. In the second incident, a ransomware attack resulted in unauthorized access and loss of integrity and availability of personal data of about 100 data subjects.

The Edoardo Amaldi School decided to inform the public about the summer vacation schedule by publishing a circular on its website. This circular included the exact vacation dates of the school staff. The intention was to provide clarity on the availability of staff during the summer period.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: A website operator published personal data of 383 individuals on their website. The data included sensitive information such as telephone numbers, ID numbers and series, e-mail addresses, bank details, and marital status. The individuals whose data was published did not provide consent for this information to be shared publicly.

A homeowners' association decided to install a video surveillance system in the common areas of their residential complex. The system was set up to record both video and audio to enhance security measures. The association did not provide adequate information to the residents and visitors about the surveillance system, including details about the data being collected and the purpose of the collection.

Everis Spain S.L. published information on sold data of users of an insurance company, as well as records with personal data of Spanish customers of the insurance company. This publication was made without proper technical and organizational measures to protect the personal data, leading to a breach of confidentiality.

A company decided to install video surveillance cameras on its premises for security monitoring purposes. However, the company did not obtain the necessary authorization for the installation of these cameras. Additionally, the company failed to provide adequate signage indicating the presence of CCTV cameras and did not include contact details of the data controller on any signs that were present.
A private individual sent emails containing personal data to multiple recipients using an open distribution list. This action allowed all recipients to view the email addresses of other recipients.

HEI - Medical Travel accessed an individual's email address through the Icelandic Medical Association's internal website. Subsequently, HEI - Medical Travel sent unsolicited emails to this individual. The individual requested information from HEI - Medical Travel regarding the processing of their personal data, including the origin of their email address, but did not receive a proper response.

A researcher accessed a health database containing personal data of patients for private research activities. The researcher did not obtain proper authorization from the patients to use their health data for this purpose. The research institution facilitated this access without ensuring that the necessary legal requirements for data processing were met.

respondent: CAJA DE SEGUROS REUNIDOS, COMPAÑÍA DE SEGUROS Y REASEGUROS, S.A.
case_content: A data subject took out an insurance policy with an insurance company, designating their ex-life partner as the beneficiary. After their separation, the ex-life partner requested the insurance company to change the debit entry for the premium from the data subject's account to her own account. The insurance company made this change without obtaining the data subject's consent.

PUNTO BADAL-BCN S.L., a real estate agency, sent marketing emails to several individuals. These emails were sent using an open distribution list, which made the email addresses of all recipients visible to each other.

Senseonics Inc. conducted an information campaign via email targeting diabetic patients. An employee accidentally sent the email to a large number of recipients using an open distribution list, exposing the email addresses of all recipients to each other. This exposure allowed the inference of the health status of the recipients as diabetic patients. Additionally, when users downloaded the company's glucose monitoring app, they were required to accept the terms of use and privacy policy with a single click, without the option to separately consent to different processing operations, including the processing of health data. The company also provided users with confusing and sometimes incorrect information about how their personal data would be processed. Furthermore, Senseonics Inc. did not designate a representative in the European Union to handle data protection issues.

An individual received an invitation from the regional health authority to participate in a cervical cancer screening program. The invitation was addressed to her daughter, who had passed away in 1995. The daughter's data was still present in the region's database, and the region had not provided the required information about the processing of personal data when sending out the invitation letters.

Easylife Ltd., a retailer selling household items and services under various clubs, made assumptions about customers' health conditions based on their purchases. When customers bought certain 'trigger products' from the Health Club catalog, Easylife created profiles of these customers to target them with health-related products via phone or SMS. This profiling and targeting occurred without the customers' consent or knowledge. Additionally, Easylife made a large number of unsolicited marketing calls to individuals without obtaining their consent.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: A data subject, who is a member of Club Náutico el Estacio, discovered that the club had published an announcement and the record of its ordinary meeting on its website. This publication included personal data of the members without any access restrictions, making it available to the general public. The data subject was concerned about the lack of privacy and the potential misuse of their personal information.

In spring and summer 2020, the Danish Immigration Agency experienced several security incidents in its IT systems, leading to the loss of data records. This loss of data resulted in proceedings being initiated against a number of residents regarding the reduction of their cash benefits, and some residents were reported to the police for non-compliance with the provisions of the Foreigners Act. The agency had not made adequate backups of the data processed, which was necessary given the legal consequences a loss of the data could mean for the immigrants.

A private individual contacted a public institution to report that a statement made by a kindergarten teacher about being 50% disabled was inaccurate. To support this claim, the individual submitted a court report containing health-related data about the teacher.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: A private individual installed a video surveillance system on their property. The system was set up in such a way that it also recorded footage of the public space outside the property. The footage was stored for an excessively long period of time, beyond what might be considered necessary for the intended purpose of security.

Bayard Revistas S.A. maintained a database containing location and contact data of approximately 470,000 users. Due to a vulnerability in their systems, unauthorized persons were able to access and siphon off this data without the users' consent or knowledge.

A healthcare facility, Azienda Socio Sanitaria Territoriale Rhodense, experienced a loss of a patient's medical record. The lost file contained personal data including the patient's surname, first name, gender, date and place of birth, tax number, place of residence, and telephone numbers. This incident highlighted a lack of technical and organizational measures to protect personal data at the facility.

A former employee of Stay Over s.r.l. requested access to their personal data from the company. The company did not respond to this request in a timely manner. Additionally, after the termination of the employment relationship, the company continued to process data from the employee's email inbox without obtaining the employee's consent.

Global Service s.r.l. installed video surveillance cameras on its premises. The cameras were used to monitor the premises for security purposes. However, the company did not properly inform the employees and visitors about the processing of their data through the video surveillance system.

Auto Hi-Fi System S.n.c installed a video surveillance system that captured footage of both a public road and a private property. The system was intended for security monitoring. However, the company did not provide any signage to inform individuals about the surveillance.

CLUB NATACIO LLEIDA installed a video surveillance system that recorded the cashier areas of their facility. The system was intended to monitor security within the premises. The video surveillance captured footage of both customers and employees as they interacted in the cashier areas.

Y OTRO MAS C.B. installed a video surveillance system in a residential complex. The system was intended to monitor the premises for security purposes. However, the information sign about the video surveillance did not provide sufficient details regarding the processing of personal data, the identity of the controller, or how data subjects could exercise their rights.

Bitfactor SRL, a data controller, experienced a malfunction in one of its applications. This malfunction led to the unintended sending of marketing messages to users of its website. The messages resulted in a breach of confidentiality concerning the personal data of 1757 data subjects.

A surveyor, using his authority, accessed the electronic land register to identify several hundred property owners without their knowledge. He then passed this information to a property developer, who contacted the identified owners.
A health insurance provider published the result of a Covid-19 test of an individual on its website. This action made the personal data accessible to unauthorized persons.
An employee of a company made sound recordings with a mobile phone during repair work at a homeowner's residence. The homeowner was not informed about the recording.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: The Sułkowice Cultural Center, acting as a data controller, transferred the processing of personal data to a third-party processor. However, they did not establish a written agreement with the processor to ensure compliance with data protection obligations. Additionally, the Cultural Center failed to verify whether the processor provided sufficient guarantees for implementing appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect the personal data being processed.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured footage that included public spaces, such as sidewalks or streets, where individuals could be recorded without their knowledge. The individual did not provide adequate information to the people being recorded about the data processing activities, including the purpose of the surveillance and how the data would be used or stored.

Banca Comercială Română SA experienced a data breach due to an error in their IT application. This error resulted in emails containing personal data of customers being sent to unintended recipients. The personal data disclosed included first and last names, home addresses, phone numbers, email addresses, and financial information. A total of 564 individuals were affected by this incident.

An individual, who is a member of the Union Sindical Obrera, requested the deletion of their personal data from the union's records. Despite this request, the individual continued to receive emails from the union. The individual then filed a complaint with the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA) regarding the union's failure to comply with their data deletion request.

An individual approached a real estate agency, BARCELONA DREAM HOUSE AGENCY, to discuss the possibility of entering into a rental agreement. During this process, the real estate agent collected personal data from the individual. However, the agent did not provide sufficient information to the individual about how their personal data would be processed. Specifically, the individual was not informed about the purpose of the data processing or the identity of the data controller.

A person discovered that their bank account had been debited by MARIELI GABRIELA, S.L. despite not having any contractual relationship with the company. The person was concerned about the unauthorized transaction and decided to file a complaint with the Spanish Data Protection Authority (DPA) to address the issue.

A surveyor accessed the electronic land register using his authority and identified several hundred property owners without their knowledge. The surveyor then passed this information to a property development company. The company used this information to send letters to the property owners, making purchase price offers for their properties. The letters did not include any information about the origin of the data, and the company did not respond when property owners inquired about the data's source.

respondent: Subsidiary of a Berlin-based e-commerce group
case_content: A subsidiary of a Berlin-based e-commerce group appointed a data protection officer who was also the managing director of two service companies. These service companies processed personal data on behalf of the e-commerce group. The data protection officer's dual role raised concerns about a potential conflict of interest, as they were responsible for overseeing data protection compliance while also managing companies that processed the data.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras also captured footage of a shared access road used by neighbors. The individual did not inform the neighbors about the video surveillance or the processing of their data.

An ex-wife installed video surveillance cameras in a house jointly occupied with her ex-husband. These cameras recorded areas of the house that were part of the ex-husband's living space, leading to concerns about privacy invasion.

A data subject, who had registered in the Robinson advertising exclusion list to avoid receiving unsolicited marketing communications, received an advertising call from SOLIVESA MASTER FRANCHISE S.L. The call was made on behalf of Vodafone España, S.A.U. The data subject had not given consent for such communications, as they had opted out by registering in the exclusion list.

respondent: Person pretending to be a relative
case_content: A person contacted NATURGY ENERGY GROUP, S.A., pretending to be a relative of one of their customers. The person requested that the customer's electricity bills be sent to a new email address. To verify the identity of the requester, the company required the provision of the customer's name, address, ID number, contract number, and the last 4 digits of the bank account details.

Realmedia Network SA, a company operating a website, experienced security breaches that resulted in unauthorized access to personal data. The data involved included sensitive information such as surnames, first names, telephone numbers, e-mail addresses, postal addresses, signatures, copies of ID cards, bank data, and information from land register extracts. A total of 194,309 individuals were affected by this security incident.

A wedding dress company, SOPHIE ET VOILA, S.L., took a picture of a customer wearing one of their wedding dresses. The company then published this picture on its Instagram account. The customer was not asked for consent before the picture was shared publicly on social media.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of a public space. The cameras were intended for surveillance purposes, but they also recorded individuals who were in the public area.

An individual, who is a member or participant of the Federazione Italiana Nuoto, requested access to their personal data held by the organization. The organization, acting as a data controller, was responsible for responding to this request in a timely manner, as per the individual's rights under data protection regulations.

respondent: Federazione Italiana Sommelier, Albergatori e Ristoratori
case_content: The Federazione Italiana Sommelier, Albergatori e Ristoratori sent a protocol containing personal data of one of its members to all other members. This protocol included information about a disciplinary measure against the member, which was not yet legally binding and was later revoked. Despite the revocation, the disciplinary measure continued to be published on a cloud platform.

A store owner installed video surveillance cameras in their store. These cameras also captured footage of the public space outside the store. The store owner did not properly inform individuals who were recorded by the cameras about the data processing activities.

MUXERS CONCEPT, S.L., a company operating a restaurant, installed video surveillance cameras and microphones in the employee changing room. The company intended to monitor the area for security or other purposes. However, the employees were not informed about this surveillance, and no consent was obtained from them for such data processing.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: EURO DONER KEBAB installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of public spaces. The cameras were intended for security purposes. However, the individuals in the public space were not properly informed about the data processing activities related to the video surveillance.

An individual began receiving text messages from SC Raiffeisen Bank SA regarding money transfers to certain persons. The individual had not initiated these transactions and was not a customer of the bank. The bank had mistakenly used the individual's telephone number for transaction purposes in 44 cases.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they captured footage not only of the individual's own property but also of the public space and a neighboring property. The cameras were intended for surveillance purposes.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of the public space outside the property. The individual intended to use the cameras for surveillance purposes.

GIE INFOGREFFE operates a website that provides access to legal information about companies and allows users to order documents certified by commercial courts. The portal retained personal data of 25% of its members and subscribers, including bank details, surnames, first names, addresses, and telephone numbers, for a period longer than intended, specifically 36 months. Additionally, the portal did not enforce the use of secure passwords during account creation, resulting in 3.7 million accounts with insufficient password security. Passwords were transmitted unencrypted via email, and both passwords and secret questions and answers used for password resets were stored in an unencrypted database.

A private individual installed three video surveillance cameras on his property. These cameras, in addition to monitoring his own property, also captured footage of the access road used by a neighbor. The neighbor's access road was within the surveillance range of the cameras, leading to the collection of video footage of the neighbor's activities without their consent.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: Recover AS, a company, conducted a credit check on an individual. The company did not have a valid legal basis for performing this credit check on the data subject.

MH VILASECA S.L. installed video surveillance cameras on its premises to monitor security. However, the company did not provide any notice to inform individuals, such as visitors and employees, that they were being recorded. This lack of transparency meant that individuals were unaware of the video surveillance and the purpose behind it.

Bazar Pekin, a business entity, installed video surveillance cameras on its premises to monitor activities for security purposes. However, the business did not provide any notice to individuals entering the premises about the presence of these cameras and the collection of their video data. Additionally, Bazar Pekin failed to maintain a proper register of processing activities related to the video surveillance data.

Alpha Bank Romania SA sent a document via WhatsApp to an unintended recipient. The document contained personal data of four individuals, including their first and last names, as well as information on loans and contracts.

An individual discovered that a company, DIGITECNIA SOLUTIONS, S.L., had published a picture of them without obtaining their permission. The individual was concerned about their privacy and the unauthorized use of their image, leading them to take action.

COLEGIO VILLAEUROPA, S.C.L., a school, implemented a video surveillance system on its premises. However, the school did not provide adequate information to individuals being recorded by the surveillance system. The information sign associated with the surveillance system failed to include a reference to the data controller and did not provide an address for individuals to contact if they wished to exercise their data subject rights.

SERVICIOS PROFESIONALES LA PARADA S.L. installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of public spaces. The company did not adequately inform individuals in the public space about the data processing activities being conducted through the video surveillance system.
violated_articles: Article 12 - Transparent Information, Communication and Modalities for the Exercise of the Rights of the Data Subject

case_content: Meta Platforms, Inc. operated Instagram, a social media platform where users could create accounts to share content. On Instagram, business accounts of minors were configured such that their cell phone numbers and email addresses were publicly displayed. Additionally, the default settings for underage users' accounts were set to 'public', making their social media content accessible to anyone unless the users manually changed their account settings. This configuration potentially exposed millions of teenagers' personal information to the public.

respondent: Sindicato Intersectorial Trabajadores/as Provincia de Alicante
case_content: The Sindicato Intersectorial Trabajadores/as Provincia de Alicante union decided to share the protocols of a works council meeting. They published these protocols on their bulletin board and in a WhatsApp group. This action led to the exposure of the handwritten signatures of all union representatives who were part of the works council.

E Software Concept SRL uploaded certain documents on its website that were publicly accessible. These documents included invoices and transport documents containing personal data such as names, surnames, addresses, telephone numbers, user names, passwords, and e-mail addresses. The company failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to protect this personal data.

A customer of Enel Energie Muntenia S.A. received an email that was intended for another customer. This email contained documents with personal data belonging to the other customer. The incident occurred due to inadequate technical and organizational measures taken by the company to protect personal data.

An employee of Unicredit S.p.A. sought to access their personal data held by the company. The company required the employee to fill out a specific form to gain access to this data. The employee found this requirement to be a barrier to accessing their personal data and filed a complaint.

Cribis Credit Management s.r.l., a credit management company, sent an email regarding late payments on a subscription. This email was inadvertently sent to the head of an employee, allowing the head to access the employee's personal data, including their name, surname, and payment status information.

An individual contacted a real estate company, Fincas Arenys SL, to rent a property. During this process, the company requested certain documents from the individual. However, the company did not inform the individual about how their personal data would be processed as part of the rental process.

SMART ELECTRIC SOLUTIONS, S.L. installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of public spaces. The company did not adequately inform individuals in these public spaces about the data processing activities being conducted by the video surveillance system.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras captured footage that included not only their own property but also extended to cover public spaces and a neighboring property. The individual did not inform the people being recorded about the data processing activities being conducted through the video surveillance.

UNONO NET 3.0, S.L., a company, sent an email to multiple recipients. However, instead of using the blind copy (BCC) function, the company used the carbon copy (CC) function, which allowed all recipients to see each other's email addresses. This action led to the exposure of personal data (email addresses) of the recipients to one another.

respondent: DO VALUE GREECE LOANS & CREDITS CLAIM MANAGEMENT S.A.
case_content: An individual received numerous calls from DO VALUE GREECE LOANS & CREDITS CLAIM MANAGEMENT S.A. regarding debts that had already been settled. The individual objected to the processing of their data and demanded that the calls stop immediately and that their personal data be deleted from the company's database.

respondent: Private Polyclinic and Diagnostic Centre of Pyle Axiou
case_content: A patient requested access to their personal data from an imaging examination conducted at the Private Polyclinic and Diagnostic Centre of Pyle Axiou. However, the clinic was unable to provide the requested images because they were not available. This situation arose due to the clinic's failure to maintain adequate storage facilities for the imaging data.

Hotel guests who made bookings directly with ACCOR SA or through the hotel group's websites were automatically subscribed to an advertising newsletter due to a pre-ticked consent box. Many individuals faced technical issues that prevented them from opting out of receiving promotional emails. ACCOR SA did not adequately inform data subjects about the processing of their personal data in the context of promotional messages. Additionally, ACCOR SA failed to respond to data subjects' requests for access to personal data in a timely manner and did not comply with the data subjects' right to object due to technical problems. Furthermore, ACCOR SA allowed the use of passwords that were not sufficiently secure.

A data controller was responsible for processing personal data. However, the controller failed to demonstrate accountability by not having proof of conducting a data protection impact assessment. Additionally, the controller did not ensure fairness and transparency in its data processing activities. Furthermore, the controller neglected to formalize a contractual agreement with the data processor, which is necessary to outline the responsibilities and obligations of both parties in handling personal data.

In a garden community, the management installed video surveillance cameras to monitor the premises for security purposes. The cameras were positioned in such a way that they captured footage of residents and visitors in common areas, including private gardens. The community management did not obtain explicit consent from the residents or visitors for this surveillance, nor did they provide adequate information about the purpose and scope of the monitoring. The residents became aware of the surveillance and raised concerns about their privacy being invaded.

A data controller in Slovakia was required to cooperate with the Slovak Data Protection Authority (DPA) as part of its regulatory obligations. The DPA requested certain information or cooperation from the controller to ensure compliance with data protection laws. However, the controller failed to provide the necessary cooperation or information to the DPA.

JOYPAZAR, S.A. installed video surveillance cameras in their premises. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of a nearby public playground. The intention behind installing these cameras was to enhance security. However, the cameras inadvertently recorded individuals, including children, who were using the playground.
A customer of FREE SUN ENERGY S.L. expected to receive their invoice but instead received the invoice of another customer. This invoice contained personal data of the other customer.

respondent: ECOZONO Y CULTURA, S.L., Service Provider
case_content: ECOZONO Y CULTURA, S.L., through a service provider, collected personal data from individuals who agreed to participate in surveys. The individuals provided their data under the impression that it would be used solely for survey purposes. However, the data was subsequently used by ECOZONO Y CULTURA, S.L. to contact these individuals for advertising purposes.

The Santa Ninfa municipality published a resolution on its website. This resolution contained personal information, including the name and references about the enforcement title of an individual. The information was made accessible to the general public through the municipality's website.

Farpa s.r.l. installed video surveillance systems in the social facilities it operates. The systems had different features and were installed in different positions than those initially approved. Additionally, the company did not sufficiently inform the guests and relatives of the facility about the video surveillance.

Manx Care Ltd, a healthcare provider, sent an unsecured email attachment containing a patient's confidential health information to more than 1870 recipients. The recipients were not related to the patient's care, and the patient was not informed of this data breach.

An individual was involved in the process of acquiring an apartment through RODALI GESTIÓN INMOBILIARIA, S.L. During this process, the individual's personal data was processed by the company. However, the company did not inform the individual about the processing of their personal data, which is a requirement under GDPR.

An employee of a political organization sent an email to 400 people using an open distribution list. This action inadvertently exposed the email addresses and political orientation of all recipients to each other.

During the Covid-19 pandemic, a restaurant collected guest registration forms for contact tracing purposes. These forms contained personal data of the guests. The restaurant stored the completed forms in an adjoining room accessible to all employees without any special security measures, such as a locked cabinet. Eventually, the restaurant disposed of 120 completed guest registration forms in a publicly-accessible dumpster.

An employee of a bank had regular access to the bank account data of a customer. Over a period of about a year, the employee accessed this data for private purposes. The employee's actions involved viewing the customer's bank account information without any professional or work-related reason.

An employee working at a Covid testing center accessed the personal information of a test subject, specifically their phone number, which was collected during the testing process. The employee then used this phone number to contact the test subject privately, outside the scope of their professional duties.

A physician, responsible for maintaining the confidentiality and security of patient records, stored these records in an open carport instead of a locked room. This storage method exposed sensitive patient information to potential unauthorized access, as the carport was not secured.

A physician's office, responsible for maintaining the confidentiality and security of patient records, disposed of these records in a waste paper container. This container was used by several offices, potentially exposing sensitive patient information to unauthorized access.

The owner of a gym issued an apology for the late opening of the gym. In the apology, the owner shifted the responsibility for the delay to an employee, naming the employee in the process. This resulted in the employee's personal data being disclosed to the public.

A private individual attended a court hearing and used their mobile phone to secretly record video footage of the proceedings. The individual did not inform the court or any of the participants about the recording, nor did they obtain any form of consent or authorization to capture the video. The recording was made without the knowledge or permission of the court or the individuals present.

A resident of a residential building decided to install a video recording device that captured footage of the shared inner courtyard. This area was used by other residents and visitors. The resident did not inform or seek consent from the other individuals who might be recorded by this device. The recordings included activities and interactions of people in the courtyard, which was a common area shared by all residents.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of the public space outside the property. The individual did not obtain consent from people in the public space to record them.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of the public space outside the property. The individual intended to monitor their property for security reasons, but the cameras inadvertently recorded passersby and other activities occurring in the public space.

An individual installs a dashcam in their vehicle to record video footage while driving. The dashcam captures video of public spaces, including other vehicles and pedestrians. The individual does not obtain consent from those being recorded. The footage is used for personal surveillance purposes.

A store had security cameras installed to monitor the premises for security purposes. Due to a faulty configuration, the camera images, which included recordings of both employees and customers, were distributed to the public without the knowledge or intention of the store, which acted as the data controller.

A company installed live video surveillance cameras in a public area for security monitoring purposes. The footage from these cameras was accessible via the Internet. Due to insufficient pixelation or redaction, individuals captured in the footage could be recognized by anyone accessing the live stream online.
