However, the Ministry failed to implement adequate security measures to protect this data, making it vulnerable to unauthorized access. Additionally, the Ministry did not properly inform visa applicants that their personal data would be shared with other parties.

During the Covid-19 pandemic, Brussels Airport Charleroi and Brussels Airport Zaventem implemented a health screening process using thermal imaging cameras to identify individuals with body temperatures above 38 degrees. Those identified were then asked to complete questionnaires about possible coronavirus symptoms. The Ambuce Rescue Team was responsible for providing these questionnaires. The process aimed to ensure public health safety by identifying potential Covid-19 cases among passengers.

During the Covid-19 pandemic, Brussels Airport Charleroi implemented a system using thermal imaging cameras to monitor the body temperatures of individuals at the airport. Those with temperatures above 38 degrees Celsius were identified and required to answer questions about potential coronavirus symptoms. The airport aimed to use this data to manage public health concerns.

During the Covid-19 pandemic, Brussels Airport Zaventem implemented a system using thermal imaging cameras to monitor the body temperatures of passengers. Individuals with temperatures above 38 degrees Celsius were identified and subsequently required to answer questions regarding potential coronavirus symptoms. The airport aimed to use this data to protect public health by identifying and managing potential Covid-19 cases among travelers.

The Bank of Ireland experienced a series of data breaches, reporting 22 incidents to the Data Protection Authority (DPA). During these breaches, the bank mistakenly provided incorrect account data of its customers to the Central Credit Register. This mix-up had the potential to negatively affect the creditworthiness of the customers involved. The bank failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to prevent such breaches and did not promptly inform the affected data subjects or the DPA about the incidents.

An employee working as a language teacher at a private foreign language school was being constantly monitored by their employer during online courses via the platform 'Zoom'. The employee objected to this monitoring, but the employer continued the practice. Additionally, the employer did not properly inform the employee about the processing of their personal data.

Klarna Bank AB, a financial company, processes a large amount of personal data in various ways. On its website, Klarna did not provide sufficient information about the purpose and legal basis for processing personal data. Additionally, Klarna provided incomplete information about the recipients of personal data when transferring it to Swedish and foreign credit agencies. Klarna also failed to inform data subjects about third countries where their personal data is transferred. Furthermore, Klarna did not adequately inform data subjects about their rights under the GDPR.

Condor SA experienced a data breach where unauthorized individuals accessed documents containing personal data of employees and former employees. The data included sensitive information such as place of work, surname, first name, position, salary, and bank details.

A data subject requested copies of video surveillance recordings from Kaufland Romania SCS, in which they were visible. The data subject believed that these recordings were available and sought to obtain them from the controller.

A teacher, who is also a member of the English School staff union, accessed the email addresses of the parents of the students. These email addresses were originally collected for a specific purpose related to the students' education. However, the teacher used these email addresses for a different purpose, which was not the original intent of the data collection.

A teacher at the English School in Cyprus used the email addresses of students' parents for a purpose other than that for which the email addresses were originally collected. The school had collected these email addresses for specific purposes related to the students' education and communication with parents. However, the teacher used them for a different, unspecified purpose without obtaining the necessary consent or authorization from the parents.

An employee was participating in online courses offered via Zoom. The employer monitored these courses continuously. The employee objected to this monitoring, expressing a desire for it to stop. Despite the objection, the employer continued to monitor the employee's online course activities. The employer was unable to provide a sufficient legal basis for processing the employee's data.

The Danish National Genome Center conducted a data protection impact assessment which identified potential high risks to the rights of data subjects. Despite this, the center proceeded to process personal data without consulting the Danish Data Protection Authority (DPA) as required when high risks are identified.

PIKA Sp. z o.o., acting as a data processor for Fortum Marketing and Sales Polska S.A., was responsible for implementing changes in the IT environment. During this process, PIKA created an additional database containing Fortum's customer data. However, the server hosting this database lacked adequate security measures, leading to unauthorized access and data siphoning. Furthermore, PIKA failed to pseudonymize and encrypt the data and used real customer data instead of test data for system testing.
violated_articles: Article 25 - Data protection by design and by default

respondent: Fortum Marketing and Sales Polska S.A., Processing Agent
case_content: Fortum Marketing and Sales Polska S.A. engaged a processing agent to implement changes in its IT environment. During this process, an additional customer database was created. However, the server hosting this database lacked adequate security measures, allowing unauthorized persons to access customer data. The processing agent used real customer data instead of test data for system testing and failed to pseudonymize and encrypt the data.

BREBAU GmbH, a housing association, collected and processed data from over 9,500 potential tenants. The data included sensitive information such as skin color, ethnic origin, religious affiliation, sexual orientation, and health status. BREBAU GmbH did not have a valid legal basis for processing this data and ignored requests from data subjects for transparency about the processing of their data.

A community decided to publish information about a court case on its website. This publication included personal data such as the name and professional information of an individual involved in the case. The community aimed to share this information with the public, making it accessible to anyone visiting the website.

The Region of Tuscany was in the process of hiring administrative assistants and had organized a pre-selection test for applicants. Scanshare S.r.l. was entrusted with organizing this test. During the process, an error occurred on the part of Scanshare, leading to the inadvertent publication of a URL. This URL allowed public access to the personal data and test results of 3,548 applicants who had applied for the positions.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: The Region of Tuscany, acting as a data controller, inadvertently published personal data of 3,548 applicants for administrative assistant positions. This data was shared by the applicants as part of a pre-selection test for the application process. The region mistakenly published a URL through which personal data and the results of the test could be accessed by the public.

respondent: Azienda socio sanitaria territoriale Melegnano e della Martesana
case_content: A healthcare provider, Azienda socio sanitaria territoriale Melegnano e della Martesana, mistakenly included the medical records and clinical documentation of one patient in the digital medical record of another patient. This error resulted in the unintended disclosure of sensitive health information to an unauthorized individual.

Clearview AI, a U.S.-based company, owns a database containing over 10 billion facial images from around the world. The company offers a search service that allows profiles to be created based on the biometric data extracted from these images. These profiles can be enriched with additional information such as image tags and geolocation. Despite initial claims, Clearview AI enabled searches of Italian nationals and residents, processing their personal data without a valid legal basis.
violated_articles: Article 5(1)(a) - Principle of lawfulness, fairness and transparency

case_content: A concert hall, Hörpu tónlistar- og ráðstefnuhúss ohf., collected ID numbers and dates of birth from customers as part of an electronic ticket purchase process. This occurred before the Covid-19 pandemic, at a time when such data collection was not required for contact tracking purposes. The concert hall believed this information was necessary for the transaction.

An individual, acting as a data subject, submitted a request for information to Operatorul Briza Land S.R.L., a data controller. The request was made to obtain specific information regarding the processing of their personal data. The data controller was expected to respond to this request in a timely and appropriate manner, as per the obligations under the GDPR.

A company continued to keep the email account of a former employee active after the termination of their employment. The company did not provide sufficient information to the former employee regarding the status of their email account or the reasons for keeping it active.

Between June 7, 2018, and December 4, 2018, Meta Platforms Ireland Limited, formerly known as Facebook Ireland Limited, experienced twelve data breaches. These breaches involved the personal data of EU users. Meta, as the data controller, was responsible for implementing appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect this data. However, during this period, Meta failed to demonstrate that it had taken such measures, leading to the exposure of personal data.

A retail company, acting as a data controller, experienced a breach of personal data when its employees recorded video surveillance footage using their mobile phones without authorization. This footage was subsequently leaked to social media and other media outlets. The company had implemented certain measures such as internal acts on access to video surveillance footage, employee education, and confidentiality statements. However, these measures were insufficient to prevent the unauthorized recording and disclosure of the footage.

The energy company, which owns petrol stations, sells fuel to customers. A customer filed a complaint about inaccurate measuring and charging of fuel at one of the petrol stations. The customer requested a copy of their personal data, specifically the video surveillance footage from a specific time and area. The energy company rejected the request, citing the lack of a written request from competent authorities, lack of a justified purpose for the request, and the claim that providing the footage would adversely affect the rights and freedoms of the station's personnel and other customers. Later, the company informed the customer that the footage could not be provided as it was erased after seven days.

A private individual observed potential violations of the Road Traffic Regulations and decided to document these by taking photos of the vehicles involved and, in some cases, their drivers. The individual then sent these photos via email to the city of Magdeburg to report the violations. However, the emails were sent in an unencrypted form, potentially exposing the personal data of the drivers.

WORLDWIDE CLASSIC CARS NETWORK S.L. installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of both their premises and parts of the public space. The company did not provide adequate information to individuals about the presence and purpose of the CCTV cameras.

Customers of DPG Media Magazines B.V. wanted to exercise their rights under GDPR to access or delete their personal data. To process these requests, the company required customers to upload or send in proof of identity. This requirement was seen as an excessive hurdle for customers trying to exercise their data protection rights.

A customer of a medical clinic requested access to his medical records. The clinic did not provide the requested information. Additionally, the clinic did not adequately inform its clients about the processing of their personal data, specifically failing to inform them about the extent to which it was acting as a data controller for patient data generated by its activities.

respondent: FRUTAS Y VERDURAS LOS CAMPEONES, S.L.
case_content: FRUTAS Y VERDURAS LOS CAMPEONES, S.L. installed a video surveillance system on their premises. However, they did not place any signs to inform individuals about the use of video surveillance. This lack of signage meant that individuals were unaware that they were being recorded when entering the premises.

A hotel operator installed video surveillance cameras that covered not only the hotel's premises but also extended to public spaces and parts of the hotel's pool area. The cameras were intended for security monitoring. However, the hotel operator did not adequately inform individuals about the presence and purpose of the CCTV cameras.

A former employee of Santander Bank Polska S.A. managed to gain unauthorized access to a database for electronic services. This breach allowed the former employee to access numerous Santander customers' data. Despite the high risk posed to the data subjects, the bank chose not to inform the affected customers about the data breach and stated that it would not comply with this obligation in the future.

MALAGATROM, S.L.U., a company operating in Spain, was required to comply with an order issued by the Spanish Data Protection Agency (DPA). The order was related to ensuring compliance with data protection regulations. However, MALAGATROM, S.L.U. failed to adhere to the order issued by the DPA, which led to further scrutiny by the regulatory authority.

A former employee of IAMSAT Muntenia SA discovered that the company continued to process their personal data, including their email address, after their employment contract ended in 2020. The former employee had explicitly stated their objection to the continued use of their personal data by the company or any third parties. Additionally, it was found that the company had not adequately informed its employees about the use of a video surveillance system at the workplace.

A client of the civil law firm 'Sabou, Burz & Cuc' shared their personal data with the firm for a specific purpose. However, the firm subsequently published this personal data in a WhatsApp group used by several lawyers of a bar association. The client had not given prior consent for their data to be shared in this manner or for this purpose.

A store owner installed CCTV cameras in their establishment to monitor the premises for security purposes. However, the store owner did not provide any information signs to inform customers and visitors about the CCTV surveillance in place. This lack of notification meant that individuals entering the store were unaware that they were being recorded by the CCTV system.

RESTATURANTE FUENTEBRO, S.C. installed CCTV cameras in their establishment to monitor the premises for security purposes. However, they did not provide any information signs to inform customers and visitors about the CCTV surveillance in place. This lack of notification meant that individuals entering the restaurant were unaware that they were being recorded.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras at their house. These cameras captured not only the individual's property but also extended to cover public spaces and neighboring properties. The signs indicating the presence of video surveillance were not clear and readable.

A data subject requested T.S.M. s.r.l. to delete their personal data and object to any future processing of their data. The company failed to comply with these requests, leading the data subject to file a complaint with the Italian Data Protection Authority.

A data subject was involved in a car accident on the premises of ΛΙΜΕΝΟΣ ΗΡΑΚΛΕΙΟΥ Α.Ε., an organization that operates a video surveillance system. The accident was recorded by the surveillance system. The data subject requested access to the recordings of the accident from the organization. However, the organization did not comply with this request.

The private club 'Ruian' installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of both the club's premises and the surrounding public space. The club did not provide adequate information to individuals about the data processing activities conducted through these cameras.

An employee at the health authority filed a complaint against A.S.L. Napoli 1 Centro. The health authority had published a press release on its website containing personal data of the employee and information about a disciplinary procedure. The health authority believed the publication was lawful because the data subject had already given this information to the press, which had published a report on the matter.

A private individual published images of another person in a bikini on a website without obtaining prior authorization. The images were originally uploaded by the data subject to the second-hand platform Vinted, where she was selling the bikini.

Amazon Road Transport Spain S.L. required drivers to provide certificates confirming the absence of criminal records as part of their hiring process. Amazon Road believed that these certifications were not subject to Article 10 of the GDPR.

A nursing care facility installed CCTV systems to monitor the premises for security purposes. However, the facility did not provide any signage or notification to inform residents, visitors, or staff about the presence and use of these CCTV systems. As a result, individuals within the facility were unaware that they were being recorded, and no consent was obtained for the collection of their personal data through video surveillance.

A data subject requested the deletion of their personal data from RECLAMADOR, S.L., a company that had been sending them SMS advertisements. The company confirmed the deletion of the data. However, the data subject continued to receive SMS advertisements from the company, indicating that their data had not been deleted as requested.

Etterforsker1 Gruppen AS, a company, conducted a credit check on an individual. The company accessed the individual's credit information without having a legal basis for doing so. The individual was not informed or did not provide consent for this credit check.

A company experienced a data breach and was required to provide further information to the supervisory authority. The company failed to respond to the requests for additional information within the stipulated time frame. This delay in communication hindered the authority's ability to assess the breach and its impact on data subjects.

A health department in Italy used an app to manage Covid-19 screening data. The app generated QR codes for individuals tested for Covid-19, using a progressive criterion rather than a random one. This method assigned each person a number, making it possible for unauthorized individuals to alter a digit and access another person's profile and personal data.

A data subject submitted a request to a data controller to access their personal data. The data controller failed to respond to this request within the time frame specified by the GDPR. The data subject was expecting to receive their personal data in a timely manner, as per their rights under the GDPR.

A professor applied for a position at Università Telematica Internazionale Uninettuno and submitted his CV as part of the application process. The university subsequently published the CV without redacting certain personal data that pertained to the professor's personal sphere.

Azienda Sanitaria Locale Frosinone, a medical facility, developed a privacy policy for handling patient data. The policy outlined several purposes for processing personal data but failed to clearly indicate the legal bases for these purposes. In cases where legal bases were mentioned, they were often incorrect or contradictory. Additionally, the policy did not provide adequate information regarding the storage periods for the collected data.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data
Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: A former customer of FCA Italy s.p.a. contacted the company's customer service regarding a malfunction of the instruments in one of his vehicles. Following this interaction, the customer requested the transcripts of the telephone conversations he had with the customer service, as well as any documents related to his case. However, FCA Italy s.p.a. did not comply with this request.
violated_articles: Article 15 - Right of access by the data subject

case_content: A customer of Ubi Banca spa received a letter from the bank. The envelope of the letter had the phrase 'anomalous credit Chieti' written on it. The letter itself contained information about the transparency of banking and financial services, but did not include any payment reminders. The phrase on the envelope could potentially reveal information about the customer's financial situation to third parties.

PINTODIS, S.L., a company, installed several video cameras in their workplace. These cameras covered areas including food areas and changing rooms, capturing footage of their employees. The company intended to monitor the workplace for security and operational purposes.

A private individual attended a court trial and recorded audiovisual material of the proceedings. The material included footage of witnesses and parties involved in the trial. The individual then published this material on Twitter, making it accessible to the public without obtaining consent from the individuals who appeared in the footage.

A cafe installed CCTV cameras for security purposes. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they not only captured footage within the cafe premises but also recorded the public space outside the cafe. This setup led to the collection of video footage of individuals who were merely passing by or present in the public space outside the cafe.

Fraudsters contacted TELEFÓNICA MÓVILES ESPAÑA, S.A.U. pretending to be legitimate customers. They requested copies of the customers' SIM cards. Once they obtained the SIM cards, they used them to conclude contracts and perform various financial transactions at the expense of the actual customers.

Two customers of XFERA MÓVILES, S.A. were victims of identity fraud. Fraudsters contacted Xfera, pretending to be the customers, and requested copies of their SIM cards. Xfera issued the SIM cards without properly verifying the identity of the requesters. This allowed the fraudsters to conclude contracts and perform financial transactions at the expense of the actual customers.

Fraudsters contacted Orange Espagne S.A.U. pretending to be legitimate customers and requested copies of their SIM cards. Orange Espagne did not adequately verify the identity of these individuals before issuing the SIM cards. As a result, the fraudsters were able to conclude contracts and carry out various financial transactions at the expense of the actual customers.

Fraudsters contacted Orange España Virtual pretending to be legitimate customers and requested copies of their SIM cards. Orange España Virtual issued the SIM cards without properly verifying the identity of the requesters. This allowed the fraudsters to conclude contracts and carry out financial transactions at the expense of the actual customers.

Fraudsters contacted Vodafone España, S.A.U. pretending to be legitimate Vodafone customers. They requested copies of the customers' SIM cards. Vodafone issued the SIM cards without properly verifying the identity of the requesters. This allowed the fraudsters to conclude contracts and perform various transactions at the expense of the actual customers.

ASL Latina, a healthcare provider, was responsible for handling sensitive health data of its patients. During the course of its operations, ASL Latina mistakenly sent documents containing health data of a patient to an uninvolved third party. This incident involved the unauthorized disclosure of sensitive personal information, which was not intended for the recipient.

respondent: SEGURCAIXA ADESLAS, S.A. DE SEGUROS Y REASEGUROS
case_content: The data subject, who had registered in the Robinson advertising exclusion list to avoid receiving marketing communications, continued to receive marketing emails from SEGURCAIXA ADESLAS, S.A. DE SEGUROS Y REASEGUROS. Despite the data subject's request for their data to be deleted, the emails persisted.

A business owner installed video surveillance cameras around their premises for security purposes. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of individuals in adjacent public spaces, such as sidewalks and streets. The business owner did not obtain explicit consent from individuals who were recorded in these public areas. The footage was monitored by security personnel to ensure the safety of the business premises.

IAB Europe developed the Transparency & Consent Framework (TCF) to help organizations comply with the GDPR when using the OpenRTB protocol for real-time bidding in online advertising. When users visit a website for the first time, they are presented with an interface to consent to data collection and sharing. The TCF includes a consent management tool that records user preferences in a TC string, which is then shared with partners in the OpenRTB system. This allows advertisers to see what data processing users have consented to. However, IAB Europe did not provide adequate information to users about the TCF's functioning, and it failed to maintain necessary GDPR compliance measures.

In response to the Covid-19 pandemic, a restaurant implemented a system where visitors were required to enter their contact information on an open list. This list was displayed in a manner that allowed anyone, including unauthorized third parties, to access the data. The intention was to facilitate contact tracing efforts.

In response to the Covid-19 pandemic, a restaurant implemented a system where visitors were required to enter their contact information on an open list. This list was displayed in a manner that allowed anyone, including unauthorized third parties, to access the data. The intention was to facilitate contact tracing efforts.

In response to the Covid-19 pandemic, a restaurant implemented a system requiring visitors to enter their contact information on an open list. This list was displayed in a manner that allowed anyone to view the information, potentially exposing it to unauthorized third parties.

ASESORES DE SEGURIDAD PRIVADA, S.L., a company, was processing personal data of individuals. However, the company did not provide sufficient information to the data subjects about how their data was being processed. This lack of transparency led to concerns about whether the data subjects were adequately informed about the data processing activities.

An individual booked and attended a course with Company A but did not pay the course fees. Later, the individual registered for a course at Company B, which is part of the same parent company as Company A, and was rejected due to outstanding arrears with Company A. The companies shared a common database, which led to the sharing of the individual's arrears information between them.

A company operates an online marketplace where users can upload photos of worn underwear, advertising complete anonymity. Users, primarily women aged 18 to 50, upload photos taken with smartphones or other mobile devices. These devices often store metadata, such as GPS location, within the image files. The company does not remove this metadata before the photos are uploaded to the platform, allowing for precise localization of where the photos were taken.

A police officer attended an official presentation where personal data of individuals was displayed. The officer took photos of the presentation slides containing this personal data and shared them in a WhatsApp group with other members. The sharing of these photos was done without obtaining consent from the individuals whose data was captured in the photos.

A police officer attended an official presentation where personal data of individuals was displayed. The officer took photos of the presentation slides containing this personal data and shared them in a WhatsApp group with other members. The sharing of these photos was done without obtaining consent from the individuals whose data was captured in the photos.

A police officer attended an official presentation where personal data of individuals was displayed. The officer took photos of the presentation, which included this personal data, and subsequently shared these photos in a WhatsApp group. The group consisted of various members who were not authorized to access this personal data.

A police officer accessed a police database to gather information for private research purposes. The officer used their access privileges to retrieve personal data from the database, which is intended for official use only. The officer did not have the necessary authorization to use the data for personal research, and the individuals whose data was accessed were not informed or asked for consent.

A police officer, who has access to a police database, decides to use this access for personal reasons. The officer accesses the database to conduct private research, unrelated to any official police work or investigation. The officer does not seek or obtain authorization from the individuals whose data is accessed, nor is there any official purpose for this data access.

A police officer accessed a police database to gather information for private research purposes. The officer used their access privileges to retrieve personal data from the database, which is intended for official use only. The officer did not have the necessary authorization to use the data for personal research, and the individuals whose data was accessed were not informed or asked for consent.

A police officer accessed a police database to gather personal data for private research purposes. The officer used their access privileges to retrieve information not related to any official police work or investigation, but rather for personal interest or research. The data subjects were individuals whose personal data was stored in the police database.

Clearview AI Inc., a company specializing in facial recognition technology, collected and processed personal data from various sources. The Hamburg Data Protection Authority requested specific information from Clearview AI regarding their data processing activities. The request was part of an investigation into the company's compliance with data protection regulations. Clearview AI was expected to provide the requested information to the authority.

A data subject submitted a request to a data controller to access their personal data. The data controller failed to respond to this request within the time frame stipulated by the GDPR. The data subject expected a timely response to their request, as per their rights under the GDPR.

A medical assistant working at a doctor's office stored a patient's telephone number in her personal mobile phone. She then used this number to contact the patient for reasons unrelated to her professional duties, specifically for private purposes.

The operator of a ballet school decided to showcase the activities and achievements of their students by publishing photos on their official website and Facebook page. These photos included images of underage students participating in various ballet performances and classes. The school did not obtain consent from the legal guardians of these students before making the photos publicly available online.

A company installed an extensive video surveillance system throughout its premises, including areas where employees and visitors typically expect privacy. The surveillance system continuously recorded video footage, capturing all movements and activities of individuals within the premises. The company justified the use of this surveillance system as necessary for security monitoring. However, the extent and coverage of the surveillance were not proportionate to the security needs, leading to concerns about excessive data collection.

An employee working at a Covid-19 testing center accessed the personal data of an individual who had been tested at the center. The employee used this data, specifically the contact information, to reach out to the individual via WhatsApp. The contact was made for private purposes, unrelated to the individual's testing or any official business of the testing center.

Company XYZ installed a comprehensive video surveillance system throughout its premises, including areas where employees and visitors typically expect privacy, such as break rooms and restrooms. The surveillance was continuous and recorded all activities without any specific incidents or threats justifying such extensive monitoring. Employees and visitors were not adequately informed about the extent of the surveillance, nor was their explicit consent obtained. The company claimed the purpose of the surveillance was for security monitoring, but the scope and scale of the surveillance exceeded what was necessary for this purpose.

In several instances, police officers accessed data stored in a police database. The data was accessed for purposes unrelated to their official duties, specifically for private research. The officers used their credentials to log into the system and retrieve personal data of individuals without any official authorization or consent from the data subjects.

B&T S.p.A. contracted Aimon Srl to send promotional SMS messages to potential customers. Aimon then contracted other providers to carry out the task. These providers obtained the data from unverified and illegal lists of foreign companies, which included information from registrations on information portals or online gambling sites.

respondent: B&T S.p.A., Marketing Company, Other Providers
case_content: B&T S.p.A. contracted a marketing company to send promotional SMS messages to potential customers. The marketing company further engaged other providers, who acquired their databases from third parties. These third parties obtained the data from unchecked and illegal lists of foreign companies, with some information coming from registrations on information portals or online sweepstakes.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject
Article 14 - Information to be provided where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject

case_content: Cosmote, a telecommunications provider, experienced a data breach where a hacker accessed their systems due to insufficient security measures. The breach resulted in the unauthorized access and leakage of sensitive information, including age, gender, and contract details of nearly 10 million Cosmote subscribers. OTE Group, a subsidiary of Cosmote, was responsible for contributing to Cosmote's security infrastructure.

Cosmote Mobile Telecommunications S.A. experienced a data breach where a hacker penetrated their systems and accessed sensitive information of nearly 10 million customers. The data included age, gender, and contract information. Cosmote had not implemented adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure proper data anonymization, did not conduct a sufficient data protection impact assessment, and failed to properly inform data subjects about the processing of their data. Additionally, there was a lack of clear regulation regarding the allocation of roles in data processing with its subsidiary, OTE Group.

In 2018, the NGO EU DisinfoLab conducted an analysis to identify the possible political origin of tweets related to the 'Benalla affair' in France. The organization processed data from 55,000 Twitter accounts, classifying over 3,300 as political. The raw data, which included sensitive information such as political affiliation, religious beliefs, ethnic origin, and sexual orientation, was published without pseudonymization or other security measures.
violated_articles: Article 5 (Principles relating to processing of personal data)
Article 9 (Processing of special categories of personal data)

case_content: In 2018, the NGO EU DisinfoLab conducted an analysis to identify the possible political origin of tweets related to the 'Benalla affair' in France. The organization processed data from 55,000 Twitter accounts, classifying over 3,300 as political. The raw data, which included sensitive information such as political profiling, religious beliefs, ethnic origin, and sexual orientation, was published without pseudonymization or other security measures.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data
Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: INCOPROSOL, S.L., a company, engaged in a practice where they recorded telephone conversations with their customers. During these interactions, the company did not obtain explicit consent from the customers to record the conversations. The purpose of these recordings was related to customer service operations.

Cyrana España General S.L., a service provider, sent an invoice to an individual. However, there was no existing contractual relationship between the service provider and the individual, which means the individual had not agreed to any services that would warrant the issuance of an invoice.

In a residential building complex, the management decided to install CCTV cameras for security purposes. The cameras were placed in common areas such as hallways, entrances, and parking lots. The footage captured by these cameras was accessible to the building's security personnel for monitoring purposes. However, the management did not obtain explicit consent from all the property owners or residents before installing the cameras. The residents were not informed about the extent of surveillance or the specific purposes for which the footage would be used.

SC Grupex 2000 SRL, a company, uploaded videos of patients on its website. These videos were accessible to the public, and there was no indication that the patients had given their consent for their videos to be shared in this manner.

A lawyer, representing a client in criminal proceedings, disclosed documents containing personal data of the client to the court and opposing counsel. The disclosure was made without obtaining the necessary authorization from the client.

A company continued to keep a former employee's email account active after the termination of their employment. The company set up an automatic forwarding system for incoming emails to ensure business continuity. However, the company did not provide sufficient information to the former employee about this practice.

Centro di Medicina preventiva s.r.l., a medical center, experienced a cyberattack by a hacker group. During this attack, the hacker gained unauthorized access to a database containing patient data, including sensitive information and radio-diagnostic tests. The hacker subsequently published this data on Twitter. The medical center's server was configured in a way that allowed unauthenticated external connections, which facilitated the data breach.

The Uppsala regional board and hospital board were involved in transmitting sensitive personal health data and personal identity numbers via email. Although the actual transmission of the emails was encrypted, the information within the emails was not. These emails contained patient data that was automatically sent to health administrators within the region and manually sent to researchers and physicians. The data was transferred to recipients both inside and outside Sweden.

A motor insurance center requested patient data from healthcare providers to process insurance claims. The data included patient visit notes, which were used to verify whether healthcare providers billed for visits unrelated to the treatment of injuries from accidents. The Finnish Motor Insurance Act requires that only necessary information for claim processing be accessed.

A travel agency collected personal data from its customers, including names, contact details, and passport numbers, for the purpose of processing visa applications. However, the agency failed to secure this data, resulting in the information being publicly accessible on their web server. Additionally, the agency did not comply with a customer's request to delete their personal data from its systems.

A patient at Azienda USL di Parma accessed her medical records and discovered that they contained two diagnostic test reports belonging to other patients. This incident occurred due to an error in the handling of medical records by the healthcare provider.

Limerick City and County Council implemented various surveillance technologies, including video surveillance systems, automatic license plate recognition, and body-worn cameras, to monitor individuals for traffic management purposes. However, the Council did not provide adequate information to the public regarding the identity of the data controller, contact details of the data protection officer, purposes of data processing, and other required information. Additionally, the Council did not make this information easily accessible, such as on signs near the cameras or on their website. Furthermore, the Council denied requests from individuals seeking access to their personal data processed by these surveillance systems.

A property manager sent a copy of the general meeting minutes to the director of a security company. The document contained sensitive information such as the names and addresses of residents, a list of defaulters, and the community's financial accounts. The stated purpose of sending the minutes was to inform the security company about the members of the Board of Directors appointed at the general meeting.

A website operator launched a website that collects personal data from its visitors. However, the website did not provide a privacy policy to inform visitors about how their personal data would be used, stored, or shared. This lack of transparency led to concerns about the protection of personal data and the rights of the data subjects visiting the website.

An individual visited the premises of Kaufland Romania SCS and later requested access to video recordings capturing their presence in the store for a specific period. The individual sought a complete copy of these recordings, exercising their right of access under data protection laws.

Enel Energia S.p.A, a company, engaged in telemarketing activities where they processed the personal data of millions of users. Users received unsolicited promotional calls, sometimes even recorded, in the name of and on behalf of Enel Energia. Some users continued to receive advertising calls despite having requested the deletion of their personal data or objected to their processing for advertising purposes. Enel Energia did not provide timely feedback to users on their requests to exercise their rights of access and opposition.

A data subject discovered a database on a website owned by PHARMA TALENTS, S.L.U. that contained personal data about himself and other health sector professionals. The database included email addresses and telephone numbers and was freely accessible without any security measures such as a username or password.

A company installed a video surveillance system to ensure that their customers would not have to wait when their front desk staff was not present. However, the cameras also constantly captured parts of two employees' work areas. The company did not properly inform its employees and third parties about the video surveillance.

The data subject received a call from GARLEX SOLUTIONS, S.L. regarding the renewal of their electricity supply contract. Following the call, the data subject received an SMS containing a link to a contract for electricity supply, which already included their personal data. The data subject was unable to determine how the company had obtained their personal data, as they had not provided it nor consented to its processing.

A company installed a video surveillance system with the intention of protecting its assets, preventing unauthorized intrusions, and preventing accidents. The cameras, however, also captured footage of areas where employees worked, a smoking area frequently used by employees, and parts of the public space. The company did not adequately inform its employees and third parties about the video surveillance.

A private individual residing in an apartment building decided to install video cameras in the building. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they recorded the common areas used by all residents. The individual did not obtain consent from the other residents for this surveillance.

MEETING PUERTO C.B. published a picture of an individual and their partner on Facebook and Instagram. The picture was accompanied by comments that were insulting in nature. The individuals in the picture did not provide consent for their image or the accompanying comments to be shared on these platforms.
violated_articles: Article 10 - Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences

case_content: A homeowner installed a CCTV camera on their property for security purposes. However, the camera was positioned in such a way that it also captured footage of a neighboring property, including private spaces such as the neighbor's backyard. The neighbor was not informed about the camera's presence nor was their consent obtained for the recording of their private space.

A data subject discovered that two telephone connections were registered in their name with VODAFONE ESPAÑA, S.A.U. However, the data subject had never signed any contracts with the company for these connections. The contracts were fraudulently concluded by individuals using the personal data of the data subject. Despite this, the personal data were entered into the company's information systems without verifying the authenticity of the contracts or whether the data subject had consented to the collection and processing of their personal data.

C-Planet (IT Solutions) Limited was involved in processing personal data of individuals. During this process, they failed to obtain the necessary consent and did not provide adequate information to the data subjects about the processing of their data. Additionally, they did not implement appropriate security measures to protect the data, which led to a data breach. Furthermore, they did not notify the affected individuals or the relevant authorities about the breach in a timely manner.

The Lisbon City Council, in an effort to ensure that various departments and offices within the municipality, as well as third parties, could properly perform their public duties, sent out 111 notifications about demonstrations. These notifications included sensitive data of the demonstrators and organizers, such as their political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, and sexual orientation. The data was shared with multiple entities without informing the data subjects, without a policy for data retention, and without conducting a data protection impact assessment.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: A bank appointed an individual to serve as its Data Protection Officer (DPO). In addition to his responsibilities as the DPO, this individual also held the position of head of a department within the bank. This department was one to which he was required to report in his capacity as the DPO. This dual role created a potential conflict of interest, as the DPO was responsible for overseeing data protection compliance while also being part of the management of a department that he needed to monitor.

An employee of Società H San Raffaele Resnati s.r.l. mistakenly sent medical records and clinical documentation of two patients to another patient. This error occurred during the handling of patient data within the healthcare provider's operations.

respondent: Casa di cura Fondazione Gaetano e Piera Borghi s.r.l.
case_content: Casa di cura Fondazione Gaetano e Piera Borghi s.r.l., a nursing home, experienced a cyber attack where a hacker gained unauthorized access to personal data. The hacker published radiological images of patients on their Twitter account. The nursing home had secured the data with simple passwords.

Società Med Store Saronno s.r.l., a nursing home, experienced a cyber attack where a hacker gained unauthorized access to their systems. The hacker was able to access and publish personal data, including radiological images of patients, on a public platform like Twitter. The nursing home had only used simple passwords to secure the data, which were insufficient to protect against such attacks.

A citizen attempted to log into the Greek Ministry of Tourism's online platform using their credentials. Upon doing so, they were shown another individual's personal information, including full name, tax number, social security number, postal address, phone number, email address, and disability status. The Ministry had not implemented adequate technical and organizational measures to protect personal data. Additionally, the Ministry had not appointed a data protection officer, despite providing an inactive email address for such a role on the platform.

A private individual installed video surveillance cameras that captured footage of public spaces. The cameras were intended for monitoring purposes, but the individual did not inform the people being recorded about the data processing activities.

respondent: REWE International AG, Unser Ö-Bonus Club GmbH
case_content: REWE International AG, a company operating in Austria, along with its subsidiary 'Unser Ö-Bonus Club GmbH', was involved in handling personal data of its customers. The company collected and processed personal data as part of its business operations. However, the manner in which the data was handled raised concerns regarding compliance with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). The specific details of the data processing activities, such as the type of data collected, the purposes for which it was used, and whether proper consent was obtained, were not disclosed. The case highlights the importance of adhering to data protection principles and ensuring transparency and accountability in data processing activities.

Two employees of the Irish Teaching Council accessed a phishing email, which led to the setup of an automatic forwarding system from their email accounts to a malicious email account. This resulted in 323 emails being forwarded to the unauthorized external email address over a period of time. These emails contained the personal data of 9,735 data subjects and the sensitive personal data of one data subject.

INFO COMMUNICATION SERVICES conducted advertising calls to individuals. During these calls, the company used personal data of the individuals. However, the company did not obtain consent from these individuals for such calls. Additionally, the company failed to properly inform the individuals about how their personal data was being processed.
violated_articles: Article 12 - Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject
Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: PLUS REAL ADVERTISEMENT conducted advertising calls to individuals. During these calls, they used personal data of the individuals without obtaining their consent. Additionally, they failed to properly inform the individuals about how their personal data was being processed.

Warsaw University of Technology developed an application for course registration and management, which was used by students and faculty. In January 2020, an unauthorized person accessed and downloaded a database from this application, which contained personal data of over 5,000 individuals, including students and faculty. The university had not conducted a formal risk assessment nor implemented adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure data security.

EDUCANDO JUNTOS SL, a company, published photos of one of its employees on its social media channels and website. The employee, who is the data subject, did not give consent for the publication of these photos. Despite the employee's repeated requests to remove the photos, the company did not comply.

A car owner received a fine for non-payment of a toll and exercised his right to information under the GDPR. He requested the photographic material and documentation related to the incident from Εγνατία Οδός Α.Ε., the company operating the video surveillance system. The company initially refused to provide the requested information to the car owner.

Facebook Ireland Ltd operated a website where cookies were used to collect data from Internet users. The website provided a button to accept cookies with a single click, but rejecting cookies required several clicks. This design choice led to users more frequently accepting cookies out of convenience, impacting their freedom of consent.
violated_articles: Article 82 of the French Law on Informatics and Freedoms

case_content: Google Ireland Ltd operated websites google.fr and youtube.com, where cookies were used to collect data from users. The websites provided a button to accept cookies with a single click, but rejecting cookies required multiple clicks. This design choice led to users more frequently accepting cookies out of convenience, impacting their freedom of consent.
violated_articles: Article 82 of the French Law on Informatics and Freedoms

case_content: GOOGLE LLC operated websites google.fr and youtube.com, where cookies were used to collect data from users. The websites provided a button to accept cookies with a single click, but rejecting cookies required several clicks. This design choice led to users more frequently accepting cookies out of convenience, impacting their freedom of consent.
violated_articles: Article 82 of the French Law on Informatics and Freedoms

case_content: A customer of Telekom Romania Communications SA received invoices and messages intended for another person, indicating payment arrears. The company mistakenly collected and processed the customer's personal data, leading to the disclosure of another individual's payment information. Additionally, the company failed to comply with the customer's request to delete his personal data.

A data subject, who is a customer of the mobile operator TIM S.p.A., needed access to his phone data to defend himself in a criminal case. He made repeated requests to the company to obtain this data but received no response. As the hearing in the criminal proceedings approached, he turned to the Italian Data Protection Authority (DPA) to help him obtain the necessary data.

The municipality of Collegno implemented a system developed by ICA s.r.l. to allow citizens to pay fines for traffic violations. The system, however, lacked adequate security measures, making it possible for unauthorized individuals to access personal data stored within the program.

Elektro & Automasjon Systemer AS, a company, decided to perform a credit check on an individual. The company contacted a credit check agency to obtain the individual's credit information. The individual was not informed about this credit check, and no consent was obtained from them for this purpose.

In a call shop managed by an individual, a job vacancy was announced. To facilitate the application process, the manager set up a stand where job applicants could submit their application documents. However, applicants were required to pay a fee of one euro to submit their documents. During this process, the manager did not provide proper information to the applicants regarding how their personal data would be processed.

FREEE MOBILE, a service provider, was involved in a scenario where it failed to respond to its customers' requests regarding their personal data in a timely manner. Customers had exercised their right to object to receiving advertisements, but the company continued to send them marketing communications. Additionally, the company did not implement adequate security measures to protect personal data, as evidenced by sending passwords in clear text via email.

REAL CLUB NÁUTICO DE RIBADEO, a data controller, uploaded links to court decisions containing personal data of an individual on its website and Facebook page. This action made the personal data accessible to the public, including website visitors and Facebook users.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: A corporate website was launched to provide information and services to its users. However, the website did not display a privacy policy on its main page. This omission meant that users visiting the website were not informed about how their personal data would be collected, used, or protected. The absence of a privacy policy raised concerns about transparency and the website's compliance with data protection regulations.

A data subject received unsolicited SMS messages from Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria S.A. regarding non-payments. The data subject did not have any contractual relationship with the bank. The bank claimed that the messages were sent due to human error by its employees.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: A customer of HUBSIDE IBÉRICA S.L. noticed that she was being charged for several services that she had not ordered. Concerned about these unauthorized charges, she decided to file a complaint with the Spanish Data Protection Authority (AEPD) to address the issue.

A customer of Sfam España General s.l. noticed that she was being charged for several services that she had not ordered. Concerned about these unauthorized charges, she decided to file a complaint with the Spanish Data Protection Authority (AEPD) to investigate the matter.

A private individual shared a video on Twitter that depicted a sexual assault by a man on a woman. The individual shared the video with the intention of raising awareness about domestic violence against women.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: LA OFICINA BAR installed a video surveillance system to monitor its premises. However, the cameras were positioned in such a way that their observation angle extended beyond the bar's premises and into the public traffic area. This setup resulted in the recording of individuals passing by on the public street, capturing more data than necessary for the intended purpose of security within the bar.

CLUB DEPORTIVO RITMO DE ANDALUCÍA, a sports club, collects personal data from its members and participants for the purpose of managing memberships. However, the club's data protection notice does not provide sufficient information as required under GDPR Article 13. Additionally, the notice fails to offer an adequate opportunity for members and participants to give their consent to the processing of their personal data.

respondent: FUNDACION ESPANOLA DE MEDICINA ESTETICA Y LONGEVIDAD
case_content: FUNDACION ESPANOLA DE MEDICINA ESTETICA Y LONGEVIDAD, a foundation involved in aesthetic medicine and longevity, provided a data protection notice to individuals whose personal data they intended to process. However, the notice did not include all the necessary information required by the GDPR, such as the identity and contact details of the controller, the purposes of the processing, and the legal basis for the processing. Additionally, the notice failed to offer a clear and adequate opportunity for individuals to give their consent to the processing of their personal data.

A private individual, involved in a court case with another person, obtained a document containing health-related information about the other person. This individual then sent the document to the other person's employer without obtaining consent from the person whose health information was disclosed.

T. Stene Transport AS conducted a credit check on an individual without obtaining the necessary authorization. The company accessed the individual's credit information through a credit bureau for purposes related to assessing creditworthiness.

A data subject purchased a product from an online retailer's store via eBay and paid using PayPal. The product was delivered through Amazon, although the data subject had not consented to the transfer of their personal data to Amazon.

A private individual installed video cameras in a manner that allowed them to capture images of public spaces and the entrance to a residential building. The cameras were positioned such that they recorded not only the intended private property but also areas where residents and passersby could be seen.

One Way Private Company, a controller, made telephone calls to subscribers for advertising purposes. However, due to an error in their application, calls were made to individuals who were on a list meant to protect against unsolicited telephone advertising, known as 'Register 11'.

An employee of IZA OBRAS Y PROMOCIONES, S.A. was working as a construction manager on a project. During the project, the employee was absent from work for a period of time due to illness. The company, acting as the data controller, informed its client about the employee's absence and additionally disclosed the employee's email address and certain health information.

A customer visited an authorized repair shop of a car importer for a car inspection. After the inspection, the customer began receiving unsolicited emails from the car importer related to customer surveys. The emails did not contain any contact information of the car importer.

The municipality of Frederiksberg operated a system allowing parents to access their children's dental care letters online. This access was extended to parents with joint custody. Consequently, in several instances, parents were able to access information about the other parent and the child's address, despite the fact that the affected parent and child were registered with name and address protection.

A private individual installed a video surveillance system at their property to enhance security. The system captures video footage of visitors and passersby. However, the individual did not provide sufficient information to those being recorded about the presence of the surveillance system, the purpose of the recording, or how the data would be used or stored.

Vastaamo psychotherapy center experienced a data breach where an unauthorized third party accessed their patient database on at least two occasions. The breach was facilitated by an unprotected port and a root user account without a password, leaving the database open to the Internet without firewall protection. The attacker siphoned off data and left a ransom note. Vastaamo became aware of the data loss and potential compromise in March 2019 but delayed reporting the breach to the DPA and its patients.

A company was involved in an investigation conducted by the Austrian Data Protection Authority (DPA). During this investigation, the DPA requested specific information from the company. However, the company failed to provide the requested information to the DPA.

Grindr LLC, a location-based social networking app for gay, bi, trans, and queer people, shared users' personal data, including GPS location, IP address, cell phone advertising ID, age, and gender, with several third parties for marketing purposes. Users were required to accept the privacy policy to use the app, but were not explicitly asked for consent to share their data with third parties. The information about data disclosure was not clear or accessible. The data shared could identify users as members of a sexual minority, which is a special category of personal data requiring higher protection.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: A company, acting as a data controller, was requested by the Romanian Data Protection Authority (DPA) to provide specific information related to its data processing activities. The company was required to submit this information within a specified timeframe as part of a compliance check. However, the company failed to provide the requested information within the deadline set by the DPA.

Since 2016, the Norwegian State Pension Fund (SPK) collected certain income and health-related information from individuals receiving disability pensions. This information was not required for their operations. Approximately 24,000 individuals were affected. SPK did not implement routines to review and delete excessive information collected until 2019.

A company sent advertising emails to a consumer who had previously objected to the processing of their personal data and requested its deletion. Despite the consumer's objections, the company continued to send advertising content and did not adequately inform the consumer about the processing of their personal data.

In the context of processing applications for childcare benefits, the tax offices collected and processed data on the dual nationality of applicants. This data was used not only for assessing the applications but also for purposes such as combating organized fraud and automatic classification in the authority's risk system. Despite the lack of necessity for these purposes, the data on dual nationality was retained in the systems of the tax and customs administration for several years.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of Special Categories of Personal Data

case_content: An identity thief obtained personal data of a data subject without authorization and used it to apply for a loan from NBQ Technology, S.A.U. under the pretense of being the data subject. The company approved the loan based on the fraudulent application.

A store owner installed CCTV cameras in their establishment to monitor the premises for security purposes. However, the store owner did not provide any information signs to inform customers and visitors about the CCTV surveillance in place. This lack of signage meant that individuals entering the store were unaware that they were being recorded by the CCTV system.

Vehicle owners installed dashcams in their cars to record video footage while driving. These dashcams captured video of public spaces, including other vehicles and pedestrians. The footage was stored and sometimes shared without obtaining consent from the individuals who were recorded. The vehicle owners did not have a specific purpose for collecting this data, nor did they inform the individuals being recorded.

A group of vehicle owners installed dashcams in their cars to record their journeys. These dashcams captured video footage of public spaces, including images of pedestrians and other drivers. The vehicle owners did not obtain consent from the individuals captured in the footage. The dashcams were used continuously, recording various public interactions and movements without the knowledge or consent of those being recorded.

A data subject requested access to their personal data from a data controller. The data controller failed to comply with this request, leading to a situation where the data subject was unable to access their personal data.

An individual installs a dashcam in their vehicle to record video footage while driving. The dashcam captures video of public spaces, including other vehicles and pedestrians. The individual does not inform or obtain consent from those being recorded. The footage is used for personal purposes, such as reviewing driving incidents or sharing on social media.

An individual installs a dashcam in their vehicle to record video footage while driving. The dashcam captures video of public spaces, including pedestrians and other drivers, without their knowledge or consent. The individual uses the footage for personal purposes, such as reviewing driving incidents or sharing interesting clips online.

A driver installed a dashcam in their vehicle to record video footage while driving. The dashcam captured images and videos of pedestrians and other drivers on the road. The driver did not obtain consent from the individuals being recorded. The footage was used for personal purposes, such as reviewing driving incidents or sharing on social media.

COOPERA RC SERVICES, acting as a data controller, was responsible for managing personal data. Data subjects, who are individuals whose data is being processed, attempted to exercise their rights under the GDPR. However, they found that COOPERA RC SERVICES had not provided sufficient contact details through which they could effectively exercise these rights. This lack of adequate contact information hindered the data subjects' ability to communicate with the data controller regarding their personal data.

A data subject, who was a customer of Vodafone España, S.A.U., experienced an unauthorized transfer of her cell phone line to another person due to a technical error. Additionally, her account was debited with amounts that were related to a third party's phone line.

A data subject discovered that telephone lines were registered in his name without his consent or knowledge. He had never concluded any contracts with Vodafone España, S.A.U. for these lines. It was found that Vodafone had mistakenly assigned the data subject's personal information to the contracts of another customer, resulting in the contracts being registered under the data subject's name.

IMAGINA FRAN SPORT, S.L. operates a website that collects personal data from its users. The company has a privacy policy in place, but it contains outdated information. This means that the users of the website are not being provided with accurate and up-to-date information about how their personal data is being processed, as required by the GDPR.

A consumer, who had registered their contact information in the Robinson advertising exclusion list to avoid receiving unsolicited marketing communications, received advertising calls from a company named INTRODUCTION BUSINESS CAPITAL MEDIA, S.L. The consumer had not given consent to receive such calls, as they had explicitly opted out by registering in the exclusion list.

A patient of the Health Protection Agency of Sardinia (ATS) received medical records and clinical documentation that belonged to another patient. This occurred when the patient accessed their own file and found the incorrect documents included.

A physician recommended certain medical products to a patient as part of the patient's treatment. Subsequently, the patient received a call from a marketing consultant promoting the recommended products. The patient had not given consent for their personal data to be shared with third parties for promotional purposes.

On December 27, 2019, the Cabinet Office published a file on GOV.UK containing the names and uncensored addresses of more than 1,000 individuals who had received New Year's honors. This included individuals from various professions across the UK, some with high public profiles. After discovering the data breach, the Cabinet Office removed the web link to the file, but it remained accessible online through the cache for those with the exact website address. The personal data was available online for two hours and 21 minutes and was accessed 3,872 times. The breach was due to an error in the setup of the Cabinet Office's new IT system.

Anfiteatro Flavio s.r.l. manages a hotel where a video surveillance system with three cameras is installed. The system captures footage of hotel guests as part of the hotel's security measures. However, the hotel management does not provide sufficient information to the guests about the presence and operation of the CCTV system.

OTTO s.r.l. operates a store where a video surveillance system with three cameras is installed. The cameras are used to monitor the store for security purposes. However, OTTO s.r.l. did not provide sufficient information to customers and visitors about the presence of the CCTV system and the processing of their personal data.

UAB Prime Leasing, the operator of CityBee, a short-term car rental platform, experienced a data breach in February 2021. The breach involved the personal data of 110,302 CityBee users being published on a hacking forum, RaidForums.com. The data included names, addresses, phone numbers, email addresses, personal identification numbers, driver's license numbers, type of payment card, and the last four digits of the card number. The breach was traced back to an unsecured backup copy of a database. The company had not appointed a competent person for security and risk management, failed to log and evaluate access to database files, stored the database unencrypted, and used an insecure encryption algorithm for passwords.

respondent: ASOCIACIÓN ESPAÑOLA PARA LA ENSEÑANZA ONLINE
case_content: A data subject subscribed to a newsletter from ASOCIACIÓN ESPAÑOLA PARA LA ENSEÑANZA ONLINE. The data subject later objected to receiving further newsletters and requested the deletion of all personal data held by the controller. Despite this request, the data subject continued to receive advertisements from the data controller.

DAVISER SERVICIOS, S.L., a company, implemented a system to control access to certain rooms by processing the biometric data (fingerprints) of its employees. The company had the option to use less intrusive means, such as key cards, to achieve the same purpose of access control. The employees' biometric data was collected and processed for the purpose of managing access to specific areas within the company premises.

respondent: ASOCIACIÓN ESPAÑOLA PARA LA ENSEÑANZA ONLINE
case_content: A data subject subscribed to a newsletter from ASOCIACIÓN ESPAÑOLA PARA LA ENSEÑANZA ONLINE. The data subject later objected to receiving further newsletters and requested the deletion of all personal data. Despite this request, the data subject continued to receive advertisements from the data controller.

A neighborhood community decided to enhance security by installing video cameras on their private property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they captured not only the intended private areas but also extended their view to include public spaces and neighboring private properties. The community aimed to monitor and ensure the safety of their surroundings.

A consumer, who had registered their contact information in the Robinson advertising exclusion list to avoid receiving unsolicited marketing communications, received advertising calls from a company named TIGERS MARKET, S.L. The consumer had not given consent to TIGERS MARKET, S.L. to receive such calls, as they had explicitly opted out of advertising communications by registering in the exclusion list.

A company appointed a Data Protection Officer (DPO) to oversee the protection of personal data. However, the DPO was not involved in all matters related to data protection as required. Additionally, the DPO did not report directly to the highest management level, as there were two levels of hierarchy in between. The company also lacked a data protection control plan to ensure the DPO was performing their duties appropriately.

respondent: ΚΑΠΑ ΛΑΜΔΑ ΩΜΕΓΑ ΔΙΑΦΗΜΙΣΤΙΚΗ ΕΜΠΟΡΙΚΗ ΜΟΝΟΠΡΟΣΩΠΗ ΕΤΑΙΡΕΙΑ ΠΕΡΙΟΡΙΣΜΕΝΗΣ ΕΥΘΥΝΗΣ
case_content: A company named ΚΑΠΑ ΛΑΜΔΑ ΩΜΕΓΑ ΔΙΑΦΗΜΙΣΤΙΚΗ ΕΜΠΟΡΙΚΗ ΜΟΝΟΠΡΟΣΩΠΗ ΕΤΑΙΡΕΙΑ ΠΕΡΙΟΡΙΣΜΕΝΗΣ ΕΥΘΥΝΗΣ engaged in marketing activities by making calls to individuals. These calls were made without obtaining prior consent from the individuals. Despite several individuals revoking any previously given consent, they continued to receive unsolicited marketing calls from the company.

UNIÓN FINANCIERA ASTURIANA S.A. E.F.C., a financial institution, conducted a credit check on an individual. The credit check was performed without any contractual basis or proper authorization from the individual. The financial institution accessed the individual's credit information by communicating with a credit bureau.

respondent: Ministry of Industry and Innovation, YAY ehf.
case_content: In the summer of 2020, the Ministry of Industry and Innovation in Iceland launched a campaign to encourage domestic travel among Icelanders. As part of this campaign, a digital gift voucher was offered, which could be obtained through an app developed by the company YAY ehf. To participate in the voucher promotion, individuals were required to agree to the General Terms of Use of the YAY app. However, this process involved the collection of extensive personal information and access to users' phones.

respondent: Ministry of Industry and Innovation, YAY ehf.
case_content: In the summer of 2020, the Ministry of Industry and Innovation in Iceland launched a campaign to encourage domestic travel among Icelanders. As part of this campaign, a digital gift voucher was offered, which could be obtained through an app developed by the company YAY ehf. To participate in the voucher promotion, individuals were required to agree to the General Terms of Use of the YAY app. However, the process involved collecting extensive personal information and accessing users' phones. The information provided about the processing of personal data was insufficient, and there were no appropriate technical and organizational measures in place to ensure data security. Additionally, due to a configuration error by YAY, more data than necessary was processed.

A call center employee at Valoris Center S.R.L. accidentally sent an Excel file to a customer. This file contained personal data of other customers, including email addresses, usernames, user IDs, phone numbers, customer names, customer codes, and customer PINs. A total of 11,169 individuals were affected by this incident.

An individual was a customer of Vodafone España S.A.U. Her cell phone line was mistakenly transferred to a third party due to a technical error in Vodafone's systems. As a result, she was charged amounts from a third party phone line.

A data controller was approached by the Spanish Data Protection Authority (AEPD) to provide specific information for investigative purposes. The controller, however, failed to comply with this request, leading to further actions by the AEPD.

ANIVERSALIA NETWORKS, S.L. operates a website where users can access various services. As part of its operations, the company collects personal data from users visiting the website. The company has a privacy policy in place, which is intended to inform users about how their data is collected, used, and protected.
