Storstockholms Lokaltrafik equipped ticket inspectors with body-worn cameras to prevent threatening situations, document incidents, and ensure correct fines for passengers traveling without a valid ticket. The cameras were kept on for the entire shift, capturing video and audio of all passengers passing by the inspectors. This setup potentially monitored several hundred thousand people using public transportation in Stockholm daily.
violated_articles: Article 12 - Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject

case_content: UAB VS FITNESS, a sports club operator, required its customers and employees to scan their fingerprints to access services and for employee management purposes. Customers were not provided with alternative identification methods, making consent to fingerprint processing not truly voluntary. Additionally, the company did not clearly define the purpose and legal basis for processing employees' biometric data, nor did it conduct a data protection impact assessment. Furthermore, the company failed to comply with its obligation to provide necessary information to data subjects as required by GDPR.
violated_articles: Article 9 (Processing of special categories of personal data)
Article 13 (Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject)

case_content: PURPLE SEA ΜΟΝΟΠΡΟΣΩΠΗ ΙΚΕ, a company, installed a video surveillance system in its office premises. The system was set up to monitor the office environment, capturing video footage of the employees during their work hours. However, the employees were not informed about the installation and operation of this surveillance system. The company did not provide any notice or obtain consent from the employees regarding the collection and use of their personal data through video surveillance.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: Vejle municipality's dental care service sent automated welcome letters to both parents of children receiving treatment. These letters included the contact details of both parents. The municipality did not verify whether it was permissible to share this information with the other parent, leading to situations where parents received the address of the other parent, even if the other parent had name and address protection.

Funeda Sp. z o.o., a company operating as a data controller, was involved in a situation where the Polish Data Protection Authority (UODO) requested specific information from them as part of an ongoing investigation. The company was expected to provide the necessary information to the authority to comply with the investigation process.

La Santrade S.R.L., a company operating in Romania, was involved in a situation where the Romanian Data Protection Authority (DPA) requested specific information from the company as part of an ongoing investigation. The company was expected to provide the necessary information to the DPA to assist in the investigation process.

A company, acting as a data controller, collected personal data from individuals without providing them with accurate information about the data collection process. The individuals, who are the data subjects, were not informed about the specifics of the data being collected, the purpose of the collection, or any other necessary details as required by the GDPR.

A company appointed a Data Protection Officer (DPO) to oversee its data protection activities. However, the company did not involve the DPO in all matters related to the protection of personal data. Additionally, the company failed to provide the DPO with the necessary resources to perform their duties effectively. This lack of involvement and resources hindered the DPO's ability to ensure compliance with data protection regulations.

New patients, mostly children, were required to fill out a web form with mandatory fields for various personal data to sign up for an orthodontic clinic. The data entered into the form was transmitted to the clinic via an unencrypted connection, posing a risk of unauthorized access by third parties.

BRAbank ASA launched a new 'My Page' section on their website, intended for 500 selected customers. This section was designed to provide an overview of loans taken out with the bank. However, due to inadequate risk assessment and technical measures, some customers were able to view other customers' credit terms and address information.

The Östra Skaraborg Rescue Service installed surveillance cameras in several fire stations. These cameras recorded areas where firefighters changed clothes during emergencies. The surveillance was operational 24/7, although the stated requirement was only for emergency situations. The Rescue Service justified the surveillance with significant reasons but did not limit it to emergencies.

A data controller was approached by the Polish Data Protection Authority (UODO) to provide specific information necessary for an ongoing investigation. The controller, however, failed to comply with this request, which was part of the authority's efforts to ensure adherence to data protection regulations.

S.C. Dreamtime Call S.R.L., a company operating in Romania, was involved in a situation where the Romanian Data Protection Authority (DPA) requested specific information from the company as part of an ongoing investigation. The company was expected to comply with this request and provide the necessary information to the DPA.

respondent: Inera, Medhelp AB, Medicall Co Ltd., Voice Integrate Nordic AB
case_content: In Sweden, a national health advice hotline, reachable by dialing 1177, operates across all 21 regions. Each region manages its own service, either internally or through subcontractors. In 2019, it was discovered that recorded calls to the 1177 helpline were accessible on the internet without security measures. Calls from the Stockholm, Sörmland, and Värmland regions were routed by Inera to Medhelp AB, which further contracted Medicall Co Ltd. for handling calls during weekends and nights. Both Medhelp and Medicall had agreements with Voice Integrate Nordic AB for call recordings. A data breach occurred due to a misconfigured network-attached storage device at Voice Integrate, making the recordings publicly accessible.

respondent: MedHelp AB, Medicall Co Ltd., Voice Integrate Nordic AB
case_content: In Sweden, a national telephone hotline, 1177, provides health-related advice across all 21 regions. Each region manages its own service, either internally or through subcontractors. In 2019, it was discovered that recorded calls to the 1177 helpline were accessible on the internet without security measures. Calls from the Stockholm, Sörmland, and Värmland regions were routed to MedHelp AB, which subcontracted Medicall Co Ltd. for weekend and night calls. Both companies used Voice Integrate Nordic AB for call recordings. A data breach occurred due to a misconfigured network-attached storage device, making recorded calls publicly accessible online.

respondent: Region Stockholm, Medhelp AB, Medicall Co Ltd., Voice Integrate Nordic AB
case_content: In Sweden, a national health advice hotline, reachable by dialing 1177, is operated by each of the 21 regions either internally or through subcontractors. In 2019, it was discovered that recorded calls to this hotline were accessible on the internet without security measures. Calls from the Stockholm, Sörmland, and Värmland regions were initially managed by Inera and then routed to Medhelp AB, which had subcontracted Medicall Co Ltd. for handling calls during weekends and nights. Both Medhelp and Medicall had agreements with Voice Integrate Nordic AB for call recordings. A data breach occurred due to a misconfigured network-attached storage device belonging to Voice Integrate, making a large number of call recordings publicly accessible.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data
Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

respondent: Region Värmland, Medhelp AB, Medicall Co Ltd., Voice Integrate Nordic AB
case_content: In Sweden, a national health advice hotline, reachable by dialing 1177, operates across all 21 regions. Each region manages its own service, either internally or through subcontractors. In 2019, it was discovered that recorded calls to the 1177 helpline were accessible on the internet without security measures. Calls from the Stockholm, Sörmland, and Värmland regions were routed by Inera to Medhelp AB, which had contracted Medicall Co Ltd. for after-hours service. Both companies used Voice Integrate Nordic AB for call recordings. A misconfigured network-attached storage device at Voice Integrate led to the exposure of these recordings online.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

respondent: Region Sörmland, Medhelp AB, Medicall Co Ltd., Voice Integrate Nordic AB
case_content: In Sweden, a national health advice hotline, reachable by dialing 1177, operates across all 21 regions. Each region manages its own service, either internally or through subcontractors, forming a national network. In 2019, it was discovered that recorded calls to the 1177 helpline were accessible on the internet without security measures. Calls from the Stockholm, Sörmland, and Värmland regions were routed by Inera to Medhelp AB, which had subcontracted Medicall Co Ltd. for after-hours service. Both companies used Voice Integrate Nordic AB for call recordings. A data breach occurred due to a misconfigured network-attached storage device, making a large number of calls publicly accessible.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: A company installed a video surveillance system with the intention of protecting property, securing access to private and risky areas, ensuring the safety of users, and preventing accidents. However, the cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured excessive parts of the public space. Additionally, the company did not adequately inform individuals who were recorded by the surveillance system about the data processing activities.

A company installed a video surveillance system to protect its assets and prevent unauthorized entry. The cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured footage of the canteen area, where employees take their breaks. The company did not adequately inform the employees about the video surveillance and the processing of their data.

A company installed a video surveillance system to protect its assets and prevent unauthorized entry. The cameras were positioned in such a way that they also captured parts of the canteen terrace, which is used as a recreation area for employees. This setup resulted in the recording of employees during their breaks.

A company installed a video surveillance system to protect its assets and prevent unauthorized entry. The cameras, however, captured not only the company's premises but also parts of the public space. Additionally, the company stored the video recordings for a period longer than legally permitted.

Radiotelevisión del principado de Asturias installed a video surveillance system with 14 cameras to monitor their business premises for security purposes. However, the cameras were positioned in such a way that they captured areas not necessary for security, including employees' offices and a significant portion of the recreation room. Additionally, the employees were not properly informed about the data processing activities related to the video surveillance.

Master Distancia S.A. included the personal data of an individual in a credit report register. The company justified this action by claiming that the individual had outstanding debts with them. However, the matter was still under arbitration, and no final decision had been made regarding the alleged debts.

Creator Energy S.L., an energy provider, used the personal data of a customer to conclude contracts for gas and electricity supplies and a maintenance service. The customer did not provide consent for the use of their personal data for these purposes.

respondent: Italian National Institute for Social Security
case_content: The data subject submitted two requests to the Italian National Institute for Social Security, seeking information about the disclosure of their personal data to third parties. Initially, the data subject did not receive any response to these requests.

A client of Avalos Consultores, S.L. discovered that her personal data had been transferred to another agency, Torrent Asesores Nga, S.L., without her consent. The client was concerned about this unauthorized sharing of her personal information and decided to take action.

A telecommunications company booked a service for a customer without a contract. The customer did not pay for the service, leading to its cancellation. The company then transferred the customer's personal data to a collection agency to collect the alleged debt.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

respondent: Fondazione Policlinico Tor Vergata di Roma
case_content: In February 2020, a data subject attempted to book an appointment with a medical specialist through the online booking portal of Fondazione Policlinico Tor Vergata di Roma. The process required the data subject to fill out an online form requesting various personal data. However, the data subject was not adequately informed about how their personal data would be processed, and the controller had not implemented sufficient technical and organizational measures to protect the data.

A data subject requested the deletion of their personal data from ΚARIERA A.E., a company that had been sending them email advertisements. The company confirmed the deletion of the data. However, due to a technical error, the data subject continued to receive email advertisements from the company.

An organization installed video surveillance cameras in a public space to monitor activities. The cameras captured video footage of individuals without providing sufficient information about the surveillance to the public. The organization did not minimize the data collected, capturing more information than necessary for the intended purpose.

A private individual set up video surveillance cameras that captured footage of both private and public spaces. The individual then published these recordings online, making them accessible to the general public.

Innovasjon Norge, a national development bank, conducted several credit checks on an individual. During this process, the bank analyzed various financial data of the individual. However, there was no contractual basis or consent from the individual for these credit checks.

respondent: Municipal Organization for Pre-School Education and Social Solidarity (DOPAKA)
case_content: The Municipal Organization for Pre-School Education and Social Solidarity (DOPAKA) of the municipality of Tavros Moschato published documents containing personal data of an individual. These documents included the individual's name, profession, place of work, and an evaluation of their behavior. Subsequently, the individual requested the deletion of this information, but the organization did not respond to this request.

A data subject requested access to his personal data from TECNOMEDICAL S.r.l., specifically asking for a copy of his medical records and documentation related to his dental implant surgery. The data controller failed to provide the requested information in a timely and complete manner.

A company, acting as a data controller, was required to provide specific information to the Spanish Data Protection Authority (AEPD) within a designated timeframe. This request was part of the regulatory compliance process, where the authority sought to ensure that the company adhered to data protection obligations. The company failed to provide the requested information within the stipulated period.

A customer at a restaurant submitted a consumer complaint form because he was unable to converse at the table due to the volume of the music. The restaurant retained a copy of this form. However, due to an error by a restaurant employee, copies of the form were mistakenly given to other guests who were present during the incident.

Alava Norte, S.L. installed three 360° video surveillance cameras on the facade of one of its buildings. The purpose of these cameras was to secure the facility. However, the cameras also captured parts of the public space, recording individuals who were not within the premises of the facility.

A data subject, who was registered on the Robinson advertising exclusion list, received an advertising call from a company on behalf of Vodafone España, S.A.U. The call was made due to an error in the call number filtering system of Vodafone's commissioned processor. Vodafone had not established measures to prevent advertising calls to numbers on the Robinson list and was unaware that the data subject's number was on the list, resulting in the call not being blocked.

A data subject, in the course of his professional activities, made a telephone call to a company on September 23, 2019. The company recorded the conversation without informing the data subject or obtaining his consent. The recorded conversation was then made available to the company where the data subject was employed. The employer used the recorded conversation to evaluate the data subject's performance and subsequently terminated the employment relationship, as the conversation did not meet the company's service and professional standards.

A data subject, in the course of his professional activities, made a telephone call to a controller on September 23, 2019. The controller recorded the conversation without informing the data subject or obtaining his consent. The recorded conversation was then provided to the company where the data subject was employed. The employer used the recorded conversation to evaluate the data subject's performance, which led to the termination of his employment as the conversation did not meet the company's service and professional standards.

A data subject entered into a contract with a company. During the process, the managing director of the company collected personal data from the data subject. However, the data subject was not properly informed about how their data would be processed.

A physician left their former clinic and began working at a new clinic. The complainant took over the physician's former clinic. The purchase agreement between the physician and the complainant explicitly stated that the physician was not allowed to make a copy of the patient's files under any circumstances. Despite this, the physician contacted their former patients to inform them that they could obtain services at the new clinic.

The Irish Credit Bureau (ICB), a credit reporting agency, maintains a database of credit contract performance between financial institutions and borrowers. On June 28, 2018, the ICB made a code change to its database, which contained a technical error. This error led to the inaccurate updating of records for 15,120 closed accounts. Between June 28, 2018, and August 30, 2018, the ICB disclosed 1,062 inaccurate account records to financial institutions or affected individuals before resolving the issue.

The Municipality of Oslo published a subpoena from the public prosecutor's office on its website. This document contained personal information, including health data, about an individual. The subpoena was not initially classified as confidential, leading to its public disclosure. The document was accessible to the public for five hours before it was removed.

CP&A, an employer, documented the causes of illness and specific complaints of its employees as part of recording employee absences due to illness. This information was stored in an online system that was accessible without any form of authentication, allowing potentially unauthorized access to sensitive health data.

A data subject submitted a food subsidy application to the municipality of Palermo. Subsequently, the personal data from this application was acquired by an unauthorized person and processed for their own purposes. This occurred because the municipality failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure the security and confidentiality of the data processing.

A customer of Banca Comercială Română S.A. discovered that his personal data was used in an enforcement procedure related to debts from a credit agreement. The customer was unaware of this credit agreement and had not given consent for his data to be used in this manner. The bank proceeded with the enforcement process without informing the customer or obtaining the necessary authorization.

respondent: Asociație de Proprietari din municipiul Iași
case_content: The Romanian Data Protection Authority (DPA) requested specific information from the Owners Association of Iasi Municipality as part of a data protection inquiry. The association, acting as a data controller, was expected to provide the requested information to the DPA. However, the association failed to comply with this request, leading to further actions by the DPA.

A physician presented slides of a clinical case at a medical congress. These slides were later published on the website of the Società triveneta di chirurgia. The slides included personal data of a patient, such as the patient's initials, age, gender, detailed medical history, admission details from 1980 to 2016, surgical procedures with dates, the surgical department, hospital stay duration, numerous diagnostic images, and 22 photographs of the patient during surgeries. The patient had not consented to the processing of their personal data.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: A physician presented slides of a clinical case at a medical congress. These slides included personal data of a patient, such as initials, age, gender, detailed medical history, admission details from 1980 to 2016, surgical procedures with dates, the surgical department involved, hospital stay duration, numerous diagnostic images, and 22 photographs of the patient during surgeries. These slides were later published on the controller's website. The patient had not consented to the processing of their personal data.
violated_articles: Article 9 - Processing of special categories of personal data

case_content: Cyfrowy Polsat S.A., a data controller, contracted a courier company to handle postal correspondence containing personal data. However, there were numerous instances where the correspondence was either lost or delivered to the wrong recipient. Despite the breaches being caused by the courier company, Cyfrowy Polsat S.A. was responsible for ensuring the protection of the data. Additionally, the company delayed notifying the affected data subjects about the breaches, taking two to three months to do so.

A company, A. ΕΠΙΛΟΓΗ ΙΔΙΩΤΙΚΗ ΚΕΦΑΛΑΙΟΥΧΙΚΗ ΕΤΑΙΡΕΙΑ, collected personal data from an individual for a specific agreed purpose. The individual later requested information and deletion of their data. The company did not respond to these requests. Eventually, the company deleted the data but did not inform the individual. Additionally, the company collected the individual's data for a purpose other than the agreed one without obtaining the individual's consent for this new processing purpose.

The operator of a care facility installed 25 cameras throughout the facility, excluding restrooms, locker rooms, and the main nurses' station. The cameras recorded both residents and employees, with the stated purpose of enhancing security by preventing unauthorized access and deterring theft. However, the extent of the surveillance was questioned in terms of necessity for the stated security purpose, and there was insufficient information provided to the data subjects about the data processing activities.

respondent: Allianz Compañia de Seguros y Reaseguros, S.A.
case_content: In 2016, a data subject entered into a motorcycle insurance policy with Allianz Compañia de Seguros y Reaseguros, S.A. The following year, in 2017, the data subject terminated the policy. Despite the termination, Allianz sent an invoice to the data subject, indicating a continuation of communication without an existing contractual relationship.

A customer of Telekom Romania Communications SA exercised their right to object to the processing of their personal data for marketing and advertising purposes. They requested the deletion of their telephone number and email address from the company's database. Despite this request, the company made an advertising call to the customer.

During the Covid19 pandemic, a website named declaratieppr.ro allowed visitors to fill out a form that was required for them to leave their place of residence. The form collected personal data such as name, address, and ID number from the visitors. The website operator was responsible for processing this data.

The municipality of Castellanza uploaded documents on its website that contained personal data of an individual involved in legal proceedings. These documents were freely accessible to the public, leading to the exposure of the individual's personal data.

A data subject, who is a consumer, requested the deletion of their personal data from Solram T Y R S.L., a company acting as a data controller. Despite this request, the company continued to send advertisements to the data subject via WhatsApp.

respondent: Overijssel local branch of the PVV party
case_content: An email was sent by the Overijssel local branch of the PVV party to convene a meeting. Due to a human error, the email was sent via an open distribution list, addressing 101 recipients as 'Friends of the PVV'. This inadvertently disclosed the political beliefs of the recipients to each other.

EDP Energía, S.A.U. collected personal data from customers without properly informing them as required by GDPR. The company also engaged in business practices where contracts were concluded with customer representatives instead of the customers directly. However, EDP Energía did not verify whether these representatives were authorized to act on behalf of the customers.

EDP Comercializadora, S.A.U. engaged in business practices where they collected personal data from customers. However, they failed to inform the customers about their rights under GDPR when collecting this data. Additionally, the company allowed contracts to be concluded with customer representatives instead of directly with the customers. In these instances, EDP Comercializadora did not verify whether the representatives had the proper authorization to act on behalf of the customers.

InfoMentor ehf, a company providing an online system used by schools and other institutions for communication and information purposes, experienced a data breach. The breach occurred due to a security vulnerability in their system, where the six-digit system number of each user was visible in the URL address of a specific page. This flaw allowed unauthorized persons to access the personal data of 424 children.

World Class România S.A., an employer, shared a termination letter of one of its employees in a WhatsApp group used by its employees. This action resulted in all members of the group gaining access to personal data of the employee, including their surname, first name, address, ID number, and information related to the request for termination.

Disqus Inc. provided a plugin used by various Norwegian websites. When visitors accessed these websites, Disqus tracked their activities and collected data. This data was then shared with third-party advertisers, presumably to enhance advertising strategies and target audiences more effectively.

respondent: XI District Office of the Government of Budapest
case_content: The XI District Office of the Government of Budapest collected health data regarding Covid-19 rapid tests and the contact details of individuals who were tested. This information was compiled into a single Excel file. The office then emailed this file to doctors without encrypting it or implementing any additional measures to ensure the confidentiality of the data. Furthermore, the office did not inform the data protection authority or the individuals whose data was compromised about the data breach.

ParkkiPate Oy, a company responsible for issuing parking tickets, required individuals who received parking tickets to provide their ID card number and address to process requests for information about their personal data or to delete their data. The company claimed that the name and parking ticket number were insufficient for identity verification. Additionally, ParkkiPate Oy stored photos of incorrectly parked cars and copies of parking tickets for potential future legal disputes without setting a deletion deadline.
violated_articles: Article 12 - Transparent Information, Communication and Modalities for the Exercise of the Rights of the Data Subject
Article 17 - Right to Erasure ('Right to be Forgotten')

case_content: A data subject discovered that her personal data was accessed 20 times from the credit register of the National Bank of Belgium. The data subject's ex-husband, who works for the financial company, allegedly used his position to access her financial information without her consent. The ex-husband sought to use this information to gain an advantage in their ongoing divorce proceedings. The company failed to implement adequate organizational measures to prevent unauthorized access to personal data.

A data subject began receiving email advertisements from OneDirect Srl without having given consent. Despite the data subject's repeated objections to receiving these emails, OneDirect Srl continued to send them and did not respond to the objections. Additionally, OneDirect Srl failed to maintain a register of its processing activities.

Planet Group Spa, acting on behalf of TIM s.p.a., made promotional calls to a large number of individuals. These calls were made to 47,981 telephone numbers without obtaining the necessary consent from the individuals. Additionally, the company failed to respect the individuals' right to object to such calls. In one instance, an individual was contacted 155 times in a single month despite having exercised their right to object.

Mediacom s.r.l. conducted advertising calls on behalf of TIM s.p.a. using contact lists acquired from third-party companies. Some of these calls were made to individuals who had not consented to receive such calls, had objected to them, or had their numbers listed on the Robinson list, which is a registry for opting out of telemarketing calls. Mediacom did not verify the legitimacy of the data in these contact lists or ensure that valid consents were obtained from the data subjects for the promotional activities.

In 2017, the municipality of Enschede decided to install special measurement boxes in the city center to measure crowd density. These boxes contained sensors that detected wifi signals from the cell phones of passers-by and registered them with a code. This system allowed the municipality to calculate how busy the city center was. However, it also enabled the tracking of which measurement box a particular cell phone passed by, thus tracking the movement of passers-by. The municipality claimed that tracking individuals was not its intention.

A data subject requested the deletion of their personal data from Anytime Fitness Iberia S.L. The company confirmed the deletion of the data. However, despite this confirmation, the data subject continued to receive SMS advertisements from the company.

A data subject requested the deletion of their personal data from Pagamastarde S.L., a company that had been sending them SMS advertisements. The company confirmed the deletion of the data. However, the data subject continued to receive SMS advertisements from the company. The company later stated that the failure to delete the data was due to a human error.

A company accessed and copied personal data from public registers. The data was collected without assessing the necessity of such action for their operations. The company did not obtain consent from the individuals whose data was copied, nor did it have a legitimate purpose for processing this data.

A state-subsidized organization decided to enhance its public image by sharing photos of its employees on its official website. The organization believed that showcasing its workforce would highlight its commitment to transparency and community engagement. However, the organization did not obtain explicit consent from the employees before publishing their photos online. The employees were not informed about the specific use of their images, nor were they given the opportunity to opt-out of this public display.

A public school shared personal information of its students with the municipal mayor. The mayor then disclosed this information through the city radio mobile application, making it accessible to the public.

A TV broadcaster provided information on its website regarding the processing of personal data. However, the information was not easily accessible as it was hidden, and it was also inaccurate because it contained links to outdated legal provisions. This situation led to confusion among website visitors about how their personal data was being processed.

A company decided to enhance its customer identification process by storing biometric signatures of its customers. The company believed that using biometric data would streamline the identification process and improve security. Customers were asked to provide their biometric signatures during registration or service usage. The company stored these biometric signatures in its database for future reference and verification purposes.

A bank requires customers to provide a copy of their identity card as a condition for opening a new account. Customers are informed that without providing this copy, they will not be able to proceed with the account opening process. The bank collects and stores these identity card copies as part of their account verification procedure.

A healthcare provider utilized a software solution provided by an external body to collect personal data from patients. The patients were not informed about the data collection process, nor were they made aware of the involvement of the external body in handling their personal data.

A public university required personal data from students applying for admission. The university collected this data as part of the application process, but it did not have a sufficient legal basis for processing the personal data of the applicants. The university did not obtain proper consent or provide a valid legal justification for the data collection.

respondent: Municipality of San Marco in Lamis
case_content: The municipality of San Marco in Lamis uploaded documents on its website that contained personal data of an individual and his family. These documents were related to a proceeding against the individual concerning construction activities without a building permit. The documents included sensitive information such as the date of birth, place of birth, tax number, and address of the individual and his relatives. The individual had previously requested the municipality to remove these documents from the website, but the municipality did not comply.

A parliamentary candidate contacted a private individual on her private mobile number to promote his candidacy for the Greek parliamentary elections in July 2019. The individual questioned the candidate about how her personal data was obtained, but received contradictory responses.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: HazteOir.Org, an organization, created and distributed a brochure on sex education intended for schools. This brochure included the photos and names of three individuals. These individuals had not provided their consent for their personal data to be used in this manner. The brochure was made available to schools and potentially the general public, as part of an educational initiative.

A private individual installed a surveillance camera on their property. The camera recorded not only the individual's property but also the public space and neighboring properties. The individual claimed the camera was installed for security purposes to protect their property.

Basaren Drift AS installed video cameras on its premises to record activities. These cameras captured footage of both employees and customers. The company did not provide adequate information to the individuals being recorded about the surveillance, nor did it establish a legal basis for the data processing involved in the video surveillance.

Highcliffe Estates Marbella S.L., a company, published a photo of an individual on its website. The individual did not provide consent for their photo to be used or published by the company. The photo was accessible to the public through the company's website.

A person ordered goods from a company and received an invoice from a different company. The person contacted the company that supplied the goods to inquire about the source, processing, and legal basis of her personal data. The company did not respond to her request.

Several individuals were contacted by sales staff for advertising purposes. These individuals had previously used the services of the sales staff to conclude insurance or financial contracts until around 2016. At that time, the sales staff were working for a different company with which they had an agency contract. The sales staff used personal data known from their previous activity to contact these individuals for advertising purposes on behalf of a new company.

A non-governmental medical facility operator offers diagnostic tests to patients. The results of these tests are communicated on the operator's website to both the patients and the physicians who recommended the tests. An unknown individual attacked the operator's website, leading to a security breach. In response, the operator stopped operating the affected website and proposed technical measures to increase security. However, it was found that other websites operated by the same operator had similar security shortcomings, and no new technical measures were taken for these sites.

The owner of a pub installed two video surveillance cameras that covered parts of the public space outside the pub. These cameras were intended for security monitoring purposes. However, the owner did not obtain the necessary authorization or consent from individuals who might be captured by these cameras while in the public space.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: Lugera & Makler Broker S.R.L. was acting as a data processor for Raiffeisen Bank S.A., handling customer data. During this process, Lugera & Makler Broker S.R.L. accidentally destroyed the data of Raiffeisen Bank's customers. This incident occurred because Lugera & Makler Broker S.R.L. did not implement sufficient technical and organizational measures to ensure the protection of the data they were processing.

Three former customers of Vodafone España S.A.U. received unsolicited text messages from the company informing them of new invoices, despite having no ongoing contractual relationship and no outstanding payments. The former customers repeatedly requested the cessation of these messages and the deletion of their data. Vodafone attributed the messages to a technical error and assured the customers that the issue would be resolved, but the messages continued.
violated_articles: Article 17 - Right to erasure ('right to be forgotten')

case_content: A private individual, who owns and rents out apartments on the 2nd and 3rd floors of an apartment building, installed four video cameras on the three floors and in the entrance area of the building. The individual justified the installation of the cameras with security concerns related to renting the apartments to tourists. However, the owners' association had not granted permission for the operation of the cameras, and the individual did not put up a sign in the building to inform about the operation of the cameras. The cameras covered areas of the building used by the community.

Ιγνατιάδης Νικόλαος και ΣΙΑ Ε.Ε. installed surveillance cameras in areas where employees were present, claiming the purpose was for security due to past theft incidents. The intention was to detect people entering the facilities.

respondent: S.C. Tip Top Food Industry S.R.L.
case_content: S.C. Tip Top Food Industry S.R.L. installed several video cameras in the food areas and changing rooms to surveil its employees. The purpose of the CCTV installation was to deter theft and protect the manufactured goods.

A ski rental company, due to the high value of its sports equipment, required customers to provide either a financial deposit or a full copy of a valid ID when renting equipment. The consent for copying the ID was included in the rental agreement itself, meaning that when customers signed the rental agreement, they simultaneously consented to the processing of their ID copy. However, the customers were not properly informed about how their personal data would be processed.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: Mall.tv operated two cameras that recorded parts of a public space. The footage captured by these cameras was broadcast in real time on internet television. The resolution of the footage was high enough to clearly identify people and vehicles passing by.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: A former customer of Kutxabank, S.A. had previously exercised his right to erasure of his personal data. Later, when he attempted to open a new account with the bank, he was informed that his data was still blocked due to the previous erasure request. The bank informed him that to open a new account, he would need to unblock his data. A form was provided to him, which stated that by signing it, he would revoke his right to erasure and allow the bank to use his data again.
violated_articles: Article 17 - Right to erasure ('right to be forgotten')

case_content: Azienda Ospedaliera Universitaria Careggi experienced a data breach involving the transfer of health data to an incorrect recipient. The incident occurred when medical documents intended for a patient were mistakenly sent to another patient. This happened because a doctor, while retrieving his print job, also took the print job of a colleague, which contained the affected patient's documents. The ward where the incident occurred was equipped with only two printers, contributing to the mix-up.

At a carwash operated by Miljø- og Kvalitetsledelse AS, incidents of vandalism occurred at the payment terminal. In response, the company sent footage from a surveillance camera capturing the incident to the employer of the person they believed to be the vandal.

The municipality of Asker maintained an email distribution list for sending documents. On their website, users could view the names of documents that had been sent via this list. However, these document names also included personal data such as names and dates of birth of 127 individuals, including children. Despite daily proofreading by two people, the municipality failed to detect these discrepancies, leading to the exposure of personal data.

A parliamentary candidate contacted a private individual on her private mobile number to promote his candidacy for the Greek parliamentary elections in July 2019. The individual questioned the candidate about how her personal data was obtained, but received contradictory responses.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject

case_content: Promotech Digital S.L. sent advertising SMS messages to a data subject who had not subscribed or agreed to receive such messages. The SMS did not provide a direct option to unsubscribe, instead referring to cancellation via email. Despite the data subject's objections to receiving further SMS, the messages continued.

A data subject requested information from Stockhunters S.L. regarding the use of their personal data. The company was unable to provide a satisfactory response to the data subject's requests. Additionally, the data protection policy on the company's website did not comply with the requirements set out in Article 13 of the GDPR, leaving the data subject uncertain about how their personal data was being used.

Electrotecnica Bastida S.L., an employer, had medical examination results of its employees. These results were placed in envelopes addressed to the respective employees. However, 29 of these envelopes were found discarded in a vacant lot in a local industrial area, with two of them already opened. This situation raised concerns about the protection of personal data.

Kukimbia S.L., a company involved in storing, transporting, and distributing goods, had documents containing personal data about its customers and suppliers. These documents were found freely accessible next to a trash can near one of the company's warehouses.

respondent: Fastweb S.p.A., Call Centers, External Partners
case_content: Fastweb S.p.A., a telecommunications provider, engaged in telemarketing activities through call centers. These call centers used telephone numbers not registered in the official Italian register for communications operators. Additionally, Fastweb received contact data from external partners without obtaining valid consent from the data subjects. Users reported being contacted by individuals claiming to be Fastweb operators, who attempted to collect identity documents via WhatsApp. Furthermore, the 'call me back' service procedures did not allow users to give informed consent or deactivate the service easily.

A parent filed a complaint against the Lazio Region School Authority for forwarding data about his disabled son to the Office of Public Administration. The data included information about the child's health condition. The parent had previously raised concerns about irregularities in the allocation of support hours for students with disabilities at the school I.C.G. Pitocco of Castelnuovo di Porto. In response, the school authority transmitted the data to clarify the allegations.

respondent: Roma Servizi per La Mobilita S.r.l.
case_content: Roma Servizi per La Mobilita S.r.l. was responsible for processing data related to citizens who had obtained permits to access restricted traffic areas in Rome. The data was processed by scanning QR codes on badges affixed to vehicle windshields, allowing city staff to verify in real time whether a vehicle was permitted in the zone and to whom the permit was issued. However, the QR codes could be scanned by anyone with an ordinary QR scanner, potentially exposing personal information such as the name of the user and the vehicle's license plate number.

The city of Rome implemented a system to manage permits for accessing restricted traffic areas. These permits were verified using QR codes on badges placed on vehicle windshields. The QR codes could be scanned by city staff to check if a vehicle was authorized to be in the restricted zone and to identify the permit holder. However, the QR codes could also be scanned by anyone with a standard QR scanner, potentially exposing personal information such as the name of the permit holder and the vehicle's license plate number. Additionally, the city of Rome engaged a service provider for hosting and maintaining the databases without establishing a proper agreement as required by GDPR.

Gedi Gruppo Editoriale S.p.A., a media company, published photographs in its newspaper of individuals who were in custody in connection with a murder case. These photographs depicted the accused individuals in handcuffs, and although some parts of the images were pixelated, the faces of the accused were still visible, allowing for their identification. The photographs were taken and published without obtaining consent from the individuals depicted.
violated_articles: Article 10 - Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences

respondent: Foundation for Religion and Worship 'Casa sollievo della sofferenza' Opera di San Pio da Pietrelcina
case_content: The Foundation for Religion and Worship 'Casa sollievo della sofferenza' Opera di San Pio da Pietrelcina, acting as a data controller, mistakenly sent documents containing health status information of a data subject to the wrong addressee. This error occurred due to a mix-up where an invoice was initially sent to another person with the same name as the data subject, and the incorrect address was subsequently used for further correspondence intended for the data subject.

respondent: Municipality of Commezzadura, Mayor of the Municipality
case_content: A former employee of the municipality of Commezzadura discovered that a document containing his personal data was published on the municipality's website. This document included details about his voluntary termination of employment, evaluations of his work, and information about his health. Additionally, a newspaper article mentioned this information, discussing the end of his employment and quoting a statement by the mayor about the employee's request for flexible working hours and his absence during the Christmas vacations due to illness.

In December 2018, criminals gained unauthorized access to the personal data of 4,109 individuals who had booked hotel rooms through Booking.com. This data included names, addresses, phone numbers, and booking details. Additionally, the credit card information of 283 individuals was accessed, with the security code being compromised in 97 cases. The criminals attempted to obtain further credit card details by impersonating Booking.com employees via email and phone. Booking.com became aware of the data breach on January 13, 2019, but delayed reporting it to the Dutch Data Protection Authority until February 7, 2019.

Dragefossen AS, an energy company, installed a webcam on the roof of its office building in the center of Rognan. The camera operated 24/7, recording the city center, and the footage was available via a live video stream on YouTube and the company's homepage. The camera's coverage included a public street, parking lot, entrances of grocery stores, a pharmacy, a liquor store, a bank, city hall, and other buildings. Although facial details and license plates were not discernible, the image quality allowed viewers to identify the type of car, clothing, hair color, and other personal characteristics of individuals. This enabled viewers to identify and track people such as co-workers, colleagues, friends, family, or other acquaintances. The surveillance affected a significant number of employees and members of the public, who were monitored repeatedly, often daily, as they went about their daily activities.

A former employee of the municipality of Conflenti discovered that a document containing her personal data, including details about her employment and an excerpt from her termination letter, was published on the municipality's website. This publication was done without her consent or authorization, leading to a breach of her privacy.

Air Europa Lineas Aereas, SA experienced a data breach where unauthorized individuals accessed contact details and bank account information of approximately 489,000 individuals. The breach involved 1,500,000 records and affected people not only in Spain but also worldwide. Sensitive banking and financial data were compromised, impacting several thousand people.

In Ålesund, Norway, teachers at two schools required students to download and use the Strava app for physical education classes. The app was used to assign tasks and track students' activities. However, the municipality did not establish standard procedures to ensure the app's use was compliant with privacy regulations. Specifically, a data protection impact assessment was not conducted, and adequate technical and organizational security measures were not implemented to protect the students' data.

A company installed CCTV cameras for security purposes. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they not only monitored the company's premises but also captured footage of adjacent public spaces. The intention was to enhance security by monitoring potential threats. However, the cameras inadvertently recorded individuals in public areas, leading to concerns about privacy and data protection.

S.C. Medicover S.R.L., a healthcare provider, experienced multiple incidents where personal data, including names, correspondence addresses, emails, and health data of patients, were sent to unintended recipients. These incidents were due to the lack of appropriate technical and organizational measures to secure the data during processing.

The data subject, a former customer of Vodafone Spain, began receiving payment reminders via SMS for services she had never booked. She contacted Vodafone Spain to request clarification and deletion of her data. Despite receiving assurances that the issue had been resolved and her data deleted, the SMS messages continued. The data subject filed multiple complaints with the Spanish DPA, each time receiving assurances from Vodafone Spain that the problem had been corrected, yet the messages persisted.

A client of Asesoría Alpi-Clúa S.L. requested specific documents to be sent to her for submission to the tax authorities. The controller, Asesoría Alpi-Clúa S.L., sent an email to the client. However, instead of sending the requested documents, the email contained documents belonging to another client.

Heredad de Urueña S.A. operated a website where users interacted with the platform. However, the company did not provide a privacy policy on its website to inform users about how their personal data was being processed. This lack of transparency meant that users were unaware of the specifics regarding the collection, use, and storage of their personal data by the company.

A cultural association conducted Chinese lessons and took photographs of a four-year-old child participating in these lessons. The association then shared these photographs on various groups of the Chinese messenger service WeChat. Although the association attempted to obscure the child's face with a digital sticker, the child's face was still partially visible. The parents of the child requested the association to delete the photos and issue an apology, but the association did not respond to these requests.
violated_articles: Article 17 - Right to erasure ('right to be forgotten')

case_content: A school conducted a survey on student well-being using a smartschooling system. The survey collected data on the well-being of minor students. The school did not obtain consent from the parents of these minor students before conducting the survey.

In 1999, Regione Lazio entrusted Capodarco with the management of reservations for healthcare services. However, Regione Lazio did not designate Capodarco as a data processor through a formal contract. This lack of a proper contract meant that the data processing activities carried out by Capodarco were not governed by the necessary data protection agreements. It wasn't until 2019 that a proper contract was established, ensuring compliance with data protection laws.

In Italy, small and medium-sized companies that had previously received a relevant voucher could book advice on technological and digital processes from experienced business professionals through the Ministry of Economic Development. The Ministry published personal data of more than five thousand managers on its website, making it freely accessible. The data included names, tax numbers, e-mails, full CVs, and in some cases, copies of identity cards and health cards. Additionally, a directorate resolution approving the list, which included all the directors' data, was also available for download.

In 2009, a data subject renewed her driver's license with Certime S.A. In 2018, she changed her address but did not inform Certime S.A. In 2019, she received mail from Certime S.A. at her new address, notifying her about the upcoming expiration of her driver's license. Upon inquiry, Certime S.A. informed her that they regularly updated their database with data from the Spanish transport authority DGT. The data subject had not consented to this processing of her data and filed a complaint.

An identity thief obtained the personal data of a third party without authorization. Using this data, the thief applied for a microcredit from NBQ Technology, S.A.U., pretending to be the data subject. NBQ Technology, S.A.U. processed the application and approved the loan based on the data provided, which belonged to the data subject and not the actual loan applicant.

A private individual installed a video surveillance camera that faced a public thoroughfare and covered parts of the shared patio of an apartment complex. The camera was installed without any visible sign informing about its presence, the responsible person, or the purpose of the surveillance. Additionally, the individual did not obtain the consent of the other tenants before putting the camera into operation.
violated_articles: Article 13 - Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject
Article 14 - Information to be provided where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject

case_content: Since 2018, Vodafone España, S.A.U. engaged in marketing campaigns that involved making advertising calls and sending messages (e-mail and SMS) to data subjects. These communications were made without obtaining prior consent from the data subjects. Additionally, the communications continued even after the data subjects had exercised their right to object. Many of the data subjects contacted were also listed on the Robinson list, which is a list of individuals who have opted out of receiving marketing communications.

A data subject received over 60 advertising SMS messages from Xfera Móviles S.A. within 30 days, despite having objected to receiving such messages and requested the deletion of their data. Additionally, the data subject received messages containing confidential login information of another customer, allowing access to personal information and invoices on a company platform. The data subject informed the company, but the incorrect mailing continued.

The data subject had outstanding payments of rent with her landlord, who had previously sent her corresponding requests for payment. The controller, Equifax Iberica S.L., had also sent notices to the data subject requesting her to pay the debts. However, these notices did not contain any information that the data subject would be entered in the debtors' register in the event of non-payment. Additionally, the rental contract of the data subject did not contain any provisions regarding the entry into a debtors' register.

The Istituto Nazionale Previdenza Sociale (INPS) was tasked with conducting anti-fraud investigations related to COVID-19 relief funds. As part of this task, INPS collected data on tens of thousands of politicians from public sources and cross-checked it with data from applicants. The data collection included individuals who were not eligible to receive the assistance funds. Additionally, INPS initiated checks on reimbursements for individuals whose applications had been rejected and who had never received payments. Furthermore, INPS did not conduct an impact assessment on the rights and freedoms of the data subjects involved in the processing of applications for social benefits.

The municipality of Luino published a document on its website that contained personal data of a local council member. This document also included details about a complaint procedure filed against the council member by the mayor. The document was freely accessible and could be downloaded by anyone without any authentication. Additionally, the municipality did not appoint a data protection officer nor did it provide the contact details of such an officer to the relevant data protection authority.

The municipality of Santo Stefano Belbo published two documents on its website related to a legal settlement involving a data subject. These documents were freely accessible and downloadable by the public. The documents contained personal data of the data subject, including their first and last name, confirmation of payment of legal costs, IBAN code of their checking account, information about the lawsuit, and amounts paid in favor of the data subject.

Filigrana Comunicación S.L.U. operates a website that provides information on internships and publishes the results of various competitions held by the Spanish Ministry of Education and Sports. The company compiled and published data of participants from publicly available sources without obtaining consent from the data subjects and did not fulfill its information obligations to them.

VfB Stuttgart 1893 AG, a soccer club, was involved in a situation where they were responsible for managing personal data. During their operations, they failed to uphold their accountability obligations under the GDPR. This situation arose due to negligence in their data protection practices.

A homeowners' association held a meeting to discuss planned legal actions against some residents. The association publicly displayed the meeting record in the building's elevator, revealing the names, floors, and apartment numbers of the participants, as well as the floors and apartment numbers of neighbors who were subjects of complaints during the meeting. The association justified this public notice by stating that it was necessary to inform the residents about the planned legal actions to prevent claims of not receiving relevant notifications.

An employee of Enea S.A. sent an email containing an attachment with personal data of several hundred individuals. The attachment was neither encrypted nor password protected. The email was mistakenly sent to an unauthorized recipient, who was not intended to receive this information.

An individual filed a complaint with the Polish Data Protection Authority (DPA) regarding a procedure conducted by the company Anwara Sp. z.o.o. The DPA sent written requests to Anwara Sp. z.o.o. asking for explanations related to the complaint. Despite the letters being properly sent, the company did not respond to the requests or provide any reasons for its lack of cooperation.

A General Secretary for a political party in Bucharest published a list on a social network. This list contained personal data of ten supporters of the party, including their names, signatures, nationalities, dates of birth, and postal addresses. The publication was intended to showcase the support for the party.

The Electricity Authority of Cyprus implemented an automated system to manage, monitor, and control employee absences due to illness. This system utilized a tool assessment based on the so-called Brad-Factor. Employees' absence data was processed by this system to evaluate their absences.
violated_articles: Article 22 - Automated individual decision-making, including profiling

case_content: KEPIDES, a real estate company, compiled a list of buyers for the properties it manages. This list, containing the names of the buyers, was submitted to a parliamentary committee. The list was not anonymized, resulting in the transmission of personal data.

The data subject submitted a written request to the Cypriot Real Estate Registration Authority, seeking various personal information about himself, exercising his right of access under GDPR. The authority did not respond to this request.

In 2015, Hellenic Bank closed one of its branches in Nicosia. During the move, a safe containing old documents of existing customers was forgotten in the building. The building remained vacant for several years. In 2019, when the property was rented out again, the new tenant discovered the safe and informed the bank. The bank staff retrieved the documents and reported the incident to the Cypriot DPA.

Waitum, S.L. and Servicios Aby 2018, S.L. had entered into a network access agreement with I-DE Redes Eléctricas Inteligentes, S.A.U., under which they transferred their customers' personal data to the electricity supplier. The supplier, acting as the electricity provider, sent letters to the customers of these two companies. The letters contained information about alleged breaches of contract and non-payment by Waitum, S.L. and Servicios Aby 2018, S.L. to the supplier. The customers were represented by the two companies in their dealings with the supplier.

Registrų Centras, a company responsible for managing several Lithuanian registers, experienced a data breach affecting 22 of these registers. The company had implemented certain technical and organizational measures to protect personal data, but these measures were inadequate. As a result, the integrity, availability, and resilience of the data were compromised, and the company was unable to restore data availability after incidents.

A private individual took photos of vehicles and, in some cases, their drivers. The individual then emailed these photos to the city of Magdeburg. The purpose of sending these photos was to report violations of the Road Traffic Regulations. The photos were sent in an unencrypted form.
A website operator published photos of an individual on its website. The website did not have a privacy statement available.
A company instructed one of its employees to set up automatic forwarding of their work email to a shared company account. The company justified this action as a means to improve its operations.

In spring 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic, a company named 'IT sprendimai sėkmei' developed a quarantine app for use in Lithuania. The app was utilized by the Lithuanian National Health Service to monitor individuals during the quarantine period. The app collected personal data, including names, addresses, phone numbers, and health data of 677 individuals. However, the company did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures to protect the data. Additionally, a data protection impact assessment was not conducted, and the app's privacy policy contained non-transparent and incorrect information.

During the COVID-19 pandemic in spring 2020, the Lithuanian National Health Service (NVSC) introduced a quarantine app developed by the IT company 'IT sprendimai sėkmei'. The app was designed to manage quarantine measures and processed personal data of 677 individuals, including names, addresses, phone numbers, and health data. The NVSC, as the data controller, was responsible for ensuring the protection of this data. However, the app lacked sufficient technical and organizational measures to safeguard the data, and a data protection impact assessment was not conducted. Additionally, the app's privacy policy provided non-transparent and incorrect information.

Between May 25 and November 16, 2018, the Tusla Child and Family Agency experienced 71 data breaches involving unauthorized access to personal data. These breaches were reported to the Irish Data Protection Authority. The breaches involved personal data processed by the agency, which was accessed by unauthorized individuals.

respondent: Budapest University of Technology and Economics
case_content: The Budapest University of Technology and Economics conducted audits of applications for social scholarships. During this process, the university processed personal data of the applicants. This included processing particularly sensitive data, which was not necessary for the evaluation of the scholarship applications.

Two parents contacted their credit institute to request a suspension of repayment for a 'childbirth incentive loan'. To process this request, the credit institute required proof that the fetus was at least 12 weeks old. The parents provided their pregnancy booklet, and the credit institute copied the entire booklet, which contained extensive health data.

A consumer, who had registered their contact information in the Robinson advertising exclusion list to avoid receiving unsolicited marketing communications, received advertising calls from Avilon Center 2016 S.L. The company used the consumer's contact information for advertising purposes without obtaining the necessary consent, despite the consumer's explicit registration in the exclusion list.

A security company, acting as a data processor, was responsible for managing video surveillance footage. An employee of the security company recorded the footage using a phone and shared it with a third party. This recording was subsequently made available on social media and in the media. The security company failed to maintain adequate technical and organizational measures to protect personal data for over two and a half years. After the incident, the company did not implement sufficient security measures to prevent or minimize risks. As a result, a data subject was exposed to public insults and ridicule. The company did not take action to remove the recording from social networks and media.

Ripobruna 207, S.L., a restaurant, installed two video surveillance cameras. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they recorded not only the restaurant's premises but also parts of the public space outside. The restaurant did not have a justified cause for recording the public space, nor did it obtain the necessary authorization from individuals who might be captured in the footage.

Krajowa Szkoła Sądownictwa i Prokuratury, a national school for justice and prosecution, was in the process of migrating its training platform to a new system. During a test migration, the personal data of over 50,000 individuals, including names, usernames, postal and email addresses, telephone numbers, and departmental information, were inadvertently exposed on the internet. The school had contracted a company to handle the data processing, but the contract lacked specific details about the categories of data to be processed.

In a hospital operated by Azienda Usl di Bologna, a manual error by a technician led to 49 patients in the oncology ward receiving discharge letters that contained detailed pharmacological therapy information intended for other patients. Fourteen of these patients accessed the incorrect documentation before it was corrected.
A data subject requested access to their personal data and their daughters' data from Poliambulatorio Talenti S.r.l. The request was not responded to in a timely manner.

In the first incident, parents of a minor child discovered a microbiological examination report of another patient in their child's file. This report contained the other patient's name, tax number, address, birth date, and various health data. In the second incident, the heir of a patient received a health report belonging to another patient, which included the name, birth date, and health status of the data subject.

A hospital, Azienda Ospedaliero Universitaria Senese, mistakenly sent a couple's medical report to an uninvolved third party. The report contained sensitive information about a genetic consultation, as well as details about the health status and sex life of the couple. The error occurred due to a mistake in packaging the letter.

A patient arrived at the gynecology unit of a hospital for the purpose of an abortion and explicitly requested that her health data not be shared with third parties. She provided a specific telephone number to be contacted for further communication. After being discharged, a nurse attempted to contact the patient to inform her about further therapy. Instead of using the provided contact number, the nurse used the patient's home telephone number from her file. The patient's husband answered the call, and the nurse disclosed information about the patient's treatment, despite the patient's request for confidentiality.

Azienda sanitaria provinciale di Enna, an employer, implemented a system to process the biometric data of its employees. The purpose of this processing was to register the attendance of the employees. The biometric data, which is considered sensitive, was collected and processed without establishing a legal basis or obtaining the necessary authorization from the employees.

The Washpoint S.L., a service provider, operates a website where users can access various services. However, the website does not display a privacy policy, which is essential for informing users about how their personal data is collected, used, and protected. This lack of transparency means that users are not informed about the handling of their personal data when they visit the website.

respondent: Regional Environmental Protection Agency of Campania (ARPAC)
case_content: The Regional Environmental Protection Agency of Campania (ARPAC) stored personal data, including identity documents, tax records, and payroll records, on an external hard drive. This hard drive was kept in a room accessible to all employees of the agency. Unfortunately, the hard drive was stolen, and the data was not backed up, leading to its irrevocable loss.

Between 2018 and 2020, the Amsterdam hospital OLVG did not implement sufficient measures to prevent unauthorized access to patient medical records. The hospital failed to adequately monitor who had access to these records and did not ensure that their computer systems were secure enough. As a result, working students and other employees were able to access patient files, which included sensitive information such as medical records, social security numbers, addresses, and telephone numbers, even when it was not necessary for their work.

A former customer of Vodafone España, S.A.U. continued to receive e-mails containing electronic bills even after terminating his contract with the company. Despite objecting to this several times, the customer still received these communications.

Lursoft IT SIA, a company, published documents containing personal data on its website 'www.lursoft.lv'. These documents were part of a non-public company register, which included personal data of individuals. The data was made publicly available without proper authorization.
violated_articles: Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data

case_content: University College Dublin (UCD) experienced multiple personal data breaches where unauthorized third parties gained access to UCD email accounts. The login credentials for these accounts were posted online. UCD did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure data security in its email service. Additionally, UCD stored personal data in email accounts in a manner that allowed identification of data subjects for longer than necessary for the intended purpose. Furthermore, UCD failed to notify the Irish Data Protection Commission (DPC) of a personal data breach in a timely manner.

A former employee of a hospital unlawfully copied the personal data of 100 patients from the hospital's computer network. The data included sensitive information such as social security numbers, names, dates of birth, addresses, and telephone numbers. The hospital's controller assessed the potential risk to the data subjects as high but did not inform the data subjects about the incident.

respondent: ING Bank N.V. Amsterdam - Bucharest Branch
case_content: ING Bank N.V. Amsterdam - Bucharest Branch sent files to a contractual partner to issue insurance policies. The files contained outdated information because employees of the insurance policy monitoring department did not check and process the insurance policies according to the work process. This affected 270 people.

A data subject, who had registered in the Robinson advertising exclusion list to avoid receiving unsolicited marketing communications, received an advertising call from Vamavi Phone S.L. on behalf of Vodafone España, S.A.U. The call was made despite the data subject's explicit registration to opt-out of such communications.

A company operates a website that is accessible to the public. Visitors to the website expect to find information about how their personal data is being collected and used. However, the company does not display a privacy policy on its main page, nor does it provide the necessary information required by the GDPR to inform users about data processing activities. This lack of transparency leaves visitors unaware of how their personal data is being handled.

A landlord installed a video camera in an apartment where two rooms were rented out to tenants. The landlord claimed the camera was for security purposes and was positioned to monitor the entrance door. However, the camera also captured footage of other areas, including the living room, where the tenants had a reasonable expectation of privacy.

The complainant, who worked for a construction company, carried out renovation work for Patio Ancestral S.L. During these works, damage was caused to the properties of Patio Ancestral S.L. The company then sent a letter with claims for damages not only to the complainant but also to the complainant's father, who was previously employed by the same construction company but was uninvolved in the current case.

A property owner installed two video surveillance cameras on their property. These cameras were positioned in such a way that they not only monitored the property but also captured footage of the public space, including sidewalks and neighboring properties. The cameras continuously recorded video footage, which included images of individuals passing by on the public sidewalks and those on adjacent properties.

The data subject, a customer of Iberdrola Clientes, SAU, terminated their contract due to relocation and requested the deletion of their personal data. The company rejected this request, citing outstanding invoices as the reason. However, the company continued to send bills to the customer's old address, even after being informed of the address change. Despite the customer's notification, further communications regarding the deletion request and invoices were also sent to the outdated address.

Charly Mike s.r.l., the operator of Hotel Olimpo in Alberobello, installed a video surveillance system consisting of 17 fixed cameras and one 360° recording camera. These cameras were placed both inside and outside the hotel, capturing footage of employees and customers. The hotel did not display the required signs indicating the presence of video surveillance.

A person received a debt collection email from IDFINANCE Spain S.L. The email contained a link for the payment of an invoice directly through the controller's website. Upon clicking the link, the person was able to view the personal data of another customer.

A data subject requested information from Xfera Móviles S.A. regarding their personal data. The data subject felt their right to information was not respected and filed a complaint with the Spanish Data Protection Authority (AEPD).
